movie_review_blurb: A melancholy meditation on guilt and grief, powered by deeply empathetic performances from the three leads.
Though the sequel's brisk pace and imaginative monsters should keep kids relatively fidget-free, it fails on almost every other level.
movie_title: Spy Kids 2: The Island of Lost Dreams (2002)

movie_review_blurb: Reasonably entertaining, until you realize that Soderbergh doesn't have much more on his mind than some not-very-revealing observations about Tinsel Town artifice.
This real-life Hollywood fairy-tale is more engaging than the usual fantasies Hollywood produces.
movie_title: The Kid Stays in the Picture (2002)

movie_review_blurb: A fascinating case study of flower-power liberation -- and the price that was paid for it.
Devos' performance goes a step further: She gets us rooting for Carla, even though we know she's just setting herself up for more pain.
Each story is built on a potentially interesting idea, but the first two are ruined by amateurish writing and acting, while the third feels limited by its short running time.
If you can surrender to the pace, it's more deeply satisfying than your usual summer fare.
Fortunately, Elling never gets too cloying thanks to the actors' perfect comic timing and sweet, genuine chemistry.
Witherspoon puts to rest her valley-girl image, but it's Dench who really steals the show.
Pacino hasn't been this good in ages, dropping his usual mannerisms to dig deep into his multi-layered character, and Williams makes a chillingly serene psycho.
Though ultimately derailed by an underdeveloped romance and an overly sappy ending, About a Boy shows signs that the Weitz brothers are near cinematic adulthood.
The screenplay is too obvious in its critique of arranged marriages, and its portrayal of Zaza's malicious parents is smugly cynical.
After years of rehashing the cuddly genie from Aladdin, Williams reminds us why he became a star in the first place.
Too bad writer-director Adam Rifkin situates it all in a plot as musty as one of the Golden Eagle's carpets.
Up until its oddly flat ending, Princesa is an honest depiction of the way dreams can backfire.
The personal stories in Sandi Simcha DuBowski's film are as beautifully and softly braided as challah bread.
Weber comes across as dishonest about his true interest in the gorgeous wrestler at the center of his film.
It's refreshing to see a food film that for once doesn't pour on sentimental cooking-as-life metaphors.
The script is a clunker, the acting atrocious, and there's not even enough panda footage to keep the kids happy.
Hammers home every cartoonish cliché of recent drag comedies.
Proves a tragic look into how war can break allegiances -- even long after the physical battles have ended.
Tingwell and Blake deliver astonishingly lived-in performances.
Its central mystery is less intriguing and more predictable than your average game of Clue.
The movie never builds any rhythm; it just sputters its way toward the end credits.
It's to the film's credit that [Schneebaum is] neither vilified nor romanticized.
movie_title: Keep the River on Your Right (2000)

movie_review_blurb: Ullman isn't able to harness the intensity this confessional tale needs.
Ultimately ... the movie is too heady for children, and too preachy for adults.
Chuck and Buck, director Miguel Arteta and writer Mike White have crafted an insightful portrait of inertia, and offer a complex look at the fine line between victim and victimizer.
A well-rounded tribute to a man whose achievements -- and complexities -- reached far beyond the end zone.
With its rushed pace and isn't-this-wacky soundtrack, the film exudes TV shallowness, and by the time it arrives at its absurdly happy ending, it has all the impact of a pinch.
Green might want to hang onto that ski mask, as robbery may be the only way to pay for his next project.
In the end, it's hard not to be impressed by the way Bad Santa rips into sanctimonious holiday traditions with the demented glee of an 8-year-old unwrapping an X-Box.
A powerful piece of agitprop.
Though the direction is amateurish in spots, the film boasts a winning cast of characters, energetic musical numbers ... and a genuine compassion for kids who prefer Damn Yankees to a Yankees game.
Surprisingly endearing in moments thanks to finely tuned comic performances, especially from Brody.
Its noble intentions are undermined by syrupy, movie-of- the-week direction.
A hilarious and often touching tribute to a true American underdog.
Thoroughly mediocre kiddie flick.
movie_title: Sinbad: Legend of the Seven Seas (2003)

movie_review_blurb: Caper flicks should stay two steps ahead of the audience, and this one just barely keeps pace.

Moncrieff unfolds the tale with the bare-bones grace of an expert novelist, making subtle connections but never telling the audience how to feel.
The movie floats around aimlessly between condescending dumb-blonde comedy, soggy love story and follow-your-destiny corn.
Exploring the flipside of Tautou's adorable pixie is an interesting idea, but this movie just isn't up to the task.

movie_review_blurb: There's much to recommend about Buffalo Soldiers, starting with Joaquin Phoenix, whose antihero character oozes sinister charisma, and Ed Harris, playing against type as a spineless colonel.
The film's strengths are overshadowed by Green's flawed script, which wobbles awkwardly between art-house eccentricity and trite Hollywood sentimentality.
While Broomfield's film doesn't capture the effect of these tragic deaths on hip-hop culture, it succeeds as a powerful look at a failure of our justice system.

While there's obviously no single easy answer to the questions his film raises, Moore jumps from topic to topic without ever really digging below the surface or looking for counterpoints. That said, his questions are crucial ones.
The movie stays afloat thanks to its hallucinatory production design.
The film is hampered by its predictable plot and paper-thin supporting characters.

The performances here are impeccable ... and Haynes has created a beautiful world that seems eternally stuck in autumn, but the plodding, hesitant story feels as artificial as the Whitaker's love life.
As pure over-the-top trash, any John Waters movie has it beat by a country mile.
The strong performances do make it worth a look.
Not surprisingly, director Martin Scorsese delivers an ambitious spectacle with jaw-dropping sets and bone-crunching battles.
An utterly believable and gut-wrenching portrait of Midwestern loneliness.
It's an unforgettable story, and a welcome return to form for Polanksi.
The movie has a richness that blows away most first features, not to mention most sports movies.
The cast of unknown actors, many from the real ghetto, provides the movie with unexpected heart and humor.
This indie feature lifts a beloved cartoon template, but can't hit the bar it sets.

Although the film may not always be as aesthetically involving as better-budgeted productions, the performances are really the point, so by keeping focused on her actors Seimetz succeeds in making it all work.

The social and economic pitfalls facing the vast urban underclass of Manila's sprawling metropolitan area are depicted with unflinching regard in Ron Morales' observant low-budget Filipino feature, a blend of ruthless crime drama and grim thriller.
An intense family drama that plays out as a low-key Western.
You needn't be a true believer to appreciate Rebecca Thomas's indie feature rooted in a traditional Mormon community.
Catnip for the bookish emo demo.
Beyond a few chuckle-worthy one-liners and some amusing visual comedy, there's not much to engage adults, although the wee ones should be distracted enough.
Misguided exercise in genre fetishism marks a forgettable misfire.
Determined and persuasive filmmaking pays off with a moving and remarkable true-life account of groundbreaking musicianship.
Not that it isn't entertaining, but the film's premise is certainly well past its "use by" date.
Writer-director Maggie Carey's feature debut boasts a crack ensemble cast led by Aubrey Plaza that evocatively captures the carefree elation of youthful summer romance.
Adding another must-see item to their portfolio will surely only increase One Direction's popularity.
There's little to fear from this rather tame genre outing.
More than a tribute, the film is a recognition of the talent and sacrifice that many of these vocalists have invested in often challenging careers.
A biopic that's perhaps too respectful of the tech icon's innovations still remains frequently engaging.
More comedic drama than midlife romantic comedy, rather literally titled Hope Springs holds few surprises but delivers plenty of warmth.
An intuitive approach to this literary classic yields dividends for both style and performance.

Addressing the heartrending issue of children living with HIV and AIDS is enormously complex, but Blood Brother accomplishes the challenge with sufficient grace and empathy to give hope to anyone concerned with this global affliction.
A rough DIY style doesn't obscure the significance of this very timely documentary.
Although Gregorini is very clear on where her lead characters are coming from, it's where they're headed that remains entirely vague, an oversight that leaves them unfortunately adrift.
This compassionate account of the thrills and risks of extreme sports makes it required viewing for both aspirants and enthusiasts.
Not even a checklist of indie film attributes can inject a sense of originality into this familiar narrative.
A low-key sci-fi mashup that charms by focusing on character rather than grandiose special effects.
Peralta's doc is a generous, tasty slice of skateboarding history.
With a mix of retro eye-candy for grown-ups and a thrilling, approachable storyline for the tykes, the film casts a wide and beguiling net.
This once-innovative series rolls on without much regard for either plot or character development.

Engaging enough, although not entirely satisfying from either a genre or narrative standpoint, lacking both substance and a degree of imagination.
More is not necessarily better, even when it comes to hot bodies and smooth dance moves.
A doomed parody that's almost painfully unfunny.
With a scruffy demeanor and wide-eyed enthusiasm, LaBeouf projects a degree of emotional recklessness that's both disarming and disconcerting to watch.
Faithful to the template if not the spirit of previous installments, this flabby second sequel barely manages to advance Riddick's considerable personal mythology.
An edgy premise and memorable cast make for a potent first impression.

movie_title: Codependent Lesbian Space Alien Seeks Same (2012)

movie_review_blurb: The jokes start growing stale well before the film's midpoint.
The too-infrequent scare techniques ... are mostly by the book, rarely developing sufficient dread to heighten the film's rather unremarkable climax.

Consistently engaging, although never outright challenging.

The law of diminishing returns is inexorably setting in with the third iteration.

Despite occasional disregard for the laws of physics, much of the imagery displayed onscreen is so realistic and thrill-inducing that sometimes even the plot becomes almost secondary during the more intensely visual sequences.

This disarmingly low-key genre-hybrid delivers both dramatically and comedically.

Turning the screenwriting over to adaptation experts Scott Neustadter and Michael H. Weber has preserved the distinctly literate tone of the book, even if they do occasionally deliver scenes that feel overwrought.

The actors manage as best they can with the material, but it's an uphill struggle.

A skillfully wrought feature with appreciable emotional and historical resonance.
A film of quiet intensity and poetic imagery.

movie_review_blurb: Rose-tinted as the film's perspective may be, Ping Pong Summer is still a lingering, entertaining glance back at an era that Americans just can't seem to get enough of, whether in music or movies.

Lacking both originality and thrills makes a weak formula for a suspenser.
Episodic doc could use more focus on food preparation, but vividly captures the human element involved.

With most of the running time devoted to setting up and over-explaining the premise, mayhem gets short shrift.

A suspenseful, compelling indictment of Japan's deadly dolphin-exploitation industry.

An imaginative, sympathetic spin on a classic horror theme.
A docu that makes pounding the pavement appear utterly uplifting.
A winning comedy that entertainingly elevates a low-profile sport.
A fairly routine crime procedural more suitable to the small screen than the wide screen.

[A] dizzying mashup of frenetic visual styles and clashing narrative techniques.

Too dimwitted to be disappointing.

Simultaneously a tribute to a seemingly bygone era and an affirmation of the sometimes unexpected resilience of father-son bonds.

movie_title: RUMBLE: The Indians Who Rocked the World (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Lacks a ... sense of originality and urgency, undercut by overly familiar characterizations and dilatory pacing.
Sinister 2 comes up a bit short on creative resources, although director Ciaran Foy probably gets enough right to entice those partial to the original.
Stark repeatedly squanders the decent supporting cast, revealing scant backstory that would enhance the often vague character motivation on display.

Futerman makes a momentous discovery that she adeptly shapes into an affecting emotional journey as well as a telling example of how the fortuitous intervention of social media continues to reshape lives in unexpected ways.

Although some may miss the immediacy of a rampaging kaiju destroying everything in its path, this is an entirely different breed of movie that's potentially even more effective for its shift in style and tone.
Kerem Sanga's The Young Kieslowski is a teen pregnancy comedy that suggests the nimble dialogue and plotting of Juno from a male perspective, minus the excessive self-regard.

[Levin] has an instinctive affinity for the Kentucky countryside setting and distinct empathy for the travails facing farming communities. Aside from a few scattered scenes however, the threats faced in Runoff feel generic.
Insidious: Chapter 3 offers a relatable young protagonist and several key supporting players from the prior films in a nimble setup to the series.
A fun-enough teen action comedy.

Together with cinematographer Steve Yedlin and VFX supervisor Colin Strause, director Brad Peyton achieves a persuasive blending of practical shots and superior CG techniques for the most complex sequences.
The three actresses display a realistic camaraderie, but their characters are insufficiently actualized to achieve adequate differentiation.

Leaving behind the youth-skewing perspectives of Monster House and City of Ember, director Gil Kenan not only delivers on the promise of Hooper's Poltergeist, but significantly raises the stakes for similar PG-13 fare.

[Writer-director Bradley] understands the inherent drama in Noble's life story, as well as the necessity of varying the narrative's chronological progression by alternating time periods in the film in order to maintain ongoing interest.
Intermittently amusing but rarely as funny as it wants to be.
Knowing that the situations depicted in actor and filmmaker Adam MacDonald's Backcountry are based on "true events" only makes them more harrowing to watch unfold onscreen.
A playful tone and passable performances can't overcome an unremarkable premise and predictable plotting.
It's A Year in Champagne's dedication to sharing the winemakers' own experiences, along with their anecdotes about this most quintessential of wines, that makes the film so enticing.

Lee's most accessible film yet looks poised to capitalize on enduring 80s nostalgia and a refreshingly appealing premise that could see the film crossing over from niche bookings to much broader appeal.
Merkins gets by on its considerable wit and a few genuinely hilarious moments for the first hour, then tries to play catch-up in the final 30 minutes by attempting to capitalize on marginal subplots.

A slow-burn approach seems to pose a challenging change-up for the filmmakers, who struggle to build tension as the second acts stretches well past the point when the level of menace should be escalating.
[A] humorous and touching new documentary.
By turns touching, funny and sometimes strangely existential.

Genre enthusiasts will get a kick out of Todd Strauss-Schulson's creative homage to classic slasher movies, which respects familiar horror conventions while introducing a sly contemporary perspective.
This ensemble comedic drama maintains a light touch while surveying the challenges of accepting adult responsibilities.
Drucker's eponymous documentary relies primarily on Chu's lower profile, post-Jeopardy! period for material, which comes off as rather uneventful ...

The Nile Hilton Incident represents the type of penetrating filmmaking that only a writer-director intimately familiar with Egyptian culture but possessing an outsider's perspective could convincingly accomplish.
Motherland not only provides an expressively etched account of specialized medical care, but also a telling perspective on dominant social trends and healthcare policy issues in the Philippines.
A lively inquiry that reveals more contradictions than consensus.

For anyone curious about the inner workings of the wine trade and the heritage of outstanding world wineries, Jason Wise's follow-up to his 2012 documentary Somm will help decipher many of these sometimes obscure topics.
An engrossing and accessible celebration of the game's modern origins, enhanced by striking locations and a standout cast, led by Scottish actors Peter Mullan and Jack Lowden.
An insightful, affecting film that casts sympathetic light on a neglected educational sector.
Although the intent is clearly to create a somewhat disorienting visual experience, it's the consistently derivative plotline that's really at issue.
Almost as engaging as the man himself.
Nicely observed, but misses the mark.

For those who've endured the long gap between Bad Santa movies like kids eagerly anticipating Christmas, this sequel brings it on like Saint Nick's overstuffed bag of goodies, with plenty to entertain (and offend) everyone.
A fully realized depiction of elemental fear and desperation, The Monster's modest scale should attract discerning genre fans while establishing a firm basis for potential cult status.
The filmmakers' enthusiasm for their characters and the vanished period setting is palpable, asserting a certain fatalistic charm of its own.
Killam, who recently departed SNL after six seasons, shows a great grasp of his character's escalating bewilderment and frustration.

Rather than a conventional inquiry into the circumstances and personalities that contributed to Albert's deception, Feuerzeig allows her to tell her own story, eschewing most other sources involved in her professional debut.
Often involving, although not quite entirely satisfying.
Often narratively cryptic and stylistically uneven.
Daly has crafted a carefully calibrated portrait of emotional loss in its various manifestations.
An unimaginative drama that never quite gains momentum.
Leena Yadav's third feature is a contemporary morality tale that critiques the often harsh treatment of women in the absence of egalitarian social norms.
A scrappy doc profiling boxer Claressa "T-Rex" Shields' unlikely ascension to Olympic competitor.

Not many DIY preteen bands can inspire a massive YouTube following, but the trio of young African-American musicians comprising Brooklyn-based heavy metal group Unlocking the Truth is exceptional in many respects.
A surprisingly maternal horror movie that relies as much on fraying emotional bonds as supernatural suspense to create tension.
The risks inherent in our Internet-connected lives are brought into sharp focus by Ratter, a bracingly effective low-budget suspenser.
Alex Simmons' debut feature is a fleet, consistently amusing 80-minute jaunt through the woods.
The 1980s in southern India receive affectionate reimagining in Brahman Naman, a coming-of-age-comedy about sex-obsessed college students and their quest to lose their virginity.

With its attractive young cast and a multiplatform media campaign, Nerve won't need to rely on going viral to find its audience, but it's unlikely to be trending for long once viewers digest its simplistically cautionary message.
Magic tricks become shorthand for the power of personal transformation in JD Dillard's modestly scaled thriller that's equally an accessible domestic drama.

While some fairly unconvincing theories are tossed out in frequent debates concerning the underlying purpose of the Purge, they mostly remain within the limits of the film's fundamental themes of exploitation and disenfranchisement.

An emphasis on the women's reactions to a variety of discriminatory situations starts to resemble a checklist approach, ticking off situations that cover career challenges, marriage dilemmas and personal relationships.
Draper's thorough research process yields fascinating details on the lives and careers of the athletes, particularly their early histories as amateur competitors.
Whether it's credulity or audience cynicism, Ten9Eight: Shoot for the Moon has a problem, and good vibrations won't solve it.
Memory is a recurrent theme in Varda's work, and with this film she serves her own with warmth and skill.
movie_title: Les Plages d'Agnès (The Beaches of Agnes) (2008)

movie_review_blurb: That movies from this brand will have "heart" is now a given, but the variety Rudd provides here is singular.
There's a general overbearing unpleasantness to Observe and Report, and you get the feeling this was the intention -- in order to make it more "like life."
Greg Mottola's third feature is more emotionally rich than his The Daytrippers and Superbad, but it's still more interested in the comedy than the woe and anxiety of the transition into adulthood.
The movie is ungainly, but to appreciate it one has to swallow the whole purple pill. As inconsistent as it is, it's still more album than mix tape.
Stillman's rounded-out and embroidered telling is the kind of movie people call "delicious," "sparkling," and "a comic romp," and it is indeed all of those.
Shows a Wiseman-like respect for the day-to-day heroics that keep the lights on.
Not to be overlooked in talk of The Departed's suspense and violence is how incredibly funny it is.
If anything's soft in Concussion, it's the storytelling and conventionalism of the filmmaking.
If the likes of His Girl Friday and Ball of Fire are the standards, Leatherheads can be forgiven for falling short.
As both politics and entertainment, it's lacking.
As the story becomes more about the various undercover ops and the contradictory workings of Whitacre's hateful-lovable mind, The Informant! has an undeniable crackle.
Before his initial transformation inside the bottling plant where he works, Banner warns, "Something bad is about to happen." He's right.
Howard has successfully made an okay, watchable movie, kept from greatness only by his undying artistic blandness.
Viewers on guard for the sin of condescension will have their expectations dashed.
The Messenger is always just left of straightforward, which keeps it interesting.
It's Heslov's sarcastic, assuming tone, not the actors, that makes Goats so intolerable, and it begins immediately with the opening credits.
movie_title: The Men Who Stare at Goats (2009)

movie_review_blurb: The adequate, amber-toned digital look, corny scoring, historically accurate costuming, era-appropriate peopling, and slowly-connect-the-dots storytelling together give the film the competent, stolid feel of a well-made informational video in a museum.
I'm glad I knew almost nothing going in, so I won't say much more, except that the masterful slow burn is its own payoff
A qualified, perfectly respectable success
It's methodical, distancing and sarcastic, like all of their movies. And like all of them, it's exciting cinema, "eminently watchable," as one of its characters would say.
More exhausting than funny, though it is often both, Ben Stiller's latest excoriation of ego wears you down with its smothering, pop-savvy cynicism.
Before the Bad/Dirty boom, it still felt kind of shocking to see an antihero alcoholic racist in a Santa Claus suit having sex with prostitutes in a major motion picture.
Burn After Reading maintains comic balance, and after so many smart, gutsy Coen movies (many in the note of madcap), that shouldn't be a surprise.
The one-bunker setting ultimately proves only a little more novel a trick than Cloverfield's shaky cam, and its pressure to deliver the goods lets it down.
One is always conscious that a master genre filmmaker still in command of his gifts is at the helm, and the many pleasures the film provides are testament to the fact.
[Last Flag Flying] is most comfortable within the tangles of these kinds of knotty intricacies.
Too brief and good-looking to actively dislike, Paranoid Park is still uninspiringly repetitive. If you're going to play the same riff over and over again, at least lower it an octave.
It's a bit disappointing that Redbelt doesn't go much beyond a redux of the same-old.
It's easy to overstate the varied accomplishments here because of how badly it might have gone. That it landed somewhere between adequate and excellent is satisfying enough.
[Whatever Works] has defenses built into it.
None of the scenery, plot turns, bit players or "themes" add anything new to the recipe.
You get the sense that this film was probably a lot more fun to make than it is to watch.
Hickson's largely silent performance is superb (in the kind of complex role not typically given to black actors in modern horror movies), never overselling his creeping madness.
The movie is befuddling, but not because of plot convolutions. It keeps you at a distance when it seems singly concerned with the particular plight of the "art family."
There are enough unexpected turns and inspired mini-monologues to make this an imperfect gem.
The promise of bad behavior was just bait to bring an audience to a warm-at-core and shopworn story of a woman overcoming adversity.
Sometimes over-infatuated with its own meta stratagems though it may be, Kate Plays Christine's machinery of wheels is always cranking vigorously.
As usual with action comedies, the presence of one genre dilutes the other.
A welcome alternative to the teased-at-ComicCon kid's stuff. Which isn't to say that Inferno is good.
It's unclear what the film's detractors found so risible.
WTF moves with fleet, mostly smart precision, and when it's repetitive... it's meant to emphasize the out-of-body "Kabubble" isolation of Kim's Afghanistan years.
Hackford has proven himself capable of greatness in the past (Against All Odds, Dolores Claiborne), but his playbook here is rote.

Fifteen years after the fact, the sequel risks jeopardizing the goodwill generated by the pretty-good and unexpected original, recycling too many okay jokes and references while failing to update it for the times in any substantial way.

There are moments of Hitchcockian uneasiness, accentuated by Cruz's typically stellar performance and her disturbingly close resemblance to Audrey Hepburn (which lends a feeling that this delicate flower could be crushed in an instant).
It's a manipulative guiltfest that drags its feet more sluggishly than its elderly protagonist.
The biggest detriment to Marshall's work is his continued insistence on segregating the music from the film.

Emily Blunt is remarkable, her sleepy eyes (true to photographs of Queen Victoria) compensated by a vibrant physicality and the sense that something's going on behind her gaze, a rare and valuable quality in actors.
A yarn that at times feels like a throwback to the mega-actioners of the '80s, when leads could get away with being incorrigible cards as long as they had someone by their side to keep them grounded.
As hard as it tries, Red Cliff just can't muster the heavily filtered mythmaking of the war films of Steven Spielberg and David Lean. And thank goodness for that.
Reitman wants to have his cake and eat it, too.
Although Freeman was born to play Mandela, this is not the Mandela he deserves.

Sheridan's stellar past work informs and uplifts Brothers and brings out some of the best performances of the year; in the case of Tobey Maguire as the soldier and Natalie Portman as his wife, these are the best performances of their careers.

It's hard to argue with Goldthwait's assertion that society's search for spokesmen leads to false prophets, but it feels like an observation well-made many times over in the '90s, at the height of anti-celebrity culture.
Curtis takes great joy in huddling an ensemble of misfits together, connecting them loosely and then sitting back and watching them all become a messy family.
It's too easy to dismiss Sheen's work as basic mimicry; in fact, Sheen's Clough is his most intricate work thus far.

By throwing both paranormal rumors and sadly true events at the wall, the writer and director make the whole production feel like a messy experiment -- but one that, nonetheless, is a lot of fun to partake in.
movie_title: The Men Who Stare at Goats (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Many have come close, but An Education is the first film this year to grab me by the lapel and whisk me along with its characters...
Pleasant in a flavored-rice-cakes kind of way.

It's puzzling that a paean to Gertrude Berg's Jewish New York housewife, Mrs. Goldberg -- a character so beloved and enduring that she could serve as a travel guide through early-to-mid-20th-century history -- could fall so flat.

Joel and Ethan Coen have the ability to sit their audience down in front of a black screen and make them feel comfortable with two very important factors: 1) They will not understand everything that's going on, and 2) they won't care.

The story congeals into a sometimes sweet and other times raucous comedy, yet also loses its grip.
Let's start with the title, which is problematic by nature: There is nothing more than a game on display here.

movie_title: Precious: Based on the Novel Push by Sapphire (2009)

movie_review_blurb: The Messenger is the first film from Oren Moverman as a director, and it's a fine piece of work.
With his forced smile and willowy cadence, Common plays basketball star Scott McKnight as if he's a newly lobotomized serial killer - and that's when his character is supposed to be happy.

The kind of fake movie that you sometimes see in the background of real movies as a joke.
It's a soufflé helplessly set out in the middle of a KenTacoHut stampede, and I suspect it will pay dearly for that at the box office.

Schneider spends copious amounts of celluloid introducing us to characters with no real character arcs in service of an event that's not seen as much of an event at all.

I marveled at Wright's utter disregard for stage business; his characters never quite finish menial tasks like washing their hands. I reveled in the imaginative detours of the film's transitions and garage-rock aesthetic.
This being a Steve Carell vehicle, these moments of elevated humor coexist alongside crass gags, but not as uncomfortably as you might think.
A debut feature that replaces the Coen brothers' humor in similarly labyrinthine comedies of errors with Arthur Penn's grit and Peckinpah's tense string tuning.
A film so ugly in every respect that it should come with a free ticket to a Toy Story 3 screening to follow immediately just so audiences can wash its stink off of them with something truly great.
If the film itself is slight, there's no diminishing the heft that Bridges brings.

Its core joke is decades late, and any nostalgic retro-pastiche the Richard Dean Anderson show might have held in American culture has been thoroughly used up already by The Simpsons and a 2006 Super Bowl commercial for Mastercard.
Harry Brown thrashes, telegraphing its punches from a mile away and whiffing every other knockout attempt, but when it connects, it's a whopper.

Borte's polished treatment of the material feels confidently in service of his point -- it's an assuredness that reminded me of David O. Russell -- and the actors involved commit to their situation wholeheartedly and entertainingly.

Featuring inspired casting, gleeful performances and smoothly handled story transitions, Date Night employs Steve Carell's and Tina Fey's peerless knack for selling absurdist lines to deliver something resembling a comedy classic.
The single most boring film ever made about rock & roll.
Clash of the Titans isn't art, but it's a specialized craft that turns men into boys and film critics into optimistic -- OK, slightly less cynical -- popcorn consumers for the briefest of moments.
A sharply detailed, wondrously three-dimensional fantasy in which its maker intuitively grasps so much of what's good about the tale while simultaneously blind to what makes it great.
Deeply, insultingly flawed.
As with all of Haneke's films, the only insight to be had is internal; your reactions and thoughts say more about yourself than the film.

From the moment we meet Max, however, all of that flies out the window as we soar out of our own expectations and into the fantastic world Jonze presents.

[It] takes advantage of yet another anniversary celebration of the three-day music festival, but Lee only uses the milestone for surface draw. Otherwise, this aimless, pointless, emotionless and self-aggrandizing debacle would have no reason to exist.
A film for everyone in the economic bottom 95 percent.
I'm not sure which is more offensive: That Cuarón believes these scumbag brothers are heroes, or that the biggest scumbag in the film can be a hero to all.
Many will point to the delirious preciosity of Wes Anderson's work as a reference point. I would suggest that even Anderson's recent work could use an injection of [Rian] Johnson's celluloid rapture.
Terminator Salvation: the least they could give us.
Smithsonian whips itself into a kind of frenzied exhilaration that's both fun and funny.
movie_title: Night at the Museum 2: Battle of the Smithsonian (2009)

movie_review_blurb: As it jogs toward its climax, Lymelife fails to ratchet up the tension by turning the screws of the plot.
It's a film made with utter contempt for its audience by the most cynical of Hollywood players that shrugs off any notion of mythology, character development or joy.
The approach is flighty at best and a cinematic bait-and-switch at worst.
It's a smart, edge-of-your-seat thriller that doesn't just tap into the zeitgeist but hooks up a keg funnel.
This agonizing romantic comedy about a nice boy and his grandpa relearning the 'game of love' raises far more questions than it answers.

This is no mock-doc joke. Director Sacha Gervasi deftly introduces us to irrepressible frontman Steve 'Lips' Kudlow and his ever-suffering lifelong sidekick Robb Reiner (seriously), who were and remain fine musicians but simply never quite caught on.
Adventureland is one of the best films of the year because it sticks by its own heart.
Good-natured but slightly toothless and, in the end, forgettable.
This remake is faithful in plot but not in spirit.
movie_title: The Last House on the Left (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Coraline, a stop-motion 3-D fantasia, is Alice in Wonderland without an Alice.
Taken is a completely enjoyable, low-key actioner.
It is worth an hour and a half to watch those two charm each other with literary quotations, ballroom dancing and moments of unexpected vulnerability.

A harmlessly entertaining, old-fashioned epic that fuses a SciFi Channel-esque space-colonization parable with an Iron-Age period actioner.
In the documentary Encounters at the End of the World, there's a twist that swiftly counters Herzog's instincts: Mankind's industrial supremacy has not excluded the South Pole.
movie_title: Encounters at the End of the World (2007)

movie_review_blurb: The Incredible Hulk isn't a work of art, but director Leterrier had the sense to recognize that it wasn't supposed to be art in the first place. His film delivers on something called 'fun'.

Biel still appears uncomfortable. She would do well to get more experience under her belt before reaching for a corset. If she caught any break, it's that Easy Virtue only pretends to be upscale cinema.

If Guggenheim had let it play as is, without splicing in choppy life-story filler, then it might have been a rock doc for the ages.
Has Lady Jane gone as chaste as the PG rating on Bright Star suggests? You have no idea.

O' Horten moves slowly, sometimes excruciatingly so, but its thematic center is strong: How do you run out the clock of life?
Dancy and Byrne do a fine job of portraying these two lost souls.... How unfortunate for them that they're forced to spout miles of Mayer's cutesy babble every time they're close to transcendence.

The standard action plot demotes District 9 from a potential game-changer to simply a very good film. And considering the painful summer movie season we've endured thus far, you can't ask for much more than that.

movie_review_blurb: Year One is a horse designed by committee to make a camel, and Harold Ramis, as much as today's comedy stars owe him, is an unadaptable species.

Densely written and expertly directed with performances that rank among the year's best...

Location is Fincher's strongest quality, and every log cabin, train station and archival vault here feels lived-in, bone-chillingly cold and full of surprises.
movie_title: The Girl with the Dragon Tattoo (2011)

movie_review_blurb: I don't mind a tender tribute to the man who made such a tender impact on the world, and the astounding archival footage is worth a million "dark turning points."
An Ashton Kutcher/Katherine Heigl rom-com vehicle with pretty dresses.

Everyday Sunshine is an uplifting entry that rises to its task rather than letting the music do all the talking.
movie_title: Everyday Sunshine: The Story of Fishbone (2011)

movie_review_blurb: Banderas still looks great in a suit, and Almodóvar is still a masterful artist concerned with sex, art and exotic Brazilians.

Any film that elicits wide-eyed comments like, "What a story!" afterward is inherently successful.

movie_title: The Odd Life of Timothy Green (2012)

movie_review_blurb: It's a good-natured, humanely observed dramedy, geriatric or otherwise.

Oh, man. Man, oh, man.

No matter their age, show this to kids you care about, and tell them it gets better.

movie_title: Tim and Eric's Billion Dollar Movie (2012)

A heartwrenching tale of wish fulfillment on a nearly molecular level...
Giamatti and Hoffman may be the two most unlikely movie stars ever to grace the big screen and to see them together is a treat...
Caruso continues to elevate any material he touches...
Bellamy is a perfect film for Chabrol to go out on.

A satisfying and often very funny film.

movie_title: You Will Meet a Tall Dark Stranger (2010)

movie_review_blurb: The lightest Cuckoo's Nest imaginable.
movie_title: It's Kind of a Funny Story (2010)

movie_title: The Elephant In The Living Room (2011)

movie_review_blurb: Somehow the two keep from killing each other - or even griping all that much - long enough to make it through a hefty chunk of pleasing celluloid.
A boldly old-fashioned romantic comedy with the rare quality of being both romantic and comedic.

movie_title: Page One: Inside the New York Times (2011)

movie_review_blurb: I think I'm done with robots.

"Hey, marketing is all around us, man! Like, everywhere you look there are logos and somebody trying to sell us something. Weird."

Children of the night, what disgusting movies they make.
The movie gets muted and routine.

A well-crafted, great looking adventure, with some spirited performances!
Rozema's movie ... in trying so hard to entertain, ends up sabotaging itself.

Brisk, shallow, highly condensed version of a telenovela.

... an illuminating and challenging experience for audiences.

Full marks to director Matt Reeves for capturing the human emotions and expressions of his actors even as they grunt and walk like simians.

Everything here is bigger, louder, brasher, more political, more expensive, more violent. ... The movie never flinches, though you might.

movie_review_blurb: I don't think I can say anything funny about this, because it makes me want to die.

In the space of 90 minutes, it captures some of the worst acting ever committed to film...

A crass, classic, take-the-money-and-run ripoff which squanders a golden opportunity to make a statement about racial profiling, the Patriot Act and the Geneva Conventions in favor of serving up a mindless teensploit laced with shockingly-graphic images.
movie_title: Harold & Kumar Escape from Guantanamo Bay (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Engaging, unpredictable, hilarious and entertaining at every turn, this charming thoroughly modern romantic romp offers all you could ever ask of a cross-cultural comedy, plus it paints a plausible picture of the pitfalls of sending jobs overseas.

Whether designed with a pacifist agenda or simply intended to make the case for a return of the draft, this compelling saga compassionately establishes that Iraq War veterans shouldn't have to be wounded physically to be considered damaged goods.
A hilarious, class-conscious French farce which features more coupling and uncoupling than you might be able to keep track of.
Jailbait gone wild, Parisian-style!
A latter-day Casanova meets his match in the reincarnation of Lorena Bobbitt!
A slight, surreal cinematic experiment apt to enthrall the more discerning theatergoer, while leaving the mundane masses scratching their heads and asking, 'Is that it?'
movie_title: Le Voyage du Ballon Rouge (The Flight of the Red Balloon) (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Roots documentary chronicles reunion of blacks and whites linked by ancestors to same slave plantation in North Carolina.

Despite the plot's predictability, this formulaic sitcom written by its talented star, Tangi Miller, is well-enough executed with the help of a colorful supporting cast to be rated a worthwhile rental.
A pleasant period piece harking back to days of yore, but one so superficial that it's likely to be forgotten by the time you file up the aisle.
A cautionary tale sounding the alarm that we're close to the tipping point of wholesale ecological disaster, if not already irreversibly past it.
The original Beverly Hillbillies, only sans the cement pond.
Examines the before and after mindsets of hardened cons converted to an Eastern spiritual path.
Like Amelie with an attitude, this sinister flick links strangers serendipitously, but with an almost shocking absence of naivete.
A feel-bad peek at how the other half lives showing that no one knows what goes on behind closed doors.
An over-the-top romp which rehashes lots of dumb drug jokes but breaks far enough away from the tried-and-true teen formula to earn a high mark even from this jaded critic.
movie_title: Harold & Kumar Go to White Castle (2004)

movie_review_blurb: Juno 2, and just as inspired.
This masterfully-crafted, multi-layered murder mystery proves that the legendary Sidney Lumet hasn't lost his edge, despite being well into his eighties.
movie_title: Before the Devil Knows You're Dead (2007)

movie_review_blurb: An emotionally-engaging testament to the indomitability of the human spirit even in the midst of the most dire of circumstances.
A well-crafted, slice-of-life saga which amply illustrates how easily matters might go from bad to worse in the already-overburdened inner-city when disaster strikes in the 'hood.
Career of modern classical composer revisited by generally reverential retrospective.
movie_title: Glass: A Portrait of Philip in Twelve Parts (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Though this snuff flick takes its title from an asexual stage of reproduction in the life of a fungus, don't expect to find any fungi, I mean fun guys, in this lame excuse for graphic displays of vivisection.

A chilling expose' which shows how Holocaust internees have been victimized twice, violated again by purveyors of smut who would stoop so low as to fabricate a pack of sadomasochistic lies for a quick buck.
A comical crime thriller where you're likely to find yourself more amused by the unintentionally funny goings-on than trying to solve the underlying whodunit.
Ups the ante in terms of shock value by appealing to perhaps the lowest common denominator yet, starting with an opening scene featuring gratuitous shots of male genitalia. Two schlongs up!
An inspiring affirmation of the power of friendship, courage, determination, hard work and faith to sustain even those seemingly trapped in the most dire of circumstances.
We're supposed to buy the idea that the Swazis will be saved by Africa's answer to Paris Hilton? Yeah, right. Proof-positive that despotism and decadence comes in all colors.
Bio-pic about the last reigning monarch on the continent governing just about the only sub-Saharan nation untouched by civil war or ethnic cleansing, despite the world's lowest life expectancy at 31.
Provided you have a strong stomach for bovine torture, the film is likely to prove entertaining, for it relates an otherwise admirable overcoming-the-odds saga.
It's never a good sign when a movie makes you laugh out loud at dialogue intended to be taken seriously.
An estrogen-fueled salute to the virtues of excess, if that's your Gucci bag.
Mountain-climbing undertaken with a manic sense of urgency.
A chilling reminder of why John Lennon once wrote a song entitled, 'Woman is the [N-word] of the World.'
movie_title: The Greatest Silence: Rape in the Congo (2008)

movie_review_blurb: A damning indictment of the White House which concludes that 9/11 was less a failure of intelligence than a willful failure to act.
Don't tase me bro!
You will marvel at just how naked the beautiful and talented Natalia Avelon remains scene after scene.
The worst sci-fi comedy since, well, since Eddie Murphy made The Adventures of Pluto Nash.
Dude, where's my wife and job?
A touching bio-pic about a humble soul who encountered racism and responded with love, peace and goodwill towards all people.
You heard it here first: the late Heath Ledger will win an Academy Award for his defining, spine-tingling performance as The Joker.
A novel buddy vehicle contrasting the unique perspectives of a two segments of society ordinarily either marginalized in movies or treated almost as if they didn't exist at all.
More comical than compelling, but what do you expect of a chopsocky revolving around a head case of a hero begging to be buried alive in order to channel his psychic powers?
Best if approached as a nostalgic curiosity shot a half century ago rather than as a conventional flick offering a satisfying cinematic experience.
An exhilarating film for the ages not to be missed, either for its enlightening peek inside the elite mind of an extraordinary individual or for its ethereal tribute to the Twin Towers.

A nice gesture, but in the sequel I'd like to see these refined rednecks really shaken out of their comfort zone. How about taking these folks north of the Mason-Dixon Line to see how the other half of the country lives before they miss out on the 21st C.

Director David Redmon earns accolades galore for crafting a dmning expose' which brilliantly contrasts the plight of exploited Asian females with the embarrassing behavior of drunks and bimbos floating up Bourbon Street on Fat Tuesday.
More truth than reconciliation in post-Apartheid revenge flick.
The Orient's relatively-eloquent answer to Eminem's 8-Mile and 50-Cent's Get Rich or Die Tryin', replete with gangsta' rap on the soundtrack.
A delightful indulgence in the lyric form likely to restore your faith in the Hip-Hop Generation.
movie_title: Graffiti Verite' 7 - Random Urban Static: The Iridescent Equations of Spoken Word (2008)

movie_review_blurb: A scathing indictment of the fashion industry which is designed to drive home the point that the airbrushed and digitally-altered standard of beauty popularized by the mainstream media is unattainable, because even the models don't really look like that.
The Bar Mitzvah Boy gets the boot!
America revisited as a post-democratic Banana Republic.

A tenderhearted morality play, set in the Mississippi Delta Region, which offers an array of valuable insights about what really matters most in life while simultaneously delighting you for its duration.
A string of shameless sales pitches sans the rudiments of a major motion picture. Next time, how about including an ending if you're going to ask us to sit through two hours of commercials?
Who would think that full-fledged American citizens, born in the United States, could have lost their liberty, homes and businesses, never to recover financially or emotionally?
A moving, if belated tribute to a host of visionary iconoclasts who were unappreciated if not outlawed or outright assassinated in their time.
Sidesplitting, high attrition-rate, S&M slapstick where you get to savor the sight of characters getting tortured to death about five times each, if that's your bag of grass.
A compelling bio-pic about one bad mother (shut your mouth!) who could have written a Bible for today's ghetto gangstas on how to be a player.
movie_title: One Bad Cat: The Reverend Albert Wagner Story (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Shot entirely in black and white, this endearing, low budget indie offers as compelling a combination of character development, credible dialogue and surprising plot twists as you're likely to encounter between now and New Year's Eve.
movie_title: In Search of a Midnight Kiss (2008)

movie_review_blurb: An ill-fated love triangle with a surprising twist and a chilling message for shameless gold-diggers and suave Casanovas alike.
movie_title: La Fille Coupée en Deux (The Girl Cut in Two) (A Girl Cut in Two) (2008)

movie_review_blurb: An intelligent and frequently funny film with some profound points to make about the shallowness of the movie industry.
With exhibitionist Will Ferrell finding another excuse to expose himself in a movie, he's leaving himself in danger of going down in cinematic history as the man who nude too much.
Devalued-dollar documentary drives home the point that a country which consumes more than it produces is unsustainable.

There's an irony in the contrast of Iraqi-Americans talking about life in this country and watching the military-industrial complex putting the finishing touches on young emlistees about to ship out to a godforsaken land to kill or be killed.
Hilarious, provided you have a very strong stomach for modern minstrelsy.
movie_title: Katt Williams: The Pimp Chronicles: Pt. 1 (2006)

movie_review_blurb: A kinky alternative to The Da Vinci Code for conspiracy theorists with cast iron stomachs.
movie_title: Mother of Tears: The Third Mother (2007)

movie_review_blurb: The worst sci-fi concept since The Adventures of Pluto Nash placed Eddie Murphy on the moon.
Adam Sandler takes on terrorism as Israeli agent-turned-hair stylist in raunchy shock comedy.
movie_title: You Don't Mess With the Zohan (2008)

movie_review_blurb: A curiously-compelling and impossible to pigeonhole romantic romp which blurs the line between pornography and legit cinema in magnificent fashion.
Taiwanese titillation flick featurings watermelon as a metaphor.
An animated cross of Rocky and The Karate Kid certain to delight this generation of tykes afresh.
Makes Soul Plane look like The Great Debaters.
A tearjerker certain to elicit concern and compassion from anyone watching for the billion on the planet's homeless.
Eighty is the new Forty!
Queen takes pawn, Czech-mate!
Examines how the generation of Chinese recently come of age has adjusted to the country's embrace of capitalism and the ensuing rush to rapid modernization.
What's more annoying than when a mediocre movie constantly males allusions to much better pictures? I know, it's when you wait an hour and a half for a solution this pathetic.
Can anybody smell the franchise that Marvel is cooking?
An over-plotted, 2 hour crime caper offering those blessed with patience a denouement well worth the wait.
movie_title: Ne le Dis à Personne (Tell No One) (2006)

movie_review_blurb: The sort of female empowerment flick that could get a fatwa issued against Sarah Gavron, the intrepid director daring enough to make the picture
It's Mike Myers job to make you laugh, and he fails miserably in what might not be the best performance of his career, but it's certainly his worst.
Get Smart got stupid.
An eye-opening caravan undertaken by some refreshingly honest whites willing to revisit their slaveowning legacy and the devastation left in its wake.
movie_title: Traces of the Trade: A Story From the Deep North (2008)

movie_review_blurb: It's hard in good conscience to recommend a sappy flick with a heroine this shallow, her spunkiness in the face of a dire prognosis notwithstanding.
An overdue vindication of a true patriot and a timely reminder to continue challenging authority in the face of the Patriot Act.
Self -indulgent sexaholism as a pre-feminist mantra and mandate.
movie_title: Une Vieille Maîtresse (The Last Mistress) (An Old Mistress) (2007)

movie_review_blurb: A cinematic Columbine filled with wanton carnage designed to validate the bloodlust of every ostracized loser stuck in a dead-end job and daydreaming of evening the score by going postal.
A charming low-budget ensemble piece funny enough to be a surprise sleeper with enduring appeal, ala My Big Fat Greek Wedding and Little Miss Sunshine of years past.
A wholesome, family-friendly adventure so good you have to wonder why nobody seems to make movies like this anymore.
Don't expect to laugh more than five times and you won't be disappointed.
Should we really be surprised about this explosion in human trafficking in the ghetto when it has been celebrated for over a decade in every other gangsta' video?
Heartrending musical documentary examines plight of South African AIDS orphans.
movie_title: We Are Together: The Children of Agape Choir (2006)

movie_review_blurb: Not exactly a feelgood drama, but nonetheless an eye-opening peek at the ugly underbelly of a merciless metropolis that could care less about the fate of the least of its brethren.
An outsider adventure strictly for the very open-minded, presenting the numbness of paralysis, ironically, as a potential source of paroxysms of pleasure.
The Kinshasa Social Club, if you get my drift.
Pras, one of the founding members of the hip-hop group The Fugees, goes undercover to shed light on the plight of the homeless.
A cleverly-comedic, high-concept adventure, artfully-executed, and thought-provoking, too!

Fun to watch primarily because, when not waiting tables, auditioning or appearing in a movie's mob scene, these actors actually spend most of their time in superhero costumes, not on stage, but on the street.
Credit Professor Brown for compiling quite a collection of candid conversations with an impressive cross-section of Hollywood royalty.
A bounty of enchanting, bite-sized treats guaranteed to delight young and old alike for years to come.
Patriotic claptrap masquerading as a touchy-feely salute to the troops.
Pontificating aplenty in Robert Redford's preachy anti-war polemic.
Don't make the mistake of misreading this mean-spirited production as a kid-friendly Christmas flick.
Just the right mix of red herrings, scantily-clad coeds making ill-advised choices and macho dudes being cut down to size to keep you on the edge of your seat for the duration.
A relentlessly-depressing, warts-and-all biopic which depicts the untimely demise of a diva due to the toll taken on her body and soul by a combination of unfortunate disasters.

The pace of this roller coaster ride becomes too furious to remember that it all started out as an adventure addressing some pertinent ethical issues about the pitfalls of stem cell research, cloning, and bio-genetics.
Merry Capitalism!

Perhaps Brian De Palma was too blinded by his undoubtedly fervent feelings about the Bush Administration's bungling of the invasion and occupation to make an honest appraisal of his message movie's abundance of technical flaws.
Likely to resonate with Katt's loyal fans, those unshockable and very open-minded 'real [N-words]' in his desired demographic.
Adaptation of Marquez masterpiece marred by absence of magical realism.
movie_title: Love in the Time of Cholera (2007)

movie_review_blurb: A cinematic first, a standing ovation by icons for the unsung, working-class heroes who make them look good.
movie_title: Note by Note: The Making of Steinway L1037 (2007)

movie_review_blurb: A fanciful fairytale blending elements of Oliver Twist, Ferris Bueller, Peter Pan and The School of Rock likely to entertain and enthrall preteens for a couple of hours.
Quite convincing in conveying the feeling of a real family, and in generating the requisite chemistry or antipathy as called for by their dysfunctional characters' dire circumstances.
A magnificent meditation on what it might mean for many immigrants to be American in the 21st Century.
You know a cross-cultural, gender-bending dramedy has issues, when its most memorable moment is a blasphemous, bouncy Bollywood musical finale featuring a female impersonator.

Javier Bardem steals the show as perhaps the most unnerving screen villain of the year, a monster who ups the ante in terms of tension by holding a cattle gun to his victims' heads while flipping a coin to determine who lives and who dies.
Britain's most-beloved mute behaving like a buffoon while vacationing in France.
Laura Linney and Philip Seymour Hoffman never disappoint, disappearing into roles which fit like gloves.
The Sea Inside meets My Left Foot.
movie_title: The Diving Bell and the Butterfly (2007)

movie_review_blurb: At least half the celluloid should have hit the editing room floor, since this one-trick road flick revolves around Jerry's constantly contemplating suicide and belatedly bonding with his daughter while eluding the authorities.
A terminally-clever comedy that's laced with lots of inspired sardonic humor but can't quite convince you to take its slowly thickening plot seriously.

Even though homophobia may be more of a hurdle in the 'hood than Hollywood, this ensemble's supportive response to Sheldon's revealing his sexual preference proves to be a surprisingly sweet way to close out this well-meaning message movie.
Be grateful that Gabrielle Union and Morris Chestnut have the wherewithal to elevate a mediocre script.
Read the novel. Or better yet, go fly a kite!
A posthumous probing of the psyche of a musical genius who could swing and sing, but who was also prone to someself-destructive behavior, daddy-o!
movie_title: 'Tis Autumn: The Search for Jackie Paris (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Adrienne Shelly's promising career was cut short when she was murdered in her Manhattan apartment by an illegal alien. At the time of her death, she was completing this engaging dramedy which she had written, directed and co-starred in as well.
A minimalist musical which makes the most of the 'boy-meets-girl theme.
An irresistibly seductive celebration of a monster which will undoubtedly deliver the wrong message to many an impressionable young mind.

An endlessly-inventive,edge-of-your-seat crime caper blessed with an abundance of amusing twist and turns, a stirring soundtrack and unorthodox cinematography which all add up to a sumptuous cinematic classic among the very best movies ever made.
Raw, unfiltered and expletive-laced, but a brutally-honest flick guaranteed to give you an unsanitized picture of what life was like for the least fortunate folks in the wake of Hurricane Katrina.

Regardless of whether it's authentic or all staged, this reality show remains a jaw-dropping tribute to one of the most narcissistic egomaniacs you'd ever want to meet. And the same goes for her equally-delusional mom.
Time-lapse cinematography taken at seven year intervals.

Deliberately designed to look like a low-grade B-flick from the Fifties, this slasher adventure from Quentin Tarantino is a guaranteed treat for that rare film fan nostalgic about the worst era in cinema.
Postwar is hell!

Jolie, dominating nearly every scene, is rather remarkable in this star vehicle, effectively conveying a convincing combination of unwavering dedication and the dire desperation of a woman who insists on remaining at the center of the search for her man.

A damning documentary which exposes FEMA's wholesale failings while depicting a nation still deep in denial and willing to look the other way despite the ongoing suffering of a long-marginalized segment of society.
A combination flick, part psychological thriller, part pyrotechnic patriotic spectacular, which works somehow despite considerable conceptual flaws. Sweet revenge in the desert!
How do you say "sappy Horatio Alger tale" in Español?
An unwatchable mess like this is exactly what you ought to expect from anybody with the unmitigated gall to overhaul Neil Simon.
A narrow-minded flick that squanders its potential by choosing to trade in so many superficial stereotypes promoting a backwards-thinking definition of what it means to be African-American.
America's Greatest Generation gets the Ken Burns treatment in reverential WWII documentary.
Alternately silly and shocking, yet ultimately moving, this raunchy musical revue cleverly reveals the vulnerability of ubiquitous nudity as a window to the human soul.
Not only funny, engaging and entertaining from beginning to end, but a picture which delivers an abundance of heartwarming messages.

Tyler Perry again exhibits an uncanny knack for creating realistic African-American characters likely to resonate with black audiences thirsty for such sophisticated fare, even if his one-dimensional portrayal of whites and gays leave a lot to be desired.
'Can these marriages be saved?' is the recurring theme raised by this alternately enlightening and entertaining Tyler Perry tour de force.
Worthwhile for the nostalgic walk down Memory Lane alone, as you play spot the celebrity cameo as you enjoy each episode.
A super-realistic horror flick that's so relentlessly-disturbing it's likely to trigger debate as to whether the filmmaker might have left too little to the imagination.
movie_title: Jack Ketchum's The Girl Next Door (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Relatively tame retrospective about the relationship of a gay patron of the arts and his famous photographer lover best remembered for graphic, homoerotic snapshots featuring shocking sights like that of a bullwhip in a tight place.
movie_title: Black White + Gray: A Portrait of Sam Wagstaff and Robert Mapplethorpe (2007)

movie_review_blurb: After a string of groan-inducing outings from Daredevil to Gigli to Jersey Girl, it looks like Ben Affleck has stepped to the other side of the camera and finally found his true calling.
Excuse me, but wasn't this soap opera supposed to be about Halle's grieving character's loss of a husband, not about her worrying about losing her looks? It doesn't get any more shallow than this.
movie_title: Things We Lost in the Fire (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Watch out! A serial killer's on the loose with Jungle Fever.
A drismal drama rather reminiscent of Angela's Ashes, especially in terms of maintaining a relentlessly pessimistic and morose tone.
A gruesome homage to every awful zombie flick ever made and a guaranteed treat for fans of that trashy genre from a bygone era.
movie_title: Planet Terror (Grindhouse Presents: Robert Rodriguez's Planet Terror) (2007)

movie_review_blurb: The fastest way to clear a theater!
The jewel in Wes Anderson's crown!
Worthwhile for the nostalgic appeal of the vintage costumes, retro afros and classic R&B soundtrack alone.
An urgent call for the world community to do much more than merely observe this ever-worsening humanitarian crisis as it continues to unfold.
Erin Brockovich (2000) meets A Civil Action (1998), but featuring a flawed hero with blood on his hands and an ace up his sleeve.
As complex a mindbending crime caper as you could hope to wrap your head around.
It's got a great performance by Will Smith and just enough edge-of-your-seat entertainment to remain recommended, even if the cinematic house of cards collapses during the third act.
Brainless bloodsport, Cholo-style.
Bittersweet bio-pic pays tribute to two a couple of Italian prosecutors crazy enough to take on the mob.
A 'Who's Your Mama?' melodrama unfolding for the benefit of a suddenly-spousified 11 year-old.
A cinematic disaster which attempts to address a pressing social issue, but only fails miserably in the process.

Though essentially a recording of the stage production, this film is still recommended, provided you understand that the thespians are over-enunciating and exaggerating their body movements to engage folks watching in the theater, not on a screen.
movie_title: Tyler Perry's What's Done in the Dark - The Play (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Nothing can save this overambitious enterprise embarked upon by a couple of idiots, full of sound and fury but ultimately signifying nothing.
Little Orphan Annie Latino-style, with an Oliver Twist!
Have you ever watched a heroin addict trying to kick the habit? Would you like to?
Thoroughly entertaining Hollywood fare which holds up a dope as a person deserving of admiration.
This ethereal road flick has a legitimate feminist statement to make to those willing to allow women to resolve relationship issues on their own enigmatic terms.
'Live your life!' because 'This is your moment!' says Bishop Jakes. Can I get an 'Amen!'
movie_title: T.D. Jakes - Reposition Yourself: Living Life Without Limits (2007)

movie_review_blurb: True to the Will Ferrell formula, going for the joke trumps plot and character development at every turn, with the trademark humor coming via nonsensical slapstick and such Seventies-era fashion statements as cotton-candy afros and loathsome leisure suit
Even if the cross-cultural camaraderie looks a little easy to achieve, here, aren't movies sometimes supposed to point towards the path of peace and reconciliation?
The Karate Kid joins the Fight Club and kicks butt!
An African-American classic every bit as relevant today as when it was first staged.
A fitting tribute recounting rise and fall of Earth-friendly NYC nightclub.
movie_title: Wetlands Preserved: The Story of an Activist Rock Club (2005)

movie_review_blurb: Chock full of intriguing twists and turns, plus many memorable musical numbers, this instant Disney classic is a pleasant escape that's fun for young and old.
Neil Marshall should be ashamed for foisting such a disappointing follow-up to The Descent on his fans.
A disturbing headscratcher likely to leave an audience feeling more abused than entertained.
A cinematic flatliner that was dead on arrival.
A thought-provoking drama, which arrives in a timely fashion, given these dire days of skyrocketing medical costs and a governor caught consorting with high-priced call girls.
To think that this internationally-embraced dance form was started somewhere in the ghetto by a poor kid with nothing more than a radio and an unbridled passion for self-expression.
Why make a movie about bohemian swingers, if all you're going to serve up is the French equivalent of a Broadway musical?
Bio-Pic basically defends President Carter's controversial stance on Israel.
Too laced with silly slapstick to measure up to the best of Tyler Perry's previous offerings, yet still hilarious in spots and ultimately satisfying enough to be well worth watching.
Too laced with silly slapstick to measure up to the best of Tyler Perry's previous offerings, yet still hilarious in spots and ultimately satisfying enough to be well worth watching.
Since Don Imus' disgusting remarks about the young women on the Rutgers Basketball team, this flick's sort of humor falls flat, even when coming from the mouths of African-Americans.
Well enough crafted to keep you in stitches while on the edge of your seat for the duration, even if this laff-a-minute escape is more mindless than cerebral.
Though designed more for the devotee of the arts than your average moviegoer, the film is still apt to enthrall even the uninitiated who wouldn't know a Jackson Pollock from a Willem de Kooning.
Killing for peace cleverly compared to fornicating for virginity.
How long will African-American females continue to be portrayed by Hollywood in such an offensive, demeaning, bizarre and degenerate fashion?
movie_title: Bring It On: In It to Win It (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Sassy sisters scheme against jive brothers, only sans any sizzle or flava'.

Though the IRS-entangled Wesley Snipes still remains too associated with the role to be forgotten, Sticky Fingaz certainly held his own over the course of the year he was entrusted with the franchise.
A disappointingly superficial enterprise, given its undeservedly smug, countercultural airs.

Have you ever hear of Congressman Charlie Wilson who served Texas' 2nd District from 1973 to 1996? Neither had I, despite the fact that he was virtually single-handedly responsible for toppling the Soviet Union.
John Sayles is to be commended for again serving up a thought-provoking slice of African-Americana sans the shucking and jiving which Hollywood typically attaches to black-oriented fare.
Well-Intentioned and well-executed, and recommended with reservations only because there's still something terribly troubling even about a feelgood flick packed with so many misrepresentations.

Part personal odyssey, part diplomatic mission, this bio-pic reveals a sensitive side of the Illinois Senator while simultaneously establishing him as an international figure sincerely concerned about the host of woes presently plaguing Africa.
A feelgood, end-of-life flick that manages to overcome its sobering subject-matter and somehow buoy the spirit.

More suspenseful than scary, the movie is apt to disappoint anyone expecting to scream out loud in the theater. Nonetheless, it's effective at casting a creepy pall over the proceedings which permeates the picture for the duration.
Unpredictable and refreshingly inventive, this flick certainly stands on its own as perhaps South Korea's kookiest contribution to the battle-of-the-sexes genre.

Apparently, Billy Bob Thornton has embraced the idea of appealing to the lowest possible common denominator. How else can you explain his presence in another bad taste bottom-feeder which might have been better titled Bad Gym Teacher, ala Bad Santa?
The more interesting question to raise might be "What toll does it take on a society when someone as inconsequential as Lee Harvey Oswald can slay someone as historically significant as JFK?
A blasphemous parody so painful to sit through it seems designed by the Almighty as punishment for heathens and sinners.
New York Negro neurosis as source material for mirth, amusement and introspection, like a Woody Allen classic, only in blackface.
A cringe-inducing, cinematic tribute to the Golden Age of Minstrelsy!
My Big Fat Muslim Wedding!

Accolades are in order for the inspired performances delivered by the two talented young leads, Juilliard-grad Rutina Wesley and dancer-turned-actress Tre Armstrong in this refreshingly-intelligent, inner-city melodrama.
Don't be duped by the steamy-sounding premise, for this dud manages to turn the prospect of swinging into a dull and decidedly antiseptic affair.
Reminiscent of The Blair Witch Project, this cleverly-conceived scream fest was shot entirely with a shaky hand-held camera being operated by one of the film's central characters.
The Un-Juno.
Formulaic, but watchable.
Geriatric Rambo, AARP poster boy, still saves the day!
Don't expect anything of depth and you won't be disappointed by this predigested pabulum.

Is it really ethical for a film to warn of the irresistible appeal of online snuff films while it simultaneously indulges, practically pornographically, in graphic displays of the same sort of kinky perversion?
As messy a dysfunctional relationship drama as you could hope to witness on screen. How do you say 'Jerry Springer' in Mandarin?
Brother from another temple!
movie_title: Va, Vis et Deviens (Live and Become) (Go, See, and Become) (2005)

movie_review_blurb: Comedy with a social conscious. How refreshing.
movie_title: Vince Vaughn's Wild West Comedy Show: 30 Days & 30 Nights - Hollywood to the Heartland (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Adapted from George Jackson's own prison letters and other writings, this bio-pic is to be commended for shedding surprisingly sophisticated light on such a controversial cult figure.
Not even a soulful soliloquy before the closing credits about the importance of family could undo the damage already inflicted by this impressively pointless minstrel show.
An overly-ambitious, ultimately unsatisfying adaptation of Ian McEwen's best-selling romance novel.
A transparent excuse for a constant parade of topless females eager to assume a compromising position. The only thing missing was a cheesy porn soundtrack.
A pleasant, if predictable, tale of female empowerment ideal for the under ten set.

A touching tale of tolerance from Russia circa 1936 that doesn't deserve to be dismissed as propaganda but rather elevated as a refreshing and more-enlightened alternative to the racist depictions of blacks that Hollywood was cranking out at the same time

A picture which chillingly conveys a palpable sense of what being a direct victim of slavery might have felt like and why the fallout from that evil institution persists to this day like the proverbial ripples on a pond.
Spike Lee's favorite TV show comes to DVD!
Hitler of the Dead!
Might not be Jack Black's best film, but it's definitely his worst!
Can Spooky's version of Gone with the Wind be far behind, edited so that Rhett Butler and the rest of the Rebels get exactly what they deserve?
A high-octane, 2-1%u20442 hour diversion certain to stimulate, titillate and satiate the blood and other lusts of the raging-hormone set.
Simon Cowell does Kabul!
A rudderless road version of Juno!
Easily the most poignant picture of the year, achieved without resorting to manipulative soap opera devices.
A riveting drama which remains just as intense as when it debuted in 1989.
Fascinating only for the opportunity to observe the mesmerizing effect of a well-rehearsed, mass seduction on an auditorium filled with willing, adoring girls.
An alternately hilarious and plausible peek at life in L.A.'s fast lane.
Hyper-romanticized revisionist history reflecting America's ongoing love affair with gangsters.

A thought-provoking mindbender unfolding in one room and narrowly focused on a grisly, gradually-escalating standoff.

The postman may always ring twice, but a bodyguard doesn't even have to bother to knock.

Blue eyed soul at its very best!
