movie_review_blurb: An excellent alternative to the mainstream propaganda which would have us internalize the worst beliefs about an unfairly maligned segment of society. Guaranteed to generate quality conversation about the direction of African-Americana.
Potter hits puberty!
movie_title: Harry Potter and the Half-Blood Prince (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Angry white males with suicidal tendencies are people, too!
A brilliant, haunting and informative expose' not to be missed and not to be forgotten at awards season!
Ugly, and that's the truth!
A homo erotic adventure which gives 'bosom buddies' a whole new meaning!
A harrowing examination of the metaphysical harm inflicted by gun massacres.
A scary expose' illustrating exactly what happens to a country when you let the insurance lobby set a corporate agenda which puts profits ahead of healthcare. Are you listening, President Obama?
Washington and Travolta are both still at the top of their games in this high-octane, attention-deficit adventure as riveting as it is ridiculous.

A heartbreaking documentary which landed a well-deserved Oscar-nomination for its touching portrayal of Spanish-speaking salt-of-the-earth who find it hard to fathom that the legal system could possibly side with a crook out to flatten the fruit of their
A tasteful examination of the climax strictly from the female perspective, incorporating a clever combination of the clinical, the carnal and even the downright comical.
movie_title: Passion & Power: The Technology of Orgasm (2007)

movie_review_blurb: All that matters is that the loose ends of this sweet, kids-outsmart-the-adults fable are ultimately tied together nicely in a fashion certain to satisfy the average five year-old by the time the closing credits roll.
A screwball comedy/splatter flick which might best thought of as a campy cross of Cotton Comes to Harlem and No Country for Old Men.
A splendid space saga so spellbinding, I won't complain about their resurrecting that infuriating, infinitive-splitting catchphrase, 'To boldly go where no one has gone before!'
An absolutely-appealing little gem of an indie, leaving this critic curious to see whether Ms. Rhein's sophomore offering will be anywhere near as satisfying.
This heart-stopping revenge flick written by Luc Besson is easily Liam Neeson's most memorable performance since his Oscar-nominated outing in Schindler's List.

Blending the best elements of Hancock, Godzilla and This Is Spinal Tap, Big Man Japan is likely to work for you to the extent you're willing to endure special effects almost as cheap as those in the original bad B-flicks being lampooned.
Paints a chilling portrait of the U.S.S.R. simply by stringing together a motley mix of Communist propaganda from the Fifties and Sixties.
An incomparable collection of historic performances which ought to help take beleaguered Yankee fans' minds off their hurting heroes' present plight.
movie_title: Perfect Games & No-Hitters: New York Yankees (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Didn't President Obama put a ban on this sort of torture?
How do you say 'Three's a crowd' auf Deutsch?
About ten times funnier than the similarly-themed Observe & Report, though this silly, slapstick adventure is aimed more at kids than adults.
An old-fashioned romp reminiscent of the best of Doris Day and Rock Hudson!
An interminable costume drama strictly for Tom Cruise fans and for World War II buffs.
At best, an over-stimulating concatenation of bells and whistles amounting to the cinematic equivalent of bubblegum.
A transparent fish-out-of-water romantic comedy by A Danish director which won't work with an American audience.
A fitting tribute to a selfless role model with an big heart and an indomitable spirit. Let's face it, they don't make 'em like Wilma Stephenson anymore.

A pleasant change of pace to see a film set in Saigon which isn't a high body-count splatter flick about the ravages of the war in Indochina. Worthwhile if only for the reminder that the Vietnamese are people, too!
A spine-tingling adventure guaranteed to elicit blood-curdling screams and to make you jump out of your seat when you least expect it.

A tawdry tale which suggests that in the Internet Age, if you're contemplating suicide but can't quite summon up the nerve to do yourself in, you might surf S&M chat rooms to find a sadist whose fetish corresponds with your masochistic tendencies.

A picture which periodically pushes the envelope further than the average moviegoer is probably capable of stomaching via ill-advised departures into such taboo subjects as child molestation, all in search of a cheap joke.

A serendipitous erotic thriller reminiscent of Crash in the way that lots of Angelenos' lives intersect serendipitously, except that here the characters have a seedy strip club in common instead of car accidents.
heartrending documentary examines toll exacted by Vietnam War on widows of soldiers on both sides.
Thirty-something girls gone wild!
A 21st Century version of Amos 'n Andy which must have been financed by the Klan.
Sounds a clear clarion call for the consumer to rise up and start demanding natural and healthy alternatives to the processed junk which we're being fed by agri-business in the name of profits.
Worthwhile, as long as you're willing to watch Eddie Murphy play the straight man.
Coarse, adult-oriented fare guaranteed to induce more groans than guffahs.
Wastes a lot of time weaving an unnecessarily-complicated premise given that it leads to a fairly simplistic showdown of good versus evil.

50 Cent and Val Kilmer deserve kudos galore for cultivating a convincing chemistry in this well-concealed whodunit which takes you on a relentlessly-raw, rollercoaster ride certain to satiate the bloodlust of fans of the high body-count genre.
Has its moments but when bad things happen to funny people, they might not be that funny anymore.
Matt Damon seems an ill-match for his role as the mentally-unstable title character, a tragic-comic figure deserving of more complicated treatment than as an addlepated fuddy-duddy.
An ensemble drama ever so reminiscent of Amelie, the similarly-serendipitous Oscar-nominee in the Best Foreign Film category.
The Penis Monologues!
A primer on keeping the pedal to the proverbial medal when your whole world seems to have lost faith in you.
An inspirational bio-pic about the transcendent magic of friendship forged in pursuit of hoop dreams.
Juno on roller skates!
Truth Hall? 'Rude Awakening Reception' might have made a better title for this tragicomic reunion where nobody's really well-equipped to handle the truth.
Not exactly art for art's sake, more like a case of film for historic preservation's sake!
Zombies as good clean fun, I mean, good messy fun!
A persuasive, comedic argument against the existence of God or a blasphemous reinvention of Jesus as a shameless con artist? You be the judge.
Whatever happened to the analog days when kids found contentment by cramming phone booths, sitting on flagpoles or simply going steady?
Mandatory marriage counseling ruins vacation in battle-of-the-sexes sitcom.
If you don't ask Black Dynamite to be anything deeper an an entertaining retro diversion, you're apt to feel richly rewarded. Can you dig it, you jive-ass sucker?
Megan Fox needs to set her sights a little higher now that she has some clout in Hollywood.
A guerilla-style documentary which shows just how much havoc two guys with cheap suits and fake websites are capable of wreaking in corporate America.
movie_title: The Yes Men Fix the World (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Revenge as a dish best served tempura style!
An intriguing look at a hedonist in the midst of a midlife crisis, a creep whose dalliances and denial slowly catch up with him.
Love in the time of Hitler!
movie_title: Le Chant des Mariées (The Wedding Song) (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Hair-larious!
A sumptuous cinematic feast, and kosher to boot!
Michael Jackson mesmerizes in cinematic swan song.
A sloppily-edited, series of unfunny, disconnected sketches adding up to far less than the sum of its parts.
A frightening primer on how untreated racism can lead someone to abandon, even hate their own offspring.
An undeniably authentic contrast to those ghetto fabulous adventures celebrating macho, misogynistic, malevolent and misanthropic behavior presumably of no emotional consequence.
movie_title: Precious: Based on the Novel Push by Sapphire (2009)

movie_review_blurb: An inspirational tale chronicling the contributions of a few unseen players in the South African struggle for independence.

movie_title: The Men Who Stare at Goats (2009)

movie_review_blurb: One of the most emotionally-evocative documentaries ever made about Holocaust survivors.
An unorthodox triangle of forbidden love, Korean style.
Grieving mom gets second chance at love in Tyler Perry-esque, faith-based morality play.
A bodacious effort which successfully elevates a bevy of godawful B-movies to an art form worthy not only of study but appreciation to boot.
movie_title: Not Quite Hollywood: The Wild, Untold Story of Ozploitation! (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Michael Jai White makes a convincing case here that he deserves future consideration as an action star on the order of a Vin Diesel or a Sylvester Stallone.
A hilarious slice-of-life flick offering a unique take on Japanese-American culture adding up to one of the funniest films of the year thus far.
Review of Rev Run's book Take Back Your Family.
A compelling crime saga with supernatural overtones made all the more worthwhile by some spectacular Taipei locales and its celebration of Chinese culture.
A refreshingly-charming take on an enduring cultural icon and a lady now likely to go down in history as her #1 fan.
When modernity meets the Middle Ages, something's gotta give!
An introspective, bittersweet romp reminiscent of the best of Woody Allen.
A spiritually-debilitating descent into depravity.

A thoroughly-absorbing, edge-of-your-seat thriller which is right up there with the best of sci-fi because of the subtle fashion in which it delivers its thought-provoking, universal message about ethnic tolerance.
Literally and figuratively blows the sheets off the taboo subject of geriatric sexuality.
A tweener-mesmerizing mix of music-induced mass hysteria coupled with some homespun cordiality courtesy of a colorful collection of harmless hicks.
This patchwork quilt of slapdash sketches is less a fully fleshed-out cinematic concept, than a mediocre piece of performance art.

Don't be put off by all the explicit gore, for it is ultimately vindicated by the flick's disturbing, self-referential way of delivering a thought-provoking message not only about war, but about our insatiable lust for movies about war.
Moving documentary chronicles humanitarian mission of women bonded by grief.
A Sunday school parable about the difference between good versus evil. Can I get an Amen?
Features a quartet of episodes from Season 4 when the producers decided it was time to shift the setting of the show from a hotel to luxury cruise liner.
The internet indicted as a mind control tool subtly turning humanity into exhibitionistic automatons.
A damning documentary which makes a convincing case that neither the federal government nor the corporate elite could care less about the plight of the working class.
A moving tribute to a real role model who's living proof that it's possible to overcome any obstacle standing between you and your dreams.

movie_review_blurb: [A] heartwarming drama.

A cautionary tale issuing a dire warning about the prospects for humanity in a world where machines lead and people follow.
The original installment in the outrageous slacker trilogy starring Ice Cube.
Back-to-nature documentary chronicles carbon footprint of eco-conscious family.

The impassioned young voices heard rapping here reflect the concerns of a rainbow of ethnic groups: blacks, whites, Hispanics, Asians, even Hawaiians and Native Americans. And as fascinating as their diversity is the intimate nature of their material.

A thought-provoking documentary highlighting the human suffering which radiates like ripples on a pond in the wake of criminal behavior not only by racist police with itchy trigger fingers but by cop killers to boot.
A pleasant, if predictable morality play offering a litany of teachable moments certain to resonate with the Born Again demographic.

Features 5 episodes from the siblings' hit series.

Effectively employs iconic Woodstock imagery not to regenerate a numbing sense of mass nostalgia but rather as a minimalist backdrop against which to amplify the anguished, intimate ordeal of a frustrated individual who wasn't even there.
A cinematic treat likely to leave you eager to see what Professor Arboleda cooks up next.
Fame meets Flashdance in the Chocolate City!
A mesmerizing masterpiece which eloquently meshes the raw, super-realism found in Eastern Promises with the manipulative, mental chess moves of David Mamet's House of Games.
A patently preposterous 'true story' strictly for the very gullible.

A haunting tale which very convincingly conveys the overwhelming sense of helplessness and dread which undoubtedly afflicts impressionable souls unfortunate enough to be sexually exploited while still in the bloom of youth.
A definite plus is the sense of nostalgia generated by the movie's postscript affectionately acknowledging the passing of both Bernie Mac and Isaac Hayes.
An irresponsible frittering away of the cinematic capital amassed by Stiffler, McLovin and other beloved icons of the teen genre.

Using blue material Steve Harvey rates an A, although this critic would prefer that he leave out the cursing, since he already proved to me that he can be just as funny without four-letter words.

Basically offers any still-embittered, Baby Boomers a belated opportunity to bask in Nixon's humiliation.
A relatively-morose morality play likely to land its share of accolades during award season provided everyone stops comparing it to Gump.

A dizzying, delightful spectacle situated on the Subcontinent which is well worth the investment for the kaleidoscope of colors splashed across the screen alone.
Is that it? Call me crazy for expecting a more tidy resolution of this ultimately unsatisfying parable, in spite of a taut plotline and several inspired performances.
A terribly dated mix of 8-Mile, The Karate Kid and Death Wish. The desperate last gasp of pre-Obama Era intolerance.

Humorous asides in no way interfere with the ability of this modern parable to drive home a sobering message about the sanctity of marriage. Faith-based entertainment at its best that you don't have to be Born Again to appreciate.
Hoffman and Thompson team to weave movie magic via a vintage romantic roundelay.
Battle-of-the-sexes melodrama marks the brilliant directorial debut of Tim Alexander.

A worthwhile film to the extent that it can serve a permanent watchdog function as a reminder of the possible erosion of Constitutional rights and of the citizenry's need to remain vigilant about the tendency of power to corrupt, and of absolute power to
A belated tribute to some unsung heroes which turns out to be of considerably less entertainment than historical value.
Otay!
An arresting array of chilling images worthwhile for the scary visual effects alone.

movie_review_blurb: Director Brett Morgen earns high marks for finding a most innovative way to illustrate a regrettable chapter in American history.

A transparent romance/sports flick whose predictability is easily trumped by the refreshingly appealing parade of well-developed, Asian-American characters who make the movie enjoyable by turning an array of common cinematic stereotypes on their heads.
Jamie Bell in his most memorable outing since Billy Elliot, as a Peeping Tom acting upon Oedipal urges in a dysfunctional family drama from Scotland.
How do you borrow the best elements of The Transporter, The Karate Kid and Mission Impossible and end up with an unwatchable mess like this?
A salute to Timothy Greenfield-Sanders and Elvis Mitchell is in order for producing an innovative series likely to revamp the way in which television studios approach the personal portrait genre.
Another pat and predictable cautionary tale which nonetheless manages to push the right emotional buttons. That's the magic of the Tyler Perry genre.

Alternatively mirthful and macabre, while poking fun at both modern mating habits and the paranoia of espionage culture, this sophisticated social satire is a refreshingly-intelligent diversion designed with the more cerebral cineaste in mind.
An admirable examination of one family's belated attempt to come to grips with, if not atone for, its role in America's original sin.
An ill-advised variation on Black Snake Moan touting loss of innocence as a source of inspiration.
Three cheers to director Emily Apt for making such a sobering, informative and emotionally-engaging full-length feature debut.
A molasses-paced flick which rings false from beginning to end, from its patently absurd premise clear through to its unintentionally funny resolution.
This Ricky Gervais vehicle is likely to work for you to the extent that you enjoy laughing at the insufferably stuffy Brit cliche he has practically perfected.
Serpico joins the Fight Club!
A fascinating history lesson about a generally-overshadowed aspect of the Second World War.

An overdue history lesson about the indelible stain left by Jim Crow on the conflicted minds of black men forced to wage a white man's war when they'd really prefer to be fighting for their own civil rights.
Another sappy soap opera for Nicholas Sparks fans satisfied by panoramic seascapes offset intermittently by lingering interludes of dysfunctional strangers locking lips and loins.

A slice-of-life adventure featuring a principal cast of non-professionals whose gritty naivete manage to imbue the production with a palpable sense of super-realism, even if in service of a Bill Cosby-infuriating display of black on black dysfunction.
A meandering Manhattan travelogue with a payoff worth the wait, some gross moments notwithstanding.

A trio of Muslim Rodney Dangerfields complaining about not getting any respect on account of their religion.

A frequent-flyer drama examining 21st Century mating habits.

A fine addition to the recent genre of socially-conscious sports flicks highlighting individual feats for the collective meaning of those historic triumphs to the masses of black folks in search of civil rights.
Easily the funniest teensploit of 2008 so far!
A well-acted, optimistic tale of female empowerment set against the backdrop the Civil Rights Movement.
Talk about beating a man when he's down in the opinion polls!
An uplifting tale of triumph over nature and a moving tribute to the indomitability of the human spirit.
movie_title: Stranded: I Have Come from a Plane That Crashed on the Mountains (2008)

movie_review_blurb: A fascinating, warts-and-all documentary about one of the most notorious and influential figures in 20th Century politics.
movie_title: Boogie Man: The Lee Atwater Story (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Worth it alone for Nina Simone's haunting rendition of Why (The King of Love Is Dead), heard as Dr. King's mule-drawn casket led over 100,000 silent mourners from Ebenezer Baptist Church on a 3 1/2 walk through the streets of Atlanta.
movie_title: King: A Filmed Record...Montgomery to Memphis (1970)

movie_review_blurb: Expect to well up while watching emotional tableaus of grieving mothers burying their babies at funerals and simply staring blankly into the camera with tears streaming down their pained faces.
movie_title: Crips and Bloods: Made in America (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Mickey Rourke is indebted to Darren Aronofsky for casting him as a washed-up has-been in this emotionally-engaging character study, even if the role wasn't exactly much of a stretch.
So moving it made me weep three ways: openly, deeply and repeatedly!

movie_review_blurb: If Youtube-inspired flicks are a new trend, can spin-offs of Tay 'Chocolate Rain' Zonday and Chris 'Leave Britney Alone!' Crocker be far behind?
As charming an offbeat romantic comedy as anybody could hope to make on a micro-budget.
Most noteworthy for Anne Hathaway's absorbing, Oscar-nominated portrayal of a disturbed soul desperate to control the demons derailing her reality.
If you're at all intrigued by the idea of exploring angst and anomie among the entitled upper crust, then this Ivy League variation on Fight Club just might satiate that effete brand of bloodlust.

A French chick flick designed to keep soap opera fans on the edge of their seats while watching for a couple of guilt-ridden cold fish anguish over whether to share just one kiss. For the sequel, get a room!

A refreshing retro comedy with depth recommended more for the message and the romance than for the shock value of its raunchy moments.
A worthwhile bio-pic which belatedly knocks an American icon undeserving of secular sainthood off his lofty pedestal.
A disappointing exercise in achingly-familiar irritainment.
A scary reminder of the potentially-disastrous physical and emotional consequences of indiscriminate mating.
I suppose this movie could've been worse. I'm just not sure how.

A movie which earns high marks simply for being the first feature film with the guts to tackle the subject of racial profiling in such an honest fashion, especially given the similar allegations recently leveled at the neighboring town of Tenaha.
A chilling, edge-of-your-seat expose' that puts you face-to-face for two hours with the embodiment of pure evil.
An alternatively funny and revealing flick which dares to knock some seemingly sacrosanct gurus off their lofty pedestals.
Jamie Foxx does a magnificent job in his most challenging outing since Ray.
A heck of a roller coaster ride, even if the rabbit-out-of-the-hat resolution is likely to leave you feeling cheated. Sometimes, getting there is all the fun.

Just funny enough to recommend, although other than some incestuous father-daughter sexual tension, there's nothing particularly novel or memorable about this cliché-ridden variation on the time-travel comedy theme.
Slumming, South American-style!
A riveting expose' of what looks an awful lot like child abuse in the name of quality education. What's next, an SAT test for newborns?

A surrealistic charmer blessed with some breathtaking cinematography.
A compelling reminder that Hell still hath no fury like a woman scorned, especially when she's a crazy, two-faced psycho.

Hurray to these lovely ladies for summoning up the courage to serve up an evening's worth of genuinely erotic, yet somehow simultaneously wholesome, adult entertainment. But enough is enough. I just pray none of them are tempted to quit their day jobs."
For better or worse, probably the latter, I somehow suspect this isn't the last we'll hear from Marcello Thedford this year.
The genre has certainly come a long way from I Was a Teenage Werewolf.
A sleeper that can't miss with the indie art house crowd.
Let's just pray this incendiary flick doesn't reignite civil unrest in the region.
A candid commentary on the state of the battle-of-the-sexes designed for this post-racial age of strangers with benefits.
The Filipino answer to Slumdog Millionaire!
Springtime for Hitler, the sequel!
A harrowing mindbender which successfully blends elements of X-Men, The Matrix and Memento while adding some of its own unique sci-fi flava.

movie_review_blurb: A road to ruin paved more by mindless conformity than by good intentions.

Will certainly resonate with its targeted preteen demographic, as its principal cast has returned for a sequel appropriately enhanced for the big screen.
Clive Owen and Naomi Watts wasted in overly-ambitious, over-plotted potboiler.
A gritty, super-realistic, female empowerment flick most memorable for Melissa Leo's spellbinding, Oscar-nominated performance.

Forget Revolutionary Road, if you want to see a period piece about a Connecticut couple in crisis, check out this skeletons-in-the-closet documentary deconstructing a dysfunctional marriage of Allis and Charlie.
Tyler Perry's best endeavor to date!

Endlessly thought-provoking at every turn, this iconoclastic documentary offers the opportunity for a transcendental experience amounting to this critic's most satisfying cinematic experience of 2009 thus far.
A flick for Kennedy assassination conspiracy buffs which puts a whole new spin on "the grassy knoll" courtesy of the flamboyance of a nearly-naked Gretchen Mol.

The good news is that I only need 9 more movies for my 10 Worst List.

It's 'Fanning'tastic!
A must see for any avid jazz fan!

movie_review_blurb: If "Keepin' the Faith" includes keeping the Ten Commandments, especially the one about "Thou shalt not steal," then director Marcello Thedford is going to have to answer to a higher authority for this blatant, blasphemous rip-off. Repent!
movie_title: Keepin' The Faith: My Baby's Gettin' Married! (2008)

movie_review_blurb: England's addlepated answer to Amelie!
Why do the all the Nazis here have British accents? How confusing is that? An unintentionally-comical cross of Hogan's Heroes and Springtime for Hitler!
movie_title: The Boy in the Striped Pajamas (The Boy in the Striped Pyjamas) (2008)

movie_review_blurb: A relentlessly insulting and offensive flick which endeavors to redeem itself via 11th-hour moralizing ony after every frame up to the end had been a wholesale celebration of the debasement of females and the stereotyping of blacks.
Highly recommended, primarily because of the infectious camaraderie of co-stars Paul Rudd and Jason Segel, as well as for the casually-captivating screen chemistry of Rashida Jones.
A performance-driven bio-pic which features plenty of concert footage, offset by interviews with friends, family (including her brother, renowned composer Caetano Veloso) and Maria herself.
movie_title: Maria Bethania: Music is Perfume (Maria Bethania: Musica e Perfume) (2008)

movie_review_blurb: The basic question you need to ask yourself in approaching this comedy conceert comes down to whether you want to set yourself up to listen to mean-spirited and crude jokes you might be embarrassed to admit made you laugh in polite company.
Benefiting from well-concealed reveals, shocking developments, truly unnerving antagonists, taut editing and a hair-raising score, this neverending nightmare is easily the best horror flick of 2006.

Exploring an array of themes ranging from love and betrayal to morality and mortality, Eastern Promises is a mesmerizing thriller designed for folks with a penchant for lingering depictions of utter depravity. Sheer brutality as cinematic beauty.

A much-needed wake-up call to face the fact that state-sanctioned usury and exorbitant late fees are destroying the prospects of working class citizens of ever achieving anything approaching the American Dream.
A bittersweet bio-pic which presents an articulate, defiant and sensitive soul who promises to remain committed to resistance till he draws his last breath.
I think I hated this movie!
movie_title: I Think I Love My Wife (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Winner of the Best Film at the 2006 Cannes Film Festival, this powerful political saga is not merely a cinematic masterpiece from start to finish but a righteous rallying cry for disenfranchised masses anywhere with nothing left to lose but their chains.
movie_title: The Wind That Shakes the Barley (2007)

movie_review_blurb: A refreshingly realistic, homoerotic adventure featuring recognizable gay characters actually acting gay, not behaving in some sanitized fashion intended to appeal to straight audiences. The gay version of Jungle Fever!
Well-intentioned, at best, regrettably, this fairly formulaic, Philly sports flick doesn't show enough brotherly love for anyone to be proud of it.

A meanspirited mood piece which begs to be appreciated as a meditation on the psyche of post-9/11 America but resorts far too frequently to stock Sandler humor to be of any more consequence than The Waterboy, Happy Gilmore or even Billy Madison.

Though sloppily edited like a bad B-movie, this poor man's version of Trading Places will undoubtedly resonate for anyone with a taste for gruesome gallows humor, and a desire to see a spoiled, rich kid get a taste of how the other half lives.
An informative expose' for those naïve enough not to know that the criminal justice system has always been stacked in favor of the rich, the white, and the well-connected.
The 'hood as a vast, urban quicksand where the dreams and potential of a generation of African-Americans are being swallowed up wholesale.
One of those delectable, upstairs-downstairs affairs worth savoring, and a suspenseful psychological thriller which rates right up there with the best of the genre.
movie_title: The Page Turner (La Tourneuse de pages) (2006)

movie_review_blurb: Set in locales ostensibly picked without concern for cinematic pretense, this crowd-pleaser conveys a sense of everyday life in South Africa while simultaneously serving up an endearing variation of a magical opera for the ages. Bravo!
A socially-relevant and meaningful film from South Africa which supplies plenty of reasons to feel optimistic about humanity's prospects.
Documentary offers a bird's eye view of man's inhumanity to man at the Battle of Leningrad, the epitome of a Pyrrhic victory.
Very moving, well-written, and better-acted, but bitterly realistic.
U.S. imperialism exposed as a categorical imperative by this damning documentary about the Military Industrial Complex.

Though technically the sixth in the series, this sure seems an awful lot like a remake of the first film in the storied franchise, as it somehow manages to tug at the heartstrings in a way likely to leave you wiping away tears afresh.
Fetishists are people, too!
A paradoxical, if ultimately plausible portrait of a fractured family which deals with baby-daddy drama in a way which puts similar, relatively-flip Hollywood fare to shame.
Not nearly as much of a mind-bender as Memento, yet The Lookout is, nonetheless, a praiseworthy homage to that inscrutable brain teaser.
Proves that you don't need much money to make an absolutely fascinating reality movie, provided you are willing to exploit weirdos waiting for their moment in the limelight.
Puppy love at its most bearable!
movie_title: Win a Date With Tad Hamilton! (2004)

movie_review_blurb: Guaranteed to induce nightmares!
This intriguing, character-driven drama, directed by three-time, Oscar-nominee Lasse Hallstrom, is worthwhile for its capably-executed, beguiling plot alone.
Absorbing from start to finish, this might be the first flick to interpret a Holocaust tale of survival as a highly-stylized, erotic, espionage thriller.
An eye-opening satire which makes a powerful statement about television's tendency towards very calculated, mass manipulation.
An irreverent, frequently funny clash of cultures which mostly explores the lighter side of what it means to be Jewish.

The F. Scott Fitzgerald's classic, The Great Gatsby, adapted as a modern-day morality play in blackface. This fairly-faithful version explores the same themes as its source material, only with a hip-hop spin.

No chemistry, no cool, no compelling characters, no air of urgency. Just a very average crime caper which fails to entertain the viewer on a gut, cerebral or superficial level. Not exactly your father's Miami Vice.

This cross of reality-TV with slasher thriller is a clever and compelling enough adventure to keep you guessing and on the edge of your seat right up to the shocking conclusion. And finally, a horror flick where the black guy doesn't die first!
A moving and meaningful melodrama about a blood bond tested by the trials and tribulations of trying to survive in the inner-city.
A relentlessly-grim reminder of how the world simply watched when it would have been so easy to put an end to the madness.
A fair warning that the world is watching to see whether Karl Rove and company put their thumbs on the scales again.
Bio-pic chronicles quadriplegic Ramon's Sampredo's 28-year crusade to legalize euthanasia in order that he be allowed to die with dignity.
movie_title: The Sea Inside (Mar Adentro) (The Sea Within) (2004)

movie_review_blurb: What ruins this revenge flick is Madea's boorish, bull in the china store act reminiscent of the sassy black woman stereotype popularized by Sanford and Son's Aunt Esther. Loud and ignorant, Medea tends to trivialize every scene.
movie_title: Diary of a Mad Black Woman (2005)

movie_review_blurb: A beguiling romance about an aging actress at the peak of her career who embarks on an ill-advised, illicit affair with an admirer half her age.

The casting of Hugh Grant opposite Drew Barrymore was a stroke of genius both in terms of chemistry and comedy, as his self-deprecating vulnerability serves as the perfect foil for her zaniness, and their repartee is reminiscent of Hepburn and Tracy.
A Tyler Perry tour de force!
An intensely engrossing melodrama, despite its ultimately squandering an opportunity to deliver an emotional payoff.
No logic, no laughs, a classic 'take-the-money-and-run' sequel which had me praying for a projector malfunction or some other excuse to leave the theater early.
Again, Nunez proves himself a master of understatement, presenting another poignant, slice-of-life drama peopled with vulnerable, fully fleshed-out characters caught-up in a complex situation.

A tip of the cap to Tip Harris and Lauren London for it is their chemistry and charm which allows one to believe in their tenderhearted romance in an atmosphere where women are regarded as objects and affectionately called 'bitches' and 'hos.'
This macabre fairy tale, a bizarre blend of surrealism and eccentricities, might be best described as a kinky cross of Psycho and Alice in Wonderland.
Jeffrey Togman earns high marks here for his directorial debut, a socially-significant documentary which discusses an array of taboos concerning color, class and the ever-elusive American Dream.
An utterly inane whodunit more in search of a cheap joke than the perpetrators of any crime.
Damning documentary indicts the ex-mayor as deserving to be remembered not for the clean-up of the Twin Towers, but for his utter lack of compassion for the impoverished and working classes.
This sophomoric psychological thriller might not be the best movie Jim Carrey ever made, but it certainly is his worst.

While the flick has a few funny moments likely to make the general public laugh, at heart it's a Tenacious D tribute layered with asides and inside jokes scripted with the group's diehard fans in mind.
movie_title: Tenacious D in The Pick of Destiny (2006)

movie_review_blurb: A mesmerizing mood piece which steeps the viewer in the humbling stillness of monastic life, thereby inducing reflection upon one's own relation to God versus the trappings of technology and the rampant materialism of modern society.

A daring documentary which exposes sex tourism in Jamaica as not merely the harmless indulgence of horny white women gone wild, but as a burgeoning trend which is wreaking havoc on Caribbean culture and family structure.
Brace yourself for several extended, sexually-explicit scenes which would qualify as soft porn. Rebels in heat looking for release, not for love or a relationship.
movie_title: Woman is the Future of Man (2004)

movie_review_blurb: Proof-positive that screen chemistry can trump trash, and that it's hard out here for a nympho, too.
Here, getting there is all the fun, and this flick is stocked with laughs galore, all at the expense of the most clueless loser since Napoleon Dynamite.

A Will Smith vehicle from beginning to end, capturing the two-time Oscar-nominee, here, at a stage in his career where his combination of charisma and comic timing hint at the enviable big screen career about to take off.

Perhaps predictable, sentimental and sappy, but who cares, when it also oh so effectively delivers the salient message that much is expected of those fortunate enough to have been born blessed with so much.
A high-stakes romantic comedy which pits a bourgie brother against another from the 'hood who knows how to keep it real.
Masturbation as method acting!
A convincing portrayal of a helpless soul wavering between fear and faith, and the madness of murder being perpetrated in the name of Christ.
A monochromatic, testosterone-sodden cross of Gladiator and Sin City strictly for the bloodlust demographic.

Relatively-sophisticated for a sci-fi horror flick, this psychological thriller scares the bejesus out of you while subtly using malpractice as metaphor for a generally unacknowledged aspect of American culture.

Fortunately, this fable revolves around a role model worth emulating with an intact moral compass and an indomitable spirit of adventure. What a breath of fresh air after that Space Shuttle Commander arrested for attempted murder in an adult diaper.

Gabrielle Union has never before exhibited as much of an emotional range as seen in this role as an ice princess whose cold heart melts when offered an opportunity with a real man who comes with a ready-made family.
Yeah, we're done.

What makes this multi-layered masterpiece memorable is Jackie's convincing transformation from damaged goods into a wanton temptress conflicted about whether or not to use her body to gain the confidence of this recently-paroled ex-con. Revenge as the swe
Eschews any concern with the cinematic foreground in favor of wide-angled pans across an expanded back cast encouraged to indulge in Altman's trademark overlapping dialogue.
An entertaining but inauthentic adaptation, a production which reads more like a Hollywood teensploit than a historical epic from Holland.

Schoolyard jokes about religious faiths, genetic traits, and sexuality which only work if you enjoy laughing at people because they are darker-skinned, or curlier-haired, or perverted, or have emigrated from another continent.
It's hard to expect anyone to infuse much passion into a "by-the-numbers" boxing movie which telegraphs every punch.
Cartoonish but clever, with the bulk of the fun coming when Wilson's wry wit meets Stiller's impatient officiousness head-on. Sophomoric, yet probably the best of the recent TV retreads.

The event around which the movie revolves is a desert mirage, since there is no record of any such race ever being staged. Nonetheless, those able to ignore this outrageous historical distortion might enjoy this triumph of an underdog aganst the odds.
A production which would rather scare its audience with gore than reel it in via a gripping whodunit.
A new, and arguably improved, Walking Tall, starring pro wrestler-turned-actor, The Rock.
Dude, where's my clam?
A transparent Big Chill rip-off where all the soap opera's characters share the same toxic personality. Jumpin' Jehosaphat!
movie_title: Sing Now or Forever Hold Your Peace (2006)

movie_review_blurb: This uncritical bio-pic presents Al as more of an intellectual on a mission than a funnyman in search of laughs, leaving one to wonder whether the purpose here was to makeover Al into a political figure for his rumored run for the U.S. Senate.
Mostly likely to appeal to an audience that would enjoy seeing a typical teensploit where the script flips the sexual preferences.
Trust me, a sloppily-edited, unmanageable insult to the intelligence with far too many shortcomings to deserve any further analysis.

A fractured feature which establishes itself as a taut psychological thriller only to undercut an intriguing premise with comical 11th hour courtroom antics comparable to the vaudeville act of Pigmeat Markham. 'Here come de judge!'
More of a message movie designed for mainland China than a karate chopsocky for consumption in the West where a martial arts movie has to be about butt-kicking to generate any traction.
movie_title: Jet Li's Fearless (Huo Yuan Jia) (Legend of a Fighter) (2006)

movie_review_blurb: Mixing mirth with more sophisticated moments, this delightful romantic romp ultimately triumphs primarily because of the easy-going screen chemistry generated by Sanaa Lathan and Simon Baker.
With skeletons flying out of the closet at every turn, this overplotted mess unfolds more like a dumb, daytime soap opera than a well-crafted crime thriller.

Despite the transparent plotline, the dumb dialogue, the cheesy special f/x, the cornball comic relief and the self-righteous sermonizing, this campy B-movie adds up to a cinematic experience so godawful, it's great, in a reverse chic sort of way.

A charming slapstick comedy which explores a variety of themes including love, loyalty, friendship and one's relationship with oneself before delivering at a heartwarming message that maybe there's no place like home after all.
Jamie Kennedy ought to let a bomb-sniffing dog check out scripts for him.
Peyton Place with a perv!
Despite cartoonish characters, over-the-top hijinks, and occasional lapses of bad taste, any movie that leaves you laughing up the aisle, has to remain well-recommended.

After about an hour, the novelty wears off, and you're aching to see an actual animal and real shrubs. After two hours, you feel disappointed when you realize that this wouldn't even make a good play. After three hours, it's downright infuriating.
What makes this movie riveting is not its subject, but the huge hole evident in the biographer's soul, a space he desperately tries to fill by speaking with those once close to his father.

An implausible plotline, seasick cinematography, and absence of humorous moments add up to an irritating, insulting experience which explains why Dreamworks decided to delay the film's release for a year. It should have been left on the shelf.
Undoubtedly deserves to be added to the ranks of the best Holocaust films ever made.
All the cast members, even Mr. Pitt, adopt the obligatory British accent, sans contractions, employed by the historical drama genre, even though the action takes place in Ancient Greece.
Satisfying only because of Joan Cusack's sterling performance. Will somebody please give that actress a starring role in her own vehicle?

It's just too bad that Rose is the only participant in this experiment who doesn't look like she stepped off the set of White Chicks. Yet, somehow, the questionable makeup doesn't diminish the entertainment value of this absorbing social experiment.

A couple of hilarious, high attrition-rate horror parodies augmented by faux ads for four equally-outrageous releases, all adding up to a guaranteed treat for fans of those forgettable B-flicks of the Fifties.
Charlize Theron's Oscar-winning toure de force!
A love story likely to leave you cold.
A waste of time!
Back to the Future? Back to the drawing board!
Any production featuring Jack Black in spandex and showing off his belly full of stretch marks should never have made it off the drawing board in the first place.
Just remember that the hot rods burning rubber are the real stars of this spectacular, high-octane tribute to testosterone.
movie_title: The Fast and the Furious: Tokyo Drift (2006)

movie_review_blurb: This surprisingly-engaging, semi-autobiographical docudrama must have served as sojourn of self-discovery for the moviemaker, though it now offers his audience a refreshingly realistic peek into the plight of a displaced people.
Alternately bizarre and inspired, but an appropriate tribute to an uncompromisingly experimental innovator in the field of cinema.
movie_title: Jack Smith and the Destruction of Atlantis (2006)

movie_review_blurb: Hip-hop's irreverent answer to Woodstock!
Spider-Man wrestling with demons, literally and figuratively!
A perfect stinker!
Politically-paranoid, if well-intentioned, this disjointed message movie doesn't really do much more than indict the usual suspects.
An infuriatingly-offensive, soft-porn primer on how to treat girls as objects who exist at the disposal of men.
Hillbilly Heaven, if you even want to go there.
A hilarious, heartwarming remake.
A sappy, self-congratulatory tale of triumph of penniless newcomers over every sort of adversity, and a close brush with death every time they set foot outside of their apartment.

Is this sleaze dressed up as art, or vice-versa? As more and more daring directors opt to push the envelope with similar conversation-provoking pictures, we'll have to let the debate about what could be an emerging cinematic trend continue.
movie_title: The Glamorous Life of Sachiko Hanai (2003)

movie_review_blurb: A tenderhearted slice of magical realism!
This latest French farce from Oscar-nominee Francis Veber (La Cage aux Folles) is another sophisticated screwball comedy right up there with the best of Billy Wilder.
Zooey Deschanel steals so many scenes as Paula's anti-social roommate that she deserves to share top billing alongside McConaughey and Parker.
Code Name: The Minstrel Coon Show!
A cerebral, female empowerment flick which takes its cues from empathy and understanding as opposed to two-fisted testosterone.
Dispassionate dispatching of humans as cinematic road kill. Bloody funny bloodletting, if that's your thing.

Without ever sounding a false note, this endearing ensemble holiday flick manages to be nuttier than Notting Hill, more satisfying than Bridget Jones' Diary, and even more intricate than Four Weddings and a Funeral.
Too closely cropped to allow for the expansive feel of an oceanic epic, and fails to develop any meaningful relationships among its characters.
movie_title: Master and Commander: The Far Side of the World (2003)

movie_review_blurb: Unless you are prone to laugh at endless urination, expectoration, regurgitation, defecation, flatulence, and belching, avoid this rip-off at all costs.
movie_title: Dr. Seuss' The Cat in the Hat (2003)

movie_review_blurb: A mind-numbing misadventure more funereal than funny or frightening. Yawn.
Vintage Nicholson and Keaton, like fine wines, improve with age.
When not overindulging in birth defect humor, this shock comedy divides its attention between two equally-annoying sub-themes: degrading females and prominent product placements.
An absolutely absorbing finale which establishes the trilogy as perhaps the best mythic fable ever brought to the big screen.
movie_title: The Lord of the Rings: The Return of the King (2003)

movie_review_blurb: A delightful, charming, instant holiday classic which makes us laugh repeatedly while delivering an emotionally satisfying message about unconditional love.

Reminiscent of such desert island classics as Swept Away and Lord of the Flies, this film is at heart, a microscopic suspense drama quite independent of the war which brought its unfortunate characters together.
This slice-of-life adventure is very effective at portraying the plight of young females who suddenly find themselves on the frontlines of the war on terrorism.

This compelling bio-pic is an overdue tribute to William Wilberforce (1759-1833), the British abolitionist who, for 20 years, tirelessly lobbied Parliament to end England's participation in the slave trade.

So long as you think it's okay to depict a realistic-looking assassination of a sitting president via doctored news footage, then you're likely to enjoy this intriguing whodunit in which George Bush is blown away by one of his fed-up detractors.
A 21st Century version of the state-sanctioned, pro-war propaganda designed to instill a sense of patriotism in the Baby Boom Generation back when they were still impressionable babies.
Though not for the squeamish or fans of Fascism, this morbidly bewitching fantasy is an enchanting, escapist fairy tale, even if one designed strictly with adults in mind.

This articulate and particularly poignant mood piece demands nothing of its audience, except for some brutally honest introspection about our unquestioned presumptions about the human condition. Easily, the best film of 2005.
Cinema verite at its very best!
Among the best micro-budget offerings of the year!
A slap-happy misadventure featuring Marlon Wayans as a foul-mouthed midget masquerading as a baby in order to retrieve a pilfered diamond from a childless couple.
The self-explanatory title of this campy disaster flick represents a rare case of cinematic truth-in-advertising, because it's all about snakes on a plane.
In essence, this damning documentary is a history lesson uncovering the ugly underbelly of Western Civilization from 1492 up to the present.
Assaults the senses tirelessly with wave after wave of momentum-building intensity, with Jason Statham enjoying his best role since The Transporter.
A practically-perfect family flick which delivers a big lesson about the true meaning of brotherly love.
More shocking than hilarious, this spoof of the teensploit genre offers just enough funny moments to earn this critic's seal of approval.
After Born into Brothels won an Academy Award for Best Documentary, it was only a matter of time before the imitators started coming along.
A sympathetic send-up of a well-meaning matriarch charged with managing her very dysfunctional family while her every move was monitored under the mass media's microscope.
Hilary Swank delivers as impressive a performance as her Oscar-winning outings in Boys Don't Cry and Million Dollar Baby.
I've heard of remakes before, but this is the first remake of a documentary I can recall.
Represents an adventurous attempt to lampoon cowboy movies while simultaneously paying tribute to them.
movie_title: Fah talai jone (Tears of the Black Tiger) (2007)

movie_review_blurb: The contrast between the familiar image of Harvey as the brash, above-it-all funnyman we've come to love over the years and the suddenly vulnerable soul we now see up on the on screen is unusually endearing and, ultimately, winning.
movie_title: Don't Trip...He Ain't Through with Me Yet (2006)

movie_review_blurb: Worthwhile for the amusement of the escape to a bygone era alone. But when you factor in an absorbing pulp fiction plotline, you've got all you can ask of a cinematic experience.
A refreshingly-honest empowerment flick set against an historical examination of African-American homosexuality.
50 Cent dies for our sins in disappointing screen debut.
Might best be thought of as a female version Hoop Dreams.

Easily overshadowed by the musical performers, particularly The Fugees, reunited to deliver a most-moving rendition of Killing Me Softly, it is easy to understand why Dave withdrew into his shell, after watching his lame stand-up act here.
This lackluster production fails to generate much in the way of tension and less in the way of merriment.

Has nothing of value to offer other than a dizzying number of cameos by former child stars, each of whom is only momentarily amusing as a voyeuristic opportunity to compare the grown-up on screen to the kid ever emblazoned upon our mind's eye.
Sit back, and simply enjoy all the spectacular stunt work, chase scenes, f/x, pyrotechnics, gunplay, and comic relief with your brain on idle and a big tub of popcorn in your lap.
Endlessly entertaining, though not recommended for anyone uncomfortable with soft porn, eroticized violence or graphically-depicted slaughter.
A cautionary, sci-fi comedy which envisions a miserable dystopia half a millenia in the future where humanity has degenerated instead of advanced.
Hollywood certainly didn't waste anytime in turning out its first insulting blaxploitation flick of 2007.

This overhaul of the original eliminates Uncle Remus as well as the other ethnically offensive aspects to yield a politically-correct adventure about a mischievous hare which can be safely shared with the children, and enjoyed by kids of every age.
Apartheid revisited, less as a repugnant racist ideology than as an ethically ambivalent philosophy.
Examines what life was like at an idealized, hippie oasis back in the Sixties. Not exactly groovy, or anybody's idea of nirvana, dude.
Forget about MI-3 or X-Men 3 or any other film franchises. If you only see one film this summer, you need to get out more, but District B13 is the flick you better not miss.
Jennifer Hudson's coming out party!
A deceptively delightful meditation on the meaning of life.

Recommended for the work of Forest Whitaker alone, even if the gifted actor was restricted by a screenplay which squandered a golden opportunity to imbue his character with a complex range of motivations and emotions.
One of those uplifting, overcoming-the-odds, miracle movies which seem to be released every year around Christmastime.
The Crucifixion revisited with black Jesus as victim of bias crime.
Bittersweet football flick less concerned with gridiron feats than with how members of a tight-knit community deal with their grief in the wake of a disaster.
About the best that can be said for Mel Gibson's overblown indulgence in sadism is that at least it isn't anti-Semitic.
High-impact African action flick a flawed gem!
RFK assassination revisited as 'Crash' style roundelay.

From haphazard editing to clueless cinematography to godawful acting to gaping plot holes to zero laughs to low production values, this sorry sequel has all the earmarks of your classic 'take the money and run' ripoff.
movie_title: Van Wilder: The Rise of Taj (Van Wilder 2) (2006)

movie_review_blurb: A truly touching tale which patiently paints a simple tableau while ever so subtly highlighting an endangered lifestyle deserving of protection from the onslaught of Western civilization.
movie_title: The Cave of the Yellow Dog (Die Hohle des gelben Hundes) (2005)

movie_review_blurb: A gritty, automobile-intensive, buddy flick rather reminiscent of director David Ayer's similarly amoral Training Day.
A touching rite-of-passage flick which simultaneously sends several valuable messages about friendship, fidelity, tolerance, and reaching for the stars.
An inside peek at the lethal logistics of the high-tech food industry, guaranteed to haunt you for meals to come.

What makes the movie satisfying is the fact that its ethnic tensions are never overtly exacerbated, but rather subtly illustrated simply by the comparison of the decadent malaise of the spoiled-rotten versus the neverending nightmare of the have-nots.
Highly recommended as a sobering companion piece to Hollywood's relatively-sanitized version of the same subject-matter in Blood Diamond.

This slight variation on the time travel theme will engage you to the extent that you are able to forgive a script which repeatedly relies on cartoon physics to explain away every improbable plot development
One of those heartwarming, 'It's fun to pretend!' fables that's fun for the whole family.
A praiseworthy production which all but renders the carefully-cultivated James Bond franchise unrecognizable, adding up to an exercise in frustration for purists expecting a familiar 007 spectacular.
Think of this warts-and-all misadventure as the cinematic equivalent of a 'Just Say No' public service announcement.
More amusing than compelling, like a campy episode of Lost in Space where anything goes and nothing makes sense. Oh dear! Oh dear!
A cautionary tale which amply illustrates how far the culture has come in terms of portraying the Mary Kay Letourneaus of the world empathetically.
An intricately-plotted political potboiler which makes the idea of working for the CIA seem anything but romantic.

The premise powerfully postulated here is that not only Ethiopians, but millions and millions of other Africans are suffering due to the paltry prices paid by big business for natural resources which most people from developed countries take for granted.
Feelbad experiences abound in modern morality play.
Horrifying, vulgar and exploitative, yet simultaneously inspired, brilliant, convulsively hilarious, and easily the funniest film of the year.
movie_title: Borat: Cultural Learnings of America for Make Benefit Glorious Nation of Kazakhstan (2006)

movie_review_blurb: A heartbreaking assessment of Iraq's reconstruction from the point-of-view of its intended beneficiaries.
A psychological thriller about a wannabe gangster who ends up with overwhelming regret after becoming enveloped in a whirlwind of terror.

The film's near fatal flaw rests with the recasting of Hannibal as an admirable Nazi hunter capable of compassion, a person who bears little relation to the psychopathic misanthrope who so easily sent shivers running up and down an audience's spine.
A daring drama that addresses how a wanton woman copes with a strict social structure that would deny her any outlet for her animalistic urges.
Why do Americans seem so inclined to slaughter one another? Once again, Michael Moore has once again waded into some rather murky waters to weigh in on a very thorny subject.
This lackluster cure for insomnia might have been more palatable without so many distracting digressions and pared down to a manageable ninety minutes or so. Zzzz... Zzzz... Zzzz...

Just the latest in an invaluable string of eye-opening documentaries designed to make Westerners face the fact that their relatively high standard of living comes at the expense of impoverished, indigenous peoples of the Third World.
Unless you check your political correctness at the box office, expect to be offended.
Can a picture really be considered a parody if it merely parrots rather than satirizes its source material?
A moving morality play indicting America for its ongoing love affair with the Second Amendment.
Don't expect anything life-transforming, but simply a gender-bending, screwball sitcom for the more cerebral demographic.
An unflinching look at the rise and fall of one of the most influential figures of our times.

Narrated by Harvard Professor Henry Louis Gates, Jr., this four-part PBS series follows the extraordinary efforts of nine famous blacks to find their roots, including Whoopi Goldberg who learns that she's not really Jewish.
A computer-generated animated adventure featuring few product placements, which is quite a departure from the norm for such children's fare.
A semi-autobiographical docudrama which is the first film to convey the nature of dating since the advent of MySpace.com.

This fascinating flick, using physical desire as a metaphor, examines political problems plaguing Haiti in the Seventies while simultaneously exploring pleasure purely from an older woman's point-of-view.
Easily engages the viewer in the same fashion as the best of the romance genre.
Documentary shines a scientific spotlight on the criminal justice system's dirty little secret via ten tragic cases of mistaken identity, each an unfortunate rush to judgment.
Homo-erotic themes aside, this is otherwise a stock scary movie which rates out as an above-average example of the genre.
Less a mainstream flick than faith-based entertainment aimed directly at believers and potential converts.

An enchanting, if bittersweet, memoir which seamlessly interweaves wistful, tenderhearted reflections with archival film footage and the readily-observable harsh realities associated with advanced age to yield a splendid slice of African-American history.
A bittersweet tale of human failings and redemption which ought to establish Gyllenhaal as one of the best actresses around.
A cleverly conceived, kid-friendly horror flick with a lot going for it, mixing clever asides in a thrill-a-minute roller coaster ride on the way to a finale with a satisfying send-off.

This overplotted, emotional dump plods along as if the characters are stuck in the cinematic equivalent of quicksand, never generating any traction because no matter how much everybody vents, nothing of consequence ever transpires.

In spite of several inspired moments where it exhibits some genuine promise, this desperate attempt to be all things to all people ends up sabotaging any potential to make a memorable contribution to the annals of cinema.
A gritty, high attrition-rate mindbender guaranteed to keep you on the edge of your seat from start to its shocking finale.
Everything you always wanted to know about sex, and then some. A bawdy, early Woody Allen-esque slapstick comedy!
The most engaging presentation from the perspective of an exploited, female underclass since the equally-evocative Maria, Full of Grace.
Whether or not you knew a Grace Lee before, you'll never be able to think of Asian females as a type again after getting to know the ensemble comprising this enlightening and enriching bio-pic.
An over-plotted, pressure-cooked crime caper directed by Martin Scorcese which touches on every classic theme imaginable.

What on the surface initially seems like your typical bitchy blonde-versus-ostracized newcomer teensploit is merely this taut psychological thriller's point of departure for the exploration of a more sobering set of circumstances.
Eddie portrays three of the leads including a sassy, oversexed, super-sized sister in an unmitigated disaster which makes characters with darker skin the butt of virtually every joke.

Since nothing much exciting ever happens in this contemplative mood piece, don't be surprised to be asking yourself, 'Is that it?' by the time the closing credits roll on this deliberately-paced headscratcher.
Fairly annoying from start to finish, primarily because Keaton is still relying on that ever less-endearing assortment of addlepated antics which won her an Academy Award for Annie Hall back in 1978.

An entertaining and informative concert film served up by a quartet of uncomplicated troubadours armed only with their voices and primitive acoustic instruments, augmented by just the right mix of sand dunes, desertscapes and childlike silliness.

A most impressive feature film debut by writer/director Michael Kang who has crafted a compelling tale by examining rites of passage from a fresh perspective, namely, that of a Chinese-American adolescent.
A ghetto fabulous flick certain to generate some healthy debate as to whether it is glorifying or condemning the thug life which is so celebrated by the Hip-Hop Generation.
Picture a cross between Guess Who's Coming to Dinner and Meet the Parents, except with a lot more attitude and edge.
Hood hooks-up with dancing debutante for across the tracks romance.
A United Negro College Fund PSA for anyone interested in obtaining a Ph.D. in bling and booty calls. A mind is a terrible thing to lose.
This damning documentary serves as a sobering, if painful reminder of one of the most shameful chapters in human history.
movie_title: Verdict on Auschwitz: The Frankfurt Trial 1963-1965 (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Brilliantly written and even better directed by Karen Moncreiff, The Dead Girl represents a rather remarkable innovation in the female empowerment genre.
It's unfortunate that what was undoubtedly an inspirational story could end up onscreen as such a been-there done-that hack job.
A relentlessly-disturbing, cautionary tale about how easy it might be for a deranged maniac to worm his way into your good graces.
It's okay, if you like investing two hours in a whodunit only to discover that a butler who was barely in the picture did it.
Forget the Ides of March, beware the 5th of November.
The most high-octane action-- pyrotechnics, fisticuffs, gunplay, car crashes, back alley dashes and fire escape leaps-- ever crammed into a pressure-cooked chase lasting less than a mile.
A fish-out-of-water comedy with Eddie Griffin as a con artist who finds love and a new ease on life in Ireland.
An understated exercise in edge and intensity worthy of favorable comparison to Alfred Hitchcock. A neo-noir masterpiece!

If you've ever wondered what the course America history might have taken if the south had won the Civil War, you might like to check out this infinitely creative, alternately sobering and humorous look at America's lingering legacy of racism.
movie_title: CSA: The Confederate States of America (2005)

movie_review_blurb: Coiffure competition at center of sibling rivalry comedy!
Is it now socially acceptable to utter the N-word in polite company?

A warts and all bio-pic which chronicles the life of a brash Renaissance Man who, frustrated by racism in America, abandoned the U.S. for France at an early age to pursue an assortment of artistic endeavors overseas.
movie_title: How to Eat Your Watermelon in White Company (And Enjoy It) (2005)

movie_review_blurb: 25 guys of every age and ethnicity and from every walk of life not only get naked, but also answer a variety of very intimate questions about their private parts.
A fascinating examination of the artistry, camaraderie and idiosyncrasies among a generation enigmatic jazz giants.
A quarter century after the release of The Gods Must Be Crazy, this charming variation on the theme relies on a similar scenario to examine the lost innocence of another naive primitive.
A damning documentary which indicts the MPAA as a thinly-veiled arm of the handful of Hollywood studios which have come to dominate the film industry.
movie_title: This Film Is Not Yet Rated (2006)

movie_review_blurb: Booker and James square-off for a heavyweight political fight reminiscent of Holyfield vs. Tyson, except for the eating of ears.
The basic message here is that everybody gets fired at some time during their careers, and that being able to laugh at yourself might be the best medicine to deal with that trauma.
Not really recommended for the cerebral cineaste, but more for that demographic satiated by bloodlust alone.
Any parents wondering why they don't make wholesome family flicks anymore can stop wondering.
An intricate update of The Great Gatsby exploring such themes as greed, ambition, passion, infidelity and more greed, all against the elegant backdrop of Long Island's leisure class.

Between Charlize's skimpy, spandex outfits and the equally-sparse, angular modernistic architecture this readily digestible, if implausible sci-fi adventure is laced with enough surprises to keep you engaged throughout.

Picture a campy cross of My Stepmother Is an Alien (1988) and The Brother from Another Planet (1984) in which you get to enjoy laughs galore, allusions to horror classics, and a timely social message.

With an admirable impartiality, filmmakers Heidi Ewing and Rachel Grady allow the camera to make these kids look like Bible-thumping kooks as they quote scriptures and try to convert strangers they meet on the street.
A trio of troubled Latinas linked by lawlessness in super-realistic, female empowerment flick not to be missed.
A menagerie of menacing and morphing computer-generated special effects make the movie worthwhile.
movie_title: Harry Potter and the Prisoner of Azkaban (2004)

movie_review_blurb: Why must Hollywood lace every African-American drama with elements of comedy, as if black people find everything comical?
A brainless but harmless display of senseless slaughter!

Curiously, like a compelling cross of Annie Hall and Erica Jong, it is the globetrotting Fox who emerges as the most empathetic and elegant figure by film's end, in spite of her warts-and-all confessional style.
movie_title: Flying: Confessions of a Free Woman (2007)

movie_review_blurb: At least they'll always have Paris. And snow. And 100 days of solitude.

This poignant, flashback flick, is worthwhile for the opportunity to see a couple of seasoned pros, its very well-acquainted leads, Oscar-nominees Gerard Depardieu and Catherine Deneuve, opposite each other again, for the seventh time in their careers.
A character-driven, martial arts adventure more concerned with motivations than karate moves.
A surprisingly-moving message movie about love and redemption filled with sentimental and transformational moments leading to tearjerker of a finale.
movie_title: Marilyn Hotchkiss Ballroom Dancing & Charm School (2006)

movie_review_blurb: Though not a feelgood flick by any means, this encyclopedic recounting/bittersweet biopic does pay tribute to two dudes crazy enough not only to take on the mob, but to win for a while.
Tongue-in-cheek humor that's kinda kinky around the edges.
A timely cautionary tale, even if its heartwarming message gets a little garbled along the way.
Looks like Robin Williams has replaced Cuba Gooding, Jr. as the kiss of death on the set of any comedy.
Campy cult proves that Hell hath no fury like a 50 foot woman scorned.
Puts the fun back into Kung Fu. And Zen some.
Basically, it's the Little Rascals to the rescue in a flick dressed up as a mystical fable replete with medieval mumbo jumbo and some cool, state-of-the-art special f/x. Otay!
movie_title: Harry Potter and the Order of the Phoenix (2007)

movie_review_blurb: To the extent that you can ignore the jokes in The Last Stand, you'll likely appreciate the rest of Parr's otherwise well-crafted, multi-layered mystery.
Fascinating stuff, but this portrait of these scary 'altar boys' is probably the last thing that Haiti's Board of Tourism wants to see in circulation.
This morally-ambiguous adventure's cleverly-concealed, parallel powder keg plotlines are sufficiently compelling to keep you riveted to these loco losers' predicaments till the bitter end.
A picture which makes a great case against intolerance simply by shedding a bright light on ignorance.
Don't be fooled by the subtitles and the egg head accolades. This pretentious mess is just another country's version of 50 Cent-style fare.
This cat-and-mouse caper's Swiss cheese plotline is riddled with too many holes to consider this flick as much more than a snuff film.

Check your brain at the box-office to enjoy this brand of politically-incorrect hilarity poking fun mostly at gays, women and the French, all aimed at a redneck crowd with an average I.Q. of about 75.
movie_title: Talladega Nights: The Ballad of Ricky Bobby (2006)

movie_review_blurb: Works well so long as it is approached as a tongue-in-cheek farce as opposed to a plausible melodrama.

Steve Buscemi and Sienna Miller exude a raw sensuality in this steamy, character-driven drama which unfolds like a cross between Sleuth and Swept Away. Who'd ever expect to hear 'Steve Buscemi' and 'raw sensuality' in the same sentence?
A bizarre but brilliant headscratcher!
Guaranteed to be a hit with onanistic adolescent boys blinded by raging hormones.
A disjointed, ear-splitting, visually-jarring, mirthless exercise in pandemonium that director Terry Gilliam tries to pass off as family entertainment.

A modern-day Western from Lasse Hallstrom which doesn't measure up to the best of the three-time Oscar-nominee's work, but is, nonetheless, a beautifully filmed panoramic production with a plot compelling enough to recommend.
Cluttered and predictable; but laced with laughs and enough of an emotional payoff to make it all worthwhile.
A bittersweet, if ultimately uplifting, coming-of-age tale touching on a litany of themes, including fantasy, friendship and family.
What is most remarkable about these Asian-American stand-up comics' sophisticated brand of humor is that most manage to be hilarious without referring to themselves in a disparaging fashion.

Another fascinating character study from French director Patrice Leconte who has proven himself quite adept at plumbing the depths of the human psyche by placing a couple of people with nothing in common in an emotionally-explosive predicament.

A droll romantic comedy that relies on a self-deprecating brand of humor which must be a bit of an acquired taste. The film's utter predictably sinks this exercise in obviousms, making its few funny moments not worth waiting for.

Gets this critic's seal of approval as another overblown Michael Bay extravaganza, for it succeeds in bringing a cornucopia of beloved robots to life for a concatenation of epic battles worthy of a bombastic summer blockbuster.

Leelee Sobieski, the innocent child-turned-teen star who took a break from showbiz to attend Brown University, makes it clear here that she'll have no problem making the transition to more mature roles.

This classic series holds up, because everybody enjoys timeless, classic bad B-flicks, especially when you can sit back and relax since somebody else already went to the trouble of poking fun at them for you.
All in all, these 25 sketches are so funny you'll forget that they might actually be reinforcing the same deep-seated intolerance in American culture they seek to satirize.

For a revenge comedy to work, the villain should be so despicable that you relish those moments when the victim turns the tables and gets even. This flick is misleading because the title character is not really mean, but rather a sympathetic figure.
A fitting capstone on a collection of screen classics for the ages!
movie_title: Star Wars: Episode III - Revenge of the Sith (2005)

movie_review_blurb: An irritating excuse to glorify senseless slaughter!
XXXcruciating!
The typical romantic comedy keeps the leads apart or until just before the closing credits. This film falls flat because they engage in sex during the picture's opening sequence.
Examines a variety of questions, such as superficiality versus substance, materialism versus self-worth, and taking advantage of others versus forming sincere relationships.
Drew Barrymore gives an excellent performance as a lady-in-waiting opposite Jimmy Fallon's equally-impressive portrayal of a jittery, baseball-obsessed beau.
This bottom-feeder's sophomoric, locker room approach to black-white, gay-straight, and male-female issues cannot be undone by a saccharine storybook ending.

In the end, you can't help but wonder exactly what it was you've just seen. A hard-hitting exposé? Voyeuristic slumming? A true tale of triumph, against all odds? A self-aggrandizing, vanity biopic? Some new type of reality film?Perhaps all of the above.
Though not always in good taste, this tongue-in-cheek parody of the horror genre is sophisticated and clever enough to earn the appreciation of the egghead cult crowd.
Contrasts European greed and decadence with the fallout visited upon Africa due to the relentless rape of its natural resources in the name of profit.
A chemistry-free buddy flick.
This celebration of the beloved icon's 65th birthday takes a fond look back at his life with the help of many who knew him.
An unsatisfying compromise flick on the fence which might have worked had it either been played straight or purely for laughs.
Recommended, not for the yucks, but just because it relates a touching tale about a brother who doesn't let success go to his head and never forgets where he came from.
A disconnected series of skits and one-liners likely to satisfy children while only infuriating nostalgic adults in search of the magic of the Fifties sitcom.
Works splendidly because it dispenses with the idea that Batman's archenemies have to be quirky, colorful, superficial savants, àla the campy television series from the sixties.
Has some hilarious moments, mostly thanks to Will Ferrell's zany slapstick, mugging, and other antics.
Spielberg flips the E.T. script with this sci-fi flick which reverts to the pulp fiction notion of aliens as the enemies of earthlings.
Tim Story gives the Marvel comics superheroes the Barbershop treatment.
Director Jacquet has cleverly figured out a way to anthropomorphise his wondrous, web-footed subjects, as they deal with hunger, rejection, loss, loneliness, and sensuality.

Despite being bogged down by several distracting, extended dance numbers, this zany farce has just enough momentum and surprises along the way to hold one's interest for the duration. But it'll help immeasurably if you're a devotee of daytime soap operas.
If you only see one film this summer, you need to get out more. But make this the one you choose.
Features a rainbow coalition of scantily-clad models hanging around the hedonistic protagonist like refugees from a Jay-Z video.
Right up there with the best of the revenge genre, and earns praise from this critic for its sophisticated brand of humor which kept me in stitches from start to finish.

Exposes the U.S. as a very dangerous place to be any combination of poor, sick and old and suggests that the AMA ought to consider changing its Hippocratic oath from 'First, do no harm,' to 'First, check the wallet.'
A faith-based, corporate-sponsored, family comedy for folks who don't mind having a familiar Biblical tale about sin overhauled into a contemporary allegory about saving the environment.

Despite death threats, in this revealing expose' former 'Economic Hit Man' John Perkins details exactly how America goes about cheating less powerful nations, exploiting their citizens while helping itself to their natural resources.
Recommended as an excellent alternative to the mainstream propaganda which would have us internalize the worst beliefs about an unfairly maligned segment of society.
Couldn't have arrived at a more timely moment, given the recent arrest of Atlanta Falcons quarterback Michael Vick on federal charges for hanging, drowning, electrocuting and beating dogs to death.
A no harm-no foul feelgood flick where everybody gets an 11th hour dispensation since Jimmy was really straight all along.
A deliberate, thought-provoking, existential meditation on the curse of creating a neverending heaven on Earth.

Confessions of a Call Girl lands in this critic's 'It's so bad it's good' file because the characters are so laughably cartoonish and because Tamala Jones never gets tired of baring her curvaceous booty and cannonball implants for the camera.
An eye-opening expose' welcoming white Americans to the Third World.
War, what is it good for? Unh! Absolutely nothin'!

Pardon me for being offended when a flick revolving around the question of journalistic ethics takes so many liberties with the truth simply to spin a tall tale designed to tug on unsuspecting heartstrings.
Just a voyeuristic excuse to watch people die in different ways.

From the Western perspective, the feisty protagonists' predicament might seem silly, until it gradually sinks in that this treatment is business as usual in a backward land that seems to have gotten stuck in the Middle Ages. Alley Oop lives!
A slow death.

Ballet-like bloodsport reminiscent of the eye-pleasing, if gratuitous, gore of such over-stimulation mavens as John Woo and Sam Peckinpah. Taut testosterone-sodden titillation, if graphic gunplay's your pleasure.
Suffers from one serious flaw, the otherwise talented director's choice of himself to star in the picture. Now 24, he's simply a little long in the tooth to try to pass for a teenager.

A genderbending teensploit turning on a clever twist of the genre's trademark theme. For while most makeover movies feature a female making herself more attractive, this flick has a male deliberately doing the opposite.
A riveting, well-acted, above average example of the horror genre.
Since it would be unfair to spoil a moment of this perfectly-plotted masterpiece, all you need to know is that it landed on this critic's Best Movies of the Millennium List in 2000.
Riveting, well-acted, female empowerment flicks and above average examples of the horror genre.

A romantic comedy trading on Woody Allen's trademark themes, except substituting Chicago for New York as a backdrop and as the cinematic source of its inspiration. Too bad comedienne Sarah Silverman simply is no Diane Keaton. La-di-da... la-di-da...
movie_title: I Want Someone to Eat Cheese With (2006)

movie_review_blurb: Even if you've watched archival evidence of the Holocaust before, anyone with a soul and a functioning conscience intact ought to brace yourself to be sickened afresh by this nauseating, if necessary, reminder of man's inhumanity to man. Never again!
