Not so much an examination of the tragic trajectory of an ill-fated reality-TV show but just the biggest hoax since The Blair Witch Project.
movie_title: American Cannibal: The Road to Reality (2006)

movie_review_blurb: A fascinating documentary made memorable not by its music but by its poignant portrait of a likable, if narrowly-focused, purist unwilling to compromise his values, regardless of its cost in terms of fame or his career.
A readily-forgettable romantic comedy which, unfortunately, entirely fails to be funny along the way

While equally paying homage to directors Peckinpah, Eastwood, and Kurosawa, what makes Open Range special is that it's a love story, too. And one peopled by endearing characters we're inclined to care about when the bloodletting has finally ended.
A one-dimensional cinematic treat best savored with one's brain on pause.
A complicated cowboy flick where you're conflicted about whether to root for the guys in the white hats or the black hats by the time the big showdown arrives.
What is most fascinating is how prescient expectations emanating from the mouths of babes turned out to be. Time-lapse cinematography taken at seven year intervals.
NYC as a dangerous metropolis where a gun-toting fem avenger indulging in a cerebral bloodsport has a close brush with death every five minutes or so.
A wholesome female empowerment adventure, and one very likely to resonate with youngsters of both sexes in the pre-teen crowd.
Sticky Fingaz certainly holds his own here, plus there's plenty of gore to satiate the bloodlust of fans of the genre.

Kene Holliday, who many might remember as Andy Griffith's African-American sidekick on the TV series Matlock back in the late Eighties, revitalizes his career here with a nonpareil outing which ought not be forgotten come Oscar time.

A breakout role for Dan Fogler, who comes across as a combination of Johns Belushi and Candy, exhibiting the former's unbounded enthusiasm, and the latter's ever-endearing charm. Just remember to check your brain at the box-office.

Comprehensive bio-pic of the Beat Generation poet best remembered for 'Howl' the epic poem which opens with the immortal line, 'I saw the best minds of my generation destroyed by madness.' Cool, Daddy-O!
movie_title: The Life and Times of Allen Ginsberg (1994)

movie_review_blurb: There's hope for humanity, afterall, when a sitcom like this which recognizes inner beauty is a big hit.
Can someone explain to me exactly how a horror flick about a scourge that's making humanity more civilized is supposed to be scary? Not exactly edge of your seat excitement.
Adam Sandler and Kevin James ought to be ashamed to be associated with the cinematic equivalent of gay bashing.
movie_title: I Now Pronounce You Chuck & Larry (2007)

movie_review_blurb: A safe, self-congratulatory fantasy which revisits the civil rights era not for a valuable history lesson but for an escapist, syrupy sweet, sing-a-long trip down memory lane to an unrecognizable, Hollywood utopia that never existed.

In revisiting the oppressive measures employed by the FBI during that era, the viewer is treated to a welcome message about the right, if not the duty, to challenge authority, especially in the face of corruption, intransigence and utter arrogance.

While this incriminating documentary makes a convincing case against the White House, it arrives a bit belatedly, at a juncture when John McCain is just about the only loyalist left still sipping the Bush Kool Aid.

An edgy, engaging and easily believable coming-of-age portrait whose intimacy and plausibility probably derive from the fact that it was in part based on the real-life experiences of its writer/director.
The most degrading, minstrel coon show since Soul Plane!

Brilliant, if belated, but be forewarned that The Simpsons, the movie, is merely The Simpsons, the television show, only on a much bigger screen and in an extended format. You want more, you got more.
Further proof that Christian Bale might be the best thespian around never nominated for an Oscar.
As twisted and steamy a psychological thriller as you could hope to find, provided you're not put off by the pedophilia coursing through this intriguing romantic roundelay.
An example of cinema verite at its very best.
A clean S&M flick which only devotees of mental cruelty are likely to find satisfying. Office Space, Japanese Style!
If you don't have the range to play anything other than the same sort of comedic role as an over-the-top human oddity, maybe you shouldn't try to ply your trade as a dramatic actor.
Cool CGI represents a substantial improvement over their earlier incarnations' relatively lame action sequences.
Doesn't even measure up to an episode of your typical, cowboy TV show from the Fifties like Roy Rogers or The Lone Ranger. Get my drift, Kimosabe?
Certain to evoke a few tears from Fania fans with feelings of nostalgia for the bygone era.
Rosario Dawson exhibits a previously unseen range, here, more than meeting the challenge of the most emotionally-demanding role of her career.
Not exactly compelling stuff, especially if you caught the recent 60 Minutes segment about this traitor which covered substantially the same ground.
Represents a bit of a departure of sorts for David Fincher, since this chilling crime saga is surprisingly understated in tone in comparison to some of his earlier, highly-stylized productions.
Cuba 'Show me the money!' Gooding, Jr. stars in this utterly predictable, unfunny, infantile test of patience and waste of ninety minutes of my life I can never get back. Show me the exit!
The best buddy-cop comedy since Rush Hour 2.
Predigested drivel.
Christmas with the cracked.

This isn't a movie with any meaningful insights to share about the heartfelt concerns of the over-forty set, but is rather an ill-conceived, "coming-of-age" style misadventure which could just as easily have revolved around some recent high school grads.

Borrowing a page or two from of the Hitchcock classic Rear Window (1954), this riveting psychological thriller for the Internet Age delivers as compelling a variation on the helpless voyeur theme as one might hope to find.

Rather weird for an overcoming-the-odds flick in that the newcomers cast in the starring roles are obviously attempting to achieve in real-life what the characters they're portraying are trying to do in the saga on screen.
Gives a whole new meaning to the word 'Powerball.'

Though featuring cheapo special effects, phony-looking fight scenes and cornball dialogue, this throwback is readily recommended for anyone who might enjoy a campy cross of Mothra and The Mighty Morphin Power Rangers.
A relentlessly-raunchy cross between American Pie and Harold & Kumar Go to White Castle, a laugh out loud teensploit that's every bit as funny as either of those classics.

The post-9-11 plotline is designed to question the CIA's rationalization of resorting to rendition and suspect interrogation tactics in the age of the Patriot Act. How much harrowing paranoia can you handle?
Film focuses on the pivotal round in 12 different fights which best help highlight Muhammad ali's brilliance inside the ring, where he exhibited a guile and grace unmatched either before or since.
They say The South has changed, but you wouldn't know it from this jaw-dropping shocker you have to see to be believe.

The worst comic book adaptation since, well, since Fantastic Four 1. An unimaginative disaster that takes forever to end, as if the celluloid is being stretched by Mr. Fantastic to make the movie last ten times longer than ninety minutes.
movie_title: Fantastic Four: Rise of the Silver Surfer (2007)

movie_review_blurb: The stripped-down production looks more like a play than a movie, but all the actors do a decent job with a script which turns increasingly preposterous at every turn.
There's chemistry and tension aplenty in this bittersweet character study.
Not quite Hitchcock, but a satisfying flick, and proof positive that you don't need a big budget or A-list talent to make a decent whodunit.

Relying on a daring script as executed by A-list actors, offers a potentially transformational experience for any inclined to contemplate an introspective, gut-wrenching meditation on the intractability of the legacy of slavery.
Enough projectile vomit, fart and poop jokes to keep kids of any age enthralled for ninety-minutes.
A Japanese war flick comprised of contrasting character portraits of soldiers torn between dying with honor and the very human instinct of self-preservation.
An eye-opening expose' on the evils of slavery which forced the U.S. to face that long-suppressed aspect of its legacy.

Alternately laugh-out-loud silly and profoundly moving, kudos to Sofia Coppola for managing to capture an undeniable chemistry between Murray and his 18 year-old co-star, despite a certain asexuality.
A sentimental film filled with flashbacks and clichés.
Ostensibly modeled on the egomaniacal Ted Baxter of the old Mary Tyler Moore TV series, this adventure's protagonist is less comical, less endearing, and generally grates on the nerves.
movie_title: Anchorman - The Legend Of Ron Burgundy (2004)

movie_review_blurb: In many ways this movie tells us far more about the values and age in which we are living, than the one it pretends to be returning us to.
If you ignore the plot and just approach the flick as nothing more than a 21st century update of a Busby Berkeley-style musical, you will not be disappointed.

Though I felt cheated by the Trump-McMahon charade, I'm not too proud to admit that I still found the rest of the DVD amusing enough, even if I had to lower my I.Q. 50 points or so to enjoy all the spectacular stunts with wide-eyed wonder.
An ingenious satire of the pretentious mindset of the elitist art world from the perspective of a rapidly-disillusioned kid who had no idea what he was getting into.
A blasphemous blaxploit!
A delightful, slapstick adventure about a naïve innocent, woefully ill equipped to handle the rigors of life inside any impatiently unforgiving metropolis.
Whether he's dead or alive, this film reveals Tupac to be a scared, skinny kid with a gun, and a vulnerable human being who could easily be pierced by bullets, just like the rest of us.

Filled with soul-stirring songs likely to get Christian couch potatoes stomping on their feet as if they're in the choir of a Baptist congregation that's caught the spirit in church on Sunday morning.
movie_title: Celebration of Gospel: Taking You Higher (2007)

movie_review_blurb: A wonderful message movie, warts-an-all!
Ever so subtly, Spielberg masterfully conveys the toll which the inordinate tension of their job and the mechanics of their methods take on his subjects' souls.
Be prepared to laugh from the opening credits through the closing credits.
A documentary which captures an eccentric ornithologist communing with his flock with an intimacy that's almost unimaginable.
movie_title: The Wild Parrots of Telegraph Hill (2005)

movie_review_blurb: Proves to be an intriguing enough adventure, provided you haven't seen Crimes and Misdemeanors and don't mind rooting for a despicable, amoral philanderer.
A derivative, readily-forgettable insult to the intelligence!
Instead of a tribute to a fine chapter in the annals of the Greatest Generation, we have a second-rate romance right out of a cheesy, pulp fiction novel.

While The Gospel's faith-laced dialogue might annoy non-Christians, the plot mostly explores themes of a universal nature. Recommended to members of any faith for the stirring, onscreen performance of Grammy-winner Yolanda Adams.

Worthwhile for the cinematography alone, which is nothing short of inspired, such as the love scene shot through the pale pattern of a lace curtain, which dissolves almost imperceptibly into the whiteout of a steady blizzard.
Preposterous!
A very scary documentary illustrating the carte blanche accorded Big Brother by the Patriot Act

With colorful characters relying on exaggerated Ebonics, this sitcom unfolds like an extended episode of a modern-day, minstrel TV show except not as funny, especially since the stereotypes on display here are by and large woefully outdated.
A surefire kiddie crowd-pleaser, given the teeny-bop penchant for over-stimulating computer game warfare.

Though a bit melodramatic in spots by today's standards, holds up enough to remain heartily recommended as a valuable history lesson and as a juxtaposition to demeaning satires by shock comics such as Dave Chappelle.
Hey, everybody loves the real Ray Romano, too!
Consumers of the world unite! We have nothing to lose but our plastic!
How often can you say that a psychological thriller is as intriguing as it is titillating?
The ghetto goes Godzilla!
Two dozen souls, linked by suicide as a seductive, and very visible alternative to unrelenting torment and suffering.
Like Woody Allen in a mask and stretchy pants, he's your friendly neurotic Spider-Man.
A damning documentary which indicts Americas as a Credit Industrial Complex where repossession and foreclosure have become commonplace rather than the exception.
A novel experiment which one hopes will be tried again soon.

Shrouded by a haunting pall which permeates the picture throughout, the movie is more interested in examining the mindset of a maniacal Muslim with her finger on the trigger than with the plight of her potential victims.
An alternately invigorating, intoxicating, nostalgic and uplifting testament to the intrepid activists of a bygone era when Americans felt much more comfortable challenging authority.
movie_title: Isn't This a Time! A Tribute Concert for Harold Leventhal (2005)

movie_review_blurb: A sweet, little unpretentious slice-of-life flick from Iran which, while highlighting the arid region's visually-arresting, utter desolation, ever so subtly hints at the tension between a simmering feminism and traditional Muslim values.

For some reason, teasing people about their skin color has become a big theme of brainless black comedies like this. Plus, it unfolds like one long Pepsi ad, with dialogue extolling the cola's virtues in virtually every scene.
Worthwhile as an informative and touching reminder of the existence of a forgotten set of innocent victims of the Vietnam conflict.

Who knows whether Dan Brown was motivated by a distaste for Catholicism or merely by money? Regardless, it seems dishonest for him to foist his debunked heresies on the gullible, unsuspecting public as if they're the God's honest truth.
An insult to the viewer's intelligence, which sticks to silly slapstick while failing to get around to making a mature statement about relationships.
With 100% of the profits going to non-profit charities devoted to youth, The Hip Hop Project might be the first totally tax deductible movie.
Courtroom drama about the landmark decision which established Battered Women's Syndrome as a defense, at least in England, where relief for an abused wife is now just a Molotov cocktail away.

What makes it all worthwhile are the priceless moments that Mo'Nique devotes to showing off her sensitive side, as when lifting the spirits, one-on-one offstage, of a woman doing 145 years for murder.
movie_title: Mo'Nique - I Coulda Been Your Cellmate! (2006)

movie_review_blurb: Philip Baker Hall throws himself into the role ever so convincingly opposite his anthropomorphized companion in a manner reminiscent of Jimmy Stewart with his imaginary 6-foot tall rabbit in Harvey, and Tom Hanks with Wilson the volleyball in Cast Away.

A thought-provoking clarion call which concludes that America, instead of being by the people and for the people is, in truth, an oppressive, exploitative Big Brother where government and corporations reign supreme.
Despite capturing many heartbreaking aspects of the disaster, this is essentially an overambitious mess which ultimately fails to convey effectively the scale or scope of the ongoing tragedy.
movie_title: When the Levees Broke: A Requiem in Four Acts (2006)

movie_review_blurb: Bottoms-out with this bit of dialogue: 'If you're going to be a ho, be an ambitious ho. Work uptown.' What unfortunate timing, given the whole Don Imus controversy. Life's simply too short for slur-ploitation with such lamentably low standards.

Females take it on the chin with the description of one as "a snaggle-toothed crack-head with four baby-daddies." Worse, it is suggested to the protagonist that dating a prostitute would be a step up for him. Sorry, no redeeming qualities.
One of those movies that's great until the movie starts.
A genre-bending female empowerment flick masquerading as a titillating teensplurt.
Shot on the cheap in what appears to be an abandoned ghost town, it looks like the only thing they bothered to budget for was cuss words.
A comical cautionary tale which ought to trigger a little paranoia in the souls of any advocates of the Military-Industrial Complex.
Amounts to the most convincing cinematic case yet that unconditional peace ought to be an urgent imperative.

A cross between Seabiscuit (because of the Depression) and Rocky (because of the sport), yet a fine enough film to stand on its own, even if the production falls short of both in terms of its emotional punch.

With the preordained outcome of telegraphed in its opening scene, all that's left to enjoy of this mean-spirited melodrama, are politically-incorrect laughs at the expense of a bizarre cross-section of California kooks.

Especially entertaining is this con man's exposing all the tricks of the trade, from how he healed confederates feigning illnesses to the special gestures and vocal cadences designed to hypnotize his gullible followers.
Not a particularly overtly political documentary, yet effective, given that Monsieur Henri was most definitely blessed with an eye for freezing reality via the magic of still photography.

As adroitly executed a directorial debut as you could ever hope to find, this ingenious, sci-fi comedy revolves around a mythological malady which causes carriers to change gender whenever they make love.

Deliberately disgusting, scatological, profane and vulgar, which makes this critic a bit embarrassed to admit that he found himself frequently laughing out loud at such offensive and obscene material.
Not a feel-good flick, yet likely to strike a chord with those inclined to contemplate life as a pessimistic venture guided by the unpredictable vagaries of the fickle finger of fate.
Mating calls aside, the paint-by-numbers sports side of this picture is only likely to capture the imagination of kids under the age of ten.
An intriguing deconstruction of a failed relationship, long past its point of no return.

Pardon me for expecting African-American fare to be far more sophisticated than the new millennium's equivalent of Amos & Andy, complete with Kingfish-quality buffoonery and an array of other degenerate coons.
A hilarious family values flick which manages to convince you that it's possible to transform a misogynist into a doting father on the guilt of an unplanned pregnancy.

Is Barry Bonds the greatest home run hitter ever or a cheater helped by performance enhancing drugs? This balanced documentary doesn't endeavor to answer that question, leaving it to the viewer to draw the obvious conclusion that he just might be both.
An empathetic portrait of a complicated figure, chronicling the mounting toll which his work in the gallows gradually took on his psyche and private life.
Irrefutable evidence that post modern suburbia is an unmitigated disaster which can't deliver on its seductive promise to deliver the good life to refugees from the big city.
Ostensibly-inspired by The Apprentice, what this reality movie's missing most is a cocky host with a cotton candy-colored comb-over. How do you say, 'You're fired!' in Spanish.

Upping the ante in terms of intrigue while toning it down in terms of action, this downright comfortable diversion is a relatively-cerebral affair which offers an absorbing alternative to the summer blockbusters of the over-stimulating, special effects-dr

A powerful picture primarily because it never proselytizes but simple allows its visually-overwhelmed audience to draw its own conclusions about the unconsidered downside of living beyond our ecological means.

Given the shortsighted shenanigans engaged in by these corporate-oriented politicians and greedy captains of industry, is it any wonder that we'd end up mired in the Middle East to ensure the flow of oil? Who killed the electric car? The usual suspects.

Entertaining enough as a mildly amusing diversion, even if it might deliver a dubious message to impressionable teenage girls torn between dating a nerdy nice guy and a loser without much of a future.
This documentary which exposes the twin evils of child labor and silver mining, is a most powerful expose' of an ongoing, mass-scale human tragedy.
A depressing illustration of how even Middle America has ended up marginalized and rudderless in the wake of outsourcing, downsizing and globalization.
A lighthearted look at gay love, and a far more honest and ultimately more touching exploration of the theme than what we got up on Brokeback Mountain.
Lean on Me meets Strictly Ballroom. Tough two-step replaces tough love.
A low-brow comedy chock full of cheap laughs.
This adaptation is highly-recommended for loyal devotees of the long-running radio show as a cinematic capstone on Keillor's magnificent career.
Mom, Interrupted.
Proves it's better to burn out, than to fade away.
A gritty, Brazilian drama which called for Alice Braga to be naked and in heat nearly non-stop, whether in a bed with a boyfriend or one of her assortedy Johns.
A rare, optimistic ray of hope about the prospects of Jewish-Muslim relations.

The Man of Steel as a morally-compromised and ethically-challenged figure has the potential to be quite compelling, but if and only if he is portrayed as confronting his demons in a more meaningful way.

Best remembered for launching the careers of John Travolta and Lawrence Hilton-Jacobs, this sitcom revolved around juvenile delinquents cutting-up while their flabbergasted teacher attempted to impart his pearls of wisdom.
If Corey Yuen believed in truth in advertising, ala Snakes on a Plane, this flick would have a name like Jiggly Babes Kick Butt. The stuff that post-pubescent dreams are made of.
Laila Ali's Daddy's Girl
A modern morality play whose positive messages are undercut by its pandering, paternalistic tone.

Plausibly explores the question of whether a liaison initially based on a carnal assault and fueled by an unquenchable lust has any chance of evolving into a relationship based on intimacy, affection and genuine trust.

Some pathetically predictable plot twists and syrupy sentimentality, which could only amuse a five year-old, lead the Kranks back to their materialistic senses in time for a Kodak moment which shouts a rather shallow Merry Capitalism to all!
It's mind-boggling that such relentlessly offensive trash ever finds financial backing from a major Hollywood studio.
A two-and-a-half-hour cinematic mosaic meant by Malick more as a monument to himself than to the misrepresented maiden it presumes to memorialize.
This film fails so miserably don't be surprised to find yourself often rooting against the supposed good guy.
Following a smooth takeoff, this psychological thriller hits some turbulence and crash lands due to a preposterous, almost comical, turn of events.

Who cares that this blockbuster is an incoherent, overplotted mess, when it comes stocked with a charismatic protagonist plus enough swashbuckling action and spooky special f/x to make you forget the fact that the story is impossible to keep straight?
movie_title: Pirates of the Caribbean: At Worlds End (2007)

movie_review_blurb: A fascinating flick for anyone looking for a new reason to hate lawyers.

A disturbing bio-pic chronicling a mammoth miscarriage of justice which can only be explained as resulting from deep-seated racism. Despite its feelgood resolution, the film offers little in the way of reassurances that this will never happen again.
A reality movie which turns entirely on the likeability of a nerd in heat.
To get a good idea of what to expect, think Hee Haw presented as a Shakespearean melodrama.
You are likely to enjoy this bio-pic to the extent that you buy into the idea that one effete snob ought to define an aesthetic for the rest of us slobs.
movie_title: Who Gets to Call It Art? (2006)

movie_review_blurb: Kudos to Witherspoon and Ruffalo for generating enough screen chemistry to insure a teary-eyed finale that'll make you forget the fact that you're watching a shameless rip-off.
A meandering mood piece, with no tension, no chemistry, no character development, no plot and no point.
The ludicrous plot and special effects featuring cartoon physics means this zero is strictly for those under the age of eight or so.
A formulaic soap opera likely to resonate only with fans of romance novels, though men might enjoy the multi-faceted performance of the magnetic Brooklyn Sudano.

Valuable not because of sebastian Telfair's ultimate triumph, but because of how effectively it contrasts his achievement with the plight of so many other aspiring athletes for whom the fantasy of a pro career ultimately fails to materialize.

Without a whit of subtlety, this tired retread induces nary a laugh, only groans of disbelief that we're expected to find such a sorry string of dumb puns, infantile farts, awful accents and endless pratfalls funny.
Another edge-of-your-seat, roller coaster ride from a matinee idol everybody loves to root for.
Recommended, but only for shut-ins who can't make it to a local live theater production of the play.
Narrated by Nic Cage in a zombie-like monotone, this flick is not only gross and morose, but relentlessly depressing.
Provided you're not Puritanical about frontal nudity, this powerful picture based on a myth is otherwise a delight, and a cinematic preservation of a so-called primitive people's oral tradition.
A valuable examination of the intersection of Eastern and Western philosophies from a distinctly Asian perspective.
A bawdy sitcom which careens back and forth between the ridiculous and the sublime.
A claustrophobic bio-pic which telescopes tightly on the torture of the fearless activist till her demise after less than a week in the hands of Hitler's sadistic interrogators.
Breathtaking tableaus, colorful characters, and a moving message about redemption end up overshadowed by wanton insanity one might normally associate with a sadistic snuff film.
movie_title: The Three Burials of Melquiades Estrada (2006)

movie_review_blurb: This time out, the sassy senior citizen has toned-down her act to offset her trademark intensity with an equal measure of inspirational advice.
Takes a fairly encyclopedic approach to present an unparalleled probe into the mind of an art icon.
Features some sweet moments of reflection by the late Mamie Till during which she wistfully reminisces about the intelligent, curious and animated son taken away from her so brutally and senselessly.
movie_title: Untold Story of Emmett Louis Till (2005)

movie_review_blurb: A psychological thriller with a cleverly-concealed subplot likely to surprise even the best of cinema sleuths.
A series of disjointed, shocking, and often unintentionally-humorous vignettes designed to celebrate boy-boy camaraderie while fomenting anti-Arab sentiments in the name of God, mom, and Apple Pie.
I like Kenny Shopsin!
Co-directors Lexy Levell and Michael Uys deserve a 21-gun salute for fashioning a sobering antidote to all that patriotic claptrap about serving God, country and apple pie.
A rehash of familiar material, but the engaging Garner is charismatic enough to make it magical.
A brilliantly-conceived, well-executed, micro-budgeted, action-packed thriller which gives a whole new meaning to 4th of July fireworks.

A 21st Century variation on the age-old theme where an insufferable 1%-er finally gets in touch with his sensitive side with the help of an irresistible ragamuffin representing the downtrodden rest of humanity.
An overdue tribute to a revered icon and to some unsung foot soldiers who played a critical role at a seminal moment in the courageous African-American struggle for freedom and equality.
An honorable, historical drama who's primary flaw rests in its being released too soon after a more-compelling biopic revolving around similar subject-matter.
The cinematic equivalent of an entertaining encyclopedic entry about the most irresistible offering on today's Chinese takeout menu!
A bittersweet documentary detailing an attempt to reconcile a pair of siblings' polar opposite approaches to surviving the Holocaust.

Rising star Clara Mamet makes a memorable writing and directorial debut with this semi-autobiographical coming-of-age tale where she also plays a suicidal teen struggling to find her place in the world.
An unstructured, atmospheric affair ostensibly designed to appeal to folks nostalgic for the hedonistic hippie era.
Kudos to Clint Eastwood for fashioning such a moving and well-deserved salute to a real, American war hero!

Check your brain at the box office, and motor-mouthed Kevin Hart, surrounded by a talented cast of seasoned comedians, will keep you in stitches for the duration of a decidedly-lowbrow, politically-incorrect misadventure.
Atmospheric and absorbing, this well-crafted whodunit is rather reminiscent of Red Rock West.
A well-crafted character study which just might land the talented Benedict Cumberbatch a coveted Academy Award.
A modern morality play serving as a telling reminder of exactly how easily an American Dream can dissolve into a neverending dystopian nightmare.

Worth the investment for veteran Costner's vintage performance and for the way in which the timely script dares to tackle some tough social questions in refreshingly-realistic, if perhaps politically-incorrect fashion.
A clever, laff-a-minute adventure worth the investment for the hilarity, even if it telegraphs where the love story might be headed.
Reverential retrospective recounts U.S. pilots' role in Israel's War of Independence.
An over-stimulating, intergalactic odyssey evocative of The Wizard of Oz.
The cinematic equivalent of slumming around the City of Lights' seamy underbelly.
A belated tribute to some fearless patriots with the gumption to expose the FBI's lawless ways and the wherewithal to evade apprehension by the Bureau to boot!
A nostalgic homage to 007 that's also the most mesmerizing movie of the year thus far.
What would Jesus do, Spike? Repent!
A refreshingly-principled parable proving that a picture championing chastity can be every bit as entertaining and enjoyable as one promoting promiscuity.
How come Hugh Grant and Marisa Tomei waited this long to make a romantic comedy together?
A monochromatic misfire featuring only one shade: blushing pink.
Low production values aside, this iconoclastic expose' has a wealth of information to offer the very open-minded.
The theater world's eloquent answer to Black Swan's equally-surrealistic exploration of ballet.
Will Smith and Margot Robbie generate enough chemistry to steam up the screen and make the farfetched romantic romp just worth the watch, provided eye candy alone can do for you in lieu of credulity.
A delightful diversion that succeeds in spoofing the film noir genre while simultaneously spinning a thoroughly-modern variation on the theme of those classic crime capers.
Kevin Costner has never been more endearing than in this outing as a devoted mentor and family man.
A pretty preposterous plotline, but who am I to argue with a tale presumably based on a true story?

You never know who on the Golden Gate is about to leap to his or her death in this compelling documentary, so you have to keep your eyes glued to the screen. 24 tormented souls linked by suicide as a seductive alternative to their unrelenting suffering.
Out-of-the-closet documentary chronicles clandestine life of young black man who hid his HIV status from dozens of college coed classmates he seduced.
Between an engrossing plotline and virtual non-stop combat, the picture proves to be just the perfect way to bring down the curtain on a storied fantasy franchise.
movie_title: The Hobbit: The Battle of the Five Armies (2014)

movie_review_blurb: Food for thought the next time you cavalierly instruct the gas station attendant to 'Fill 'er up!'
Denzel is even better here than in his Oscar-winning collaboration with Antoine Fuqua for Training Day.
The best antidote around to America's unhealthy obsession with youth!
Highly-stylized piffle designed to titillate and satiate bloodlust while slowly turning your brain to mush!
A thought-provoking, faith-based parable asking whether it's ever too late to make a second impression, especially on God.
A touching, true tale chronicling a talented troubadour's televised triumphs.
A cautionary tale about what might easily transpire whenever the Fourth Estate is willing to serve as the Fifth Column rather than as a government watchdog.
A fanciful, thoroughly-modern variation on the parable of the Prodigal Son!
Far be it from me to totally trash a seemingly-silly soap opera males might find laughable to the same extent it moves females to tears. Go figure!
Picture the sheer intensity of Saving Private Ryan coupled with the visual capture of The Thin Red Line, the harrowing claustrophobia of Das Boot, and the utter insanity of Apocalypse Now.
A delightful dissection of the Ivy League that stirs the pot in the way most folks mean when they a call for a national discussion of race.
A syrupy, sentimental soap opera tailor-made for fans of the Nicholas Sparks franchise.
Bill Murray's in rare form, here, as an irascible curmudgeon who exhibits an endearing vulnerability for the sake of an at-risk tween in need of a father figure.
A searing character study unfolding against a variety of visually-captivating L.A. locales ranging from the seamy to the posh, and underscored by an appropriately-gritty soundtrack.
Trench warfare as the backdrop for a tawdry love triangle about as incestuous as it gets.
A sobering cautionary tale suggesting that you reflect upon all the motivations of a news source before swallowing the veracity of a story, hook, line and sinker.
The only thing this titillating teensploit is missing is Haley Joel Osment periodically whispering, 'I see horny people!'
An overdue testament to a one-man six-million man march in memory of all those who no longer had a voice.
movie_title: I Have Never Forgotten You: The Life And Legacy Of Simon Wiesenthal (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Love in the time of hip-hopera!
I'm not too proud to admit I couldn't follow the convoluted storyline... Think, a remake of Gravity with a bunch of polysyllabic brainiacs borrowed from The Big Bang Theory.
A compelling, coming-of-age tale about a lifelong dream-turned-neverending nightmare, all because of a sadistic studio bandleader from Hell!
A sobering lesson about controlling the corporate message in this age of double speak where symbolic gestures have replaced sincerity, substance and any concern about viable solutions.
A kitchen sink shocksploit featuring disgusting displays of depravity and vulgarity.
Enlightening history lessons and lots of one-liners delivered by yesteryear's stars of tomorrow preserved on vintage footage of yesteryear.
Too bad that most of the movie is devoted to such a misanthropic and misogynistic brand of humor.
This uneventful installment basically treads water while functioning as a setup for the upcoming dramatic conclusion
I can only pray that Daniel and Jason's momentary thrill of setting those buildings ablaze was worth flushing their futures down the drain.
Reese Witherspoon delivers a decent enough performance to singlehandedly elevate an otherwise mediocre adventure to an entertaining one worth recommending.
Revisionist history doc chronicles Frenchman's secret role in toppling Apartheid.
An overdue homage to a city that for close to a decade was home to the second largest black business in America.
A mind is a terrible thing to lose!
Liam Neeson delivers afresh in an edge-of-your-seat, high body-count thriller every bit as good as they come!
A modern morality play examining the emotional and physical toll exacted by the military tactic of bombing by drones.
An edge-of-your-seat, adrenaline-fueled, high body-count splatterfest that remains riveting from start to finish despite dispensing with the idea of plot development once the premise has been set.
A road to redemption paved with wisecracks and wonderful harmonies.
The Crucifixion revisited featuring a black Jesus as the victim of a bias crime!
A derivative, estrogen-fueled, overcoming-the-odds saga strictly recommended for females interested in seeing sepia-skinned Adonises gyrate while disrobing to mind-numbing disco music.

Autism is now, effectively, universal in nature which makes a labor of love like Bass Clef Bliss certain to resonate deeply with any spiritually-inclined soul compassionately attuned to other than self.
Does for San Francisco what Jaws did for the Ocean!
Scary enough to teach me that I can scream louder than my wife!
Vintage Vince and company having tons of testosterone-fueled fun whether being titillated by bimbos or just roaming aimlessly around L.A. in a classic convertible.
A Melissa McCarthy vehicle recommended for fans with a big appetite for her crude, expletive-laced brand of humor.
A refreshingly exhilarating, emotional and ultimately uplifting examination of youngsters forging an unbreakable bond in the face of a malignant force far beyond their control.
movie_title: Me and Earl and the Dying Girl (2015)

movie_review_blurb: The Rust Belt's 'New Normal' depicted as a desolate, depressed dystopia dotted with street urchins a tad too naïve to appreciate their dire life prospects.
A riveting courtroom drama chronicling an emotionally-draining showdown played out on a world stage between the Black Lives Matter and Stand Your Ground movements.
The latest offering from filmmaker Bent Hamer, an enigmatic Norwegian with a knack for creating droll dramedies.
Not quite a Spielberg-quality blockbuster, but it'll do.
A touching tale illustrating how a dramatic life change might, temporarily at least, exact a terrible toll on a frail human psyche.
A cattle prod of a picture which incessantly provokes and pushes the cinematic envelope while taking no prisoners in a very freaky battle-of-the-sexes.
A nostalgic tribute to a materialistic generation weaned on conspicuous consumption where capped gold teeth and gaudy clock necklaces were trendy fashion statements.
A latter-day variation on the Prodigal Son parable providing proof that God still works in mysterious ways.
An unabashedly carnal indulgence solely interested in inducing gelatinous drools of saliva from the mouths of overstimulated females.
An atmospheric whodunit guaranteed to keep you intrigued and guessing right to the very end.
An improbable, if thought-provoking mind-bender built on a house of cards that holds up only to the extent you're willing to go along with its preposterous premise.
Scary fright fare that puts a creepy new spin on the meaning of school spirit.
Ole! Ole! Ole!
movie_title: Tango Negro: The African Roots of Tango (2015)

movie_review_blurb: A compelling character study of a likable do-gooder whose only regret is that he has but one life to devote to his fellow man.
From full-frontal male nudity to an F-word laced theme song, Vacation is a cringe-inducing disappointment that bears little resemblance to the original it so desperately endeavors to pay homage to.
A must-see account of the birth of passionate, television punditry.
The epitome of a bona fide summer blockbuster!
A rollicking roller coaster ride around the 'hood that's basically a hilarious cross between Kid and Play's House Party (1990) and Harold & Kumar Go to White Castle (2004).
Sorry, Adam Sandler simply isn't very convincing playing a character with an I.Q. above room temperature.
Sofia Vergara successfully stakes her claim as the heir apparent of Brazilian bombshell Carmen Miranda. All she needs now is a fruit-filled sombrero!
The best Mexican splatterfest since Bring Me the Head of Alfredo Garcia!
A tenderhearted lesson in how friendship can be forged in spite of a great gulf in age, class and I.Q.
A pleasant, if predictable, romantic romp laced with far more mirth than sophistication or substance.
movie_title: The Second Best Exotic Marigold Hotel (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Credit co-stars Douglas Smith and Zoe Kravitz for generating just the right chemistry as endearing oddballs to turn this quirky coming-of-age adventure into an appealing romantic romp.
A creepy, counterintuitive fright fest that puts a perverse spin on the meaning of getting lucky.
A rising young star exhibits an impressive acting range in a physically as well as emotionally-demanding role promising to do for her what The Hunger Games did for Jennifer Lawrence.
A Sean Penn vehicle affording the surprisingly-buff (if long in the tooth) matinee idol ample opportunities to put his pecs on display in high-impact fight sequences as well as lingering love scenes.
An inspired pairing of the relentlessly absurd Ferrell and the motor-mouthed Hart at the top of their games.
Who wants to watch four, obnoxious, testosterone-fueled slackers vent their vile along a gauntlet of unsuspecting victims?
A cautionary, eco-expose' amounting to a persuasive case that clean, free-flowing H2O in abundance is critical to preservation of life on the planet.
A relentlessly-cheesy B-flick far funnier than it is frightening.
The cinematic equivalent of a Jehovah's Witness who won't take 'no' for an answer getting his foot stuck in your door.
This inscrutable adventure proves a pure delight to unravel from beginning to end.
If the aim of the picture is to trigger introspection in an audience about the consequences of the choices one makes in life, then bull's eye!

Alternately vulnerable and bizarre, but always endearing, the Saturday Night Live alum enjoys her best outing since Bridesmaids, here, as an anguished soul allowed, against her better judgment, to purchase a terribly-embarrassing, 15 minutes of fame.
How do you say Norma Rae in Spanish?
A must-see biopic poignantly illustrating the indomitability of the human spirit, even in the most oppressive of circumstances.
A grim, grudging-buddies splatterfest featuring a few surprising plot twists and all the fixin's for a riveting cinematic experience.
This predictable whodunit proves a tad too transparent.
A daunting test of teen loyalty by way of an Electronic Age equivalent of a Salem witch hunt.
A captivating combination of camaraderie and cartoon physics tempered by just enough nostalgia to tug at your heartstrings.
A cautionary expose' making a convincing argument that consumers would be very wise to learn all they can about the ingredients in the products they buy.
Revenge as a dish best served pixilated!
Paints a plausible picture of a just-dumped divorcee doing her best to pick up the pieces of her shattered dreams.
A gritty, inner-city saga of Shakespearean proportions shot on location in West Philadelphia. Romeo, Romeo, wherefore art though Romeo? I be hanging with my homeys, mama!
An alternately humorous and sobering cautionary tale chronicling the woes of an exasperated kid smothered by a well-meaning mom in an era of omnipresent parenting.
A gospel-driven cross of Precious and Rent, only set in a sleepy Southern town that time forgot instead of New York City.
A thought-provoking thriller guaranteed to keep you enthralled while reassessing the meaning of consciousness
A moralizing, paint-by-numbers parable lifted right out of the Hollywood hack playbook.
The sort of action adventure a Born Again Quentin Tarantino might make.
A decent enough overhaul to recommend heartily as a pleasant escape from the hazy, hot, humid dog days of August.
The alpha male answer to Eat Pray Love!
movie_title: Hector And The Search For Happiness (2014)

movie_review_blurb: Thanks to Mr. Elba's menacing intensity, a potentially mediocre variation on the theme ends up elevated into a tension-filled gutwrencher his loyal fans won't want to miss.
An overplotted, feel-bad flick saved by a host of compelling performances, most notably those of Meryl Streep and Margo Martindale.
To paraphrase Mary Poppins, "Just a spoonful of sugar helps revisionist history go down," and in a most delightful way!
As much a poignant meditation on motherhood lost as a searing indictment of the Catholic Church's antiquated attitude about what might be in the best interests of an adopted child.
A modern morality play about a young felon who, after paying his debt to society, left the slammer rehabilitated with more of a fondness for rhyme than robbery.
A pleasant, if predictable, romantic romp determined to march inexorably to an implausible, happily ever after finale, whether you like it or not.
A Sunday school-style parable which makes very effective use of chess mastery as a metaphor for negotiating the perilous gauntlet of possible ghetto pitfalls.
A touching tale of sisterhood with a priceless message about blood being thicker than an ill-advised crush.
A 21st Century update of the Little Rascals' He-Man Woman Hater's Club episode where Alfalfa wises up and woos Darla, his Neanderthal pals' protestations notwithstanding.
A poignant parable which puts what matters most in proper perspective.
A history lesson about an obscure chapter of World War II successfully turned into entertaining Hollywood fare.

Anybody who needs a new reason to hate lawyers ought to check out this shocking documentary chronicling a pay-to-play scheme about a couple of crooked judges who enriched themselves at the expense of innocent adolescents.
The African-American community collectively jumps the broom over its last big taboo!
A searing, supernatural exploration of the human soul suggesting not only that love is real but that miracles happen, too!
A practically-pornographic tribute to fearless, fallen heroes strictly for patriots with a strong stomach for gratuitous violence, however historically accurate.
A compelling, high body-count whodunit for folks willing to watch a lot of kinky cavorting while trying to unravel clues leading to the killer.
Snakes in the Pulpit!
An intriguing enough whodunit to keep you guessing, thanks to a decent script and game performances by De Niro, Cusack and newcomer Rebecca Da Costa.
The Silence of the Butler!
Think a poor man's cross of Napoleon Dynamite (2004) and Old School (2003) where a coming-of-age tale merges with a midlife crisis.
Cells on a plane!
A revisionist tale of female empowerment suggesting the fairer sex was the equal of any man even when engaged in mortal hand-to-hand combat.
Though back by popular demand, consider this edition of Veronica Mars compelling enough even to hold the attention of folks unfamiliar with the original TV show.
An unabashedly-sentimental salute to single-moms from all walks of life!
My Big Fat Iranian Wedding!
This passionate polemic might very well go down in history for transforming public opinion about the recovery movement.
A tale of survival of a remarkable hero who overcame incredible odds!
A cautionary morality play offering a new take on the world's oldest profession.
A cinematic primer on how to make a mark on the world.
movie_title: American Revolutionary: The Evolution Of Grace Lee Boggs (2014)

movie_review_blurb: ALN 2.0, a bawdy variation on the theme establishing Kevin Hart as a bona fide box-office attraction.
A priceless history lesson for anyone interested in understanding the back story explaining how formerly-tolerant Egypt evolved into the religious state it is today.
Another memorable masterpiece cleverly crafted by the oh so talented David O!
As much a poignant meditation on motherhood lost as a searing indictment of the Catholic Church's antiquated attitude about what might be in the best interests of an adopted child.
Yip Man lives!
An uplifting tale of female empowerment tarnished by its crude method of delivering a positive message.
A magnificent tapestry of touching relationships more like mother and child than student-teacher. When scientists figure out how to clone humans, they ought to start with Janet Mino.
A warts-and-all biopic which focuses on its subject's childhood, college days and marriage while making short shrift of her transition into a war criminal.
A derivative disappointment that's more of an uninspired remake than a groundbreaking sequel.
Hollywood likes to make martyrs out of mobsters and murderers, but it usually waits at least a generation or two before romanticizing their life stories.
A cautionary tale featuring spectacular Fourth of July fireworks of the emotional variety.
A compelling character study of the emotional toll exacted by a kidnapping on the psyche of the victims' loved ones.

A pleasant, if predictable, romantic comedy trading in the same sort of moralizing and colorful characters of a typical Tyler Perry production. The only thing missing is a sassy, self-righteous, pistol-packing granny in a dress.
A dazzling and delightful sequel every bit as charming as the original!
movie_title: Cloudy with a Chance of Meatballs 2 (2013)

movie_review_blurb: A compelling, high-octane thriller, literally and figuratively!
Shades of Cast Away, with Tom Hanks being tortured by sadists as opposed to talking to a volleyball for over an hour while waiting for the cavalry to arrive.
Buckle up for a relentlessly-riveting, roller coaster ride through a deceptively-close outer space you can virtually reach out and touch!
What's in your laptop?
A sobering slave narrative recounting a recorded, real-life case of inhuman bondage.
An unblinking look at a life and love irreversibly altered by the onset of MS.
A female empowerment flick featuring a blend of ice cream and drumming as a viable path to rehabilitation and reconciliation.
A dangerous border town as no country for old men or middle-aged sisters either.
Let's just hope it doesn't take Malcolm Lee 15 years to shoot another sequel!
Sexual politics make strange bedfellows, too!
A timeless parable as memorable for its spiritual music as for its moving message about the importance of faith and family.
An inspirational adaptation of Mandiba's autobiography which more than does justice to the legacy of a triumphant freedom fighter who made many selfless sacrifices on behalf of his people.
A water-treading sequel that achieves its goal of satiating the fans' bloodlust while whetting their appetite for the franchise's grand finale.
A gritty revenge thriller unfolding against the telling backdrop of a decaying American landscape.
A peaceful walk issuing a warning from the top of the world about the dangers of global warming.
Manhattan '61 revisited!
Sassy sister squares-off against backwoods hillbilly for lots of harmless holiday-themed laughs!
A career performance by Bruce Dern destined to be remembered during awards season!
A picture which proves it's hard in the 'hood not only for pimps, but for kids, too.
movie_title: The Inevitable Defeat of Mister & Pete (2013)

movie_review_blurb: A character-driven examination of a dysfunctional Jewish family about as wacky as they come.
movie_title: This Is Where I Leave You (2014)

movie_review_blurb: An alternately introspective and breathtaking Biblical epic, every bit cerebral as it is panoramic!
Ronald McDonalds of the world unite!
Think Taken with a heckuva twist!
Divisive D'Souza: Imagine an America without him!
movie_title: America: Imagine the World Without Her (2014)

movie_review_blurb: Expect to be moved to tears by this poignant picture's bittersweet resolution and sobering, universal message about the importance of family.
A rollicking romp providing proof positive that love, I mean luv, conquers all, even a hot head with a very short fuse!
A perhaps prophetic satire celebrating senseless slaughter as a natural national holiday in such a gun-loving country!
A droll dramedy examining the male metamorphosis from bachelor to family man.

Another nonpareil performance by Brendan Gleeson, here, as an introspective soul on a spiritual path able to maintain his sanity while facing his mortality in a godforsaken environ where so many in his flock have clearly lost their minds.
A misfiring misadventure not even recommended for diehard Selena Gomez fans.
A nostalgic indulgence which, like the cinematic equivalent of a fluffy fanzine, eschews serious criticism of a revered icon in favor of a pleasant parade of his most memorable classics.
A tough love remedy for internet addiction designed for impressionable young minds which prefer virtual reality to relating in the flesh.
A campy and cheesy yet visually-captivating roller coaster ride that makes Sharknado look like Sharknado 2!
An enlightening documentary chronicling the career of the Persian Picasso.
A thought-provoking meditation on mind control offering a valuable lesson about the virtue of challenging any totalitarian authority.
A 21st Century update of the beloved Shakespeare classic about a pair of star-crossed lovers from the opposite side of the tracks.
A cautionary tale depicting a shocking example of man's inhumanity to (wo)man.
A poignant portrait of a life precipitously hanging in the balance which pushes all the right buttons to open the emotional floodgates.

While the film fails to break any new ground in terms of the splatterflick genre, it's still entertaining enough to recommend, provided you have a strong stomach for vivisection and Italian stereotypes
Have Wilson, Galifianakis and Poehler ever been better? Gosh, I certainly hope so.
Vintage Brosnan!
Bless me father for I have slain!
If you've ever wondered whether the cancer industry is truly interested in developing a cure for the disease, you might want to check out this eye-opening expose.
A harrowing tale of survival revolving around an endearing heroine every bit as brainy as she is resourceful.
A difficult to decipher whodunit guaranteed to have you still scratching your head even after its confounding resolution.
movie_title: The Strange Color of Your Body's Tears (2014)

movie_review_blurb: Who knew that hara-kiri was such a hilarious subject?
To paraphrase a Presley classic: Wise men say, only fools rush in to see a one-trick pony revolving around an annoying Elvis look-a-like.
A frustrating tease of a tribute that seems to merely scratch the surface of an overprotected child of privilege-turned-irrepressible bon vivant.
A moving biopic about a humble underdog who surmounted overwhelming odds with the help of family, friends and a strong faith.
Pearls of wisdom from the mouths of babes uttered with such heartfelt conviction that you want to believe them, even when you're a little skeptical.
A dangerous border town as no country for old men or middle-aged sisters either.
A sublime whodunit designed for cinephiles with sophisticated palates.
A terminally-depraved escapade destined to disappoint even diehard Melissa McCarthy fans.
An enchanting musical adventure amounting to the best kept cinematic secret of the summer! At least until now.
A poignant portrait of a transcendent figure for the ages with a simple message that 'Forgiveness is at the very center of Christianity.'
movie_title: Thomas Keating: A Rising Tide Of Silence (2014)

movie_review_blurb: Slavery revisited as a sick institution making for strange bedfellows.
A remarkable illustration of the human capacity to find peace through forgiveness.
A refreshingly-realistic, slice-of-life drama highlighting the plight of a teen with a hole in his soul who's understandably torn between moving on with his life and making up for lost time.
A current-day, Ken Burns PBS production every bit as moving as any of his nostalgic classics!
A heartbreaking documentary retracing the devastation visited upon Pointe a la Hache, a scenario probably being played out again and again in working-class communities all along the Gulf Coast.
movie_title: Vanishing Pearls: The Oystermen Of Pointe A La Hache (2014)

movie_review_blurb: A kitchen sink comedy more shocking than funny and strictly recommended for rabid fans of the bottom-feeding franchise.
A well-deserved, if syrupy sweet, overdue tribute to an African-American role model and trailblazer.
Africa from the perspectives of a 'Native Son' returning to his roots and of a blue-eyed sister transformed by an unexpected catalyst for spiritual growth.
Beware, the Manchurian android!
The legendary Henry Jaglom proves as masterful as ever at creating fascinating characters designed to make you both laugh and reflect.
An 18th C. tale of race and romance told in a sophisticated fashion reminiscent of the best of Jane Austen.
A timely testament to motherhood that just might make the perfect Mother's Day gift.
An unapologetic retread bordering on plagiarism that nevertheless provides the perfect, popcorn summer escape for the tyke and 'tweener demographics.
A 'Marvel'-ously entertaining franchise that miraculously just keeps on giving and giving!
There's little to recommend about this ugly descent into depravity.
An empowering reminder of a woman's body's remarkable ability to provide sustenance in abundance.
Hey, why didn't they make monster movies like this when I was a kid?
Call me bwana, but it's three times a charm for Sandler and Barrymore on this totally-silly surfin' safari!
A bittersweet tale of sibling rivalry about a couple of polar-opposites endeavoring to bury the hatchet for the sake of their rapidly-expiring dad.
X-Men, a fabled franchise that, like a fine wine, just keeps improving with age.
An unappealing, un-role model who stole millions from the rich and simply frittered it away on herself in decadent fashion.
movie_title: The Life and Crimes of Doris Payne (2014)

movie_review_blurb: The Old West re-imagined as fodder for the coarsest of gross-out fare!
movie_title: A Million Ways to Die in the West (2014)

movie_review_blurb: Just when everybody was ready to count Tom Cruise's career out for the count, not only is he back, but back again and back again and back again, ad infinitum!
movie_title: Live Die Repeat: Edge of Tomorrow (2014)

movie_review_blurb: Tatum and Hill generate chemistry aplenty in a laff-a-minute, 'bro'-mantic adventure every bit as funny as the first.
A nostalgic trip down Memory Lane designed with Baby Boomers in mind.

A gruesome, expletive-laced, battle-of-the-sexes satire of the scary movie genre featuring enough eroticized gore and titillation at every turn to hold the attention of the testosterone-fueled demographic for the duration.
A pleasant, if predictable, diversion peppered with incessant chatter on the part of the irrepressible Kevin Hart.
A steamy soap opera unfolding against the backdrop of a cautionary history lesson reminding us that in Nigeria, the more things change, the more they stay insane.

A timeless tribute to a selfless martyr who led his people to the Promised Land by holding fast to his fervent faith that their willingness to endure suffering along the way would exceed their enemies' capacity to inflict suffering.
A touching bio about a selfless, self-made billionaire who'd probably prefer to be remembered as a tireless proponent of the notion that black lives matter.
The cinematic equivalent of a nostalgic fanzine designed with die-hard devotees of gangsta' rap in mind.
A heartbreakingly-palpable exploration of a strained father-daughter relationship as well as a thorough post mortem on their loved one's untimely passing!
To paraphrase an age-old maxim, Hell hath no fury like a Helen scorned!
A vulgar but funny enough departure from the classic TV series to warrant recommending.
A bittersweet biopic belatedly paying tribute to an unsung heroine who selflessly put her life on the line in the face of unspeakable evil.
Here's a two-fisted shero prepared to prove, in convincing fashion, that a girl can grow up to be anything she wants to be. A priceless primer for impressionable tykes!
Heavens to Murgatroyd! You can't ask any more of a madcap comedy than this much hilarity!
A thought-provoking character study.
It may only be April, but here it is, the year's first, bona fide summer blockbuster!
War may be hell, but luckily, love still conquers all!
Politically-incorrect, crassploitation fare strictly for the unshockable!
They're coming to take me away, ha-ha!
A 'Dirty Half-Dozen,' tailor-made for folks who appreciate scene after scene of incessant slaughter.
A melancholy mood piece for the ages!
A riveting reminder that it still ain't smart to mess with Mother Nature!
Guy, I like what you've done with the legend!
movie_title: King Arthur: Legend Of The Sword (2017)

movie_review_blurb: A blood-curdling sequel and worthy addition to the series certain to scare the living daylights out of you!

Every skit is designed to keep the target tyke and tot audience ts in stitches, with only occasional asides for adults, like an inspired homage to Psycho's shower scene. Altogether, a delightfully-mindless diversion for the pre-teen demographic!
movie_title: Diary Of A Wimpy Kid: The Long Haul (2017)

movie_review_blurb: A tender enough tearjerker to dehydrate even this crabby curmudgeon!

Don't be surprised if this chilling expose leaves you convinced the Sungs were innocent victims of a thoroughly corrupt legal system doling out 'justice' in color-coded fashion, even when it comes to white-collar crime.
Don't miss Menemsha's latest jewel, a comical clash of outlooks, pitting a self-assured sisterhood against a bewildered, backwards brotherhood.
A riveting whodunit spoiled somewhat by a rabbit-out-of-the-hat resolution.
Whaddya expect to happen in a scary, spine-tingler with such a big hint in the title?
Pat and predictable, yet a sentimental enough journey to leave you weepy in spite of yourself.
Live by the perm, die by the perm, and go out in style.
Laughs galore in a bawdy bachelorette party gone from bad to worst!

A disarmingly-endearing homage to the Silent Film era! If you're familiar with the surreal cinematic stylings of Dominique Abel and Fiona Gordon, then you have an idea of what sort of treat's in store.
This relatively-refined remake was directed by Sofia Coppola whose effort was richly rewarded at Cannes where she became only the second woman to win Best Director in the history of the festival.
A long-overdue tribute to an unsung hero who came that close to changing the course of history.
Schumer, Hawn, Sykes and Cusack, all at the top of their game. Pound-for-pound, the funniest film to be released in theaters this year!
All you really need to know about Baby Driver is that it's the best film of the year so far, hands down.

Is Herbalife a thinly-veiled con game being run by shady snake oil salesmen, or a benign operation affording average folks a realistic shot at the increasingly-elusive American Dream? You be the judge!
A riveting reboot!
A poignant period piece about a pair of practically-saintly role models well-deserving of their iconic status in the annals of American jurisprudence.
A decidedly-dystopic, African-American answer to the relatively-sedate, suburban bildungsroman served up by Boyhood!
Kudos to Gabriel Byrne for delivering a nonpareil performance in this plausible portrait of a fading star struggling to maintain his dignity in the face of diminished dreams.
A light as a feather, feminist fantasy where flawed males meet their match during creative displays of eroticized violence.
Redmayne's enviable acting range makes Newt Scamander a far more engaging and emotionally- accessible character than Harry Potter ever was. Heavens to Hogwarts!
movie_title: Fantastic Beasts and Where to Find Them (2016)

movie_review_blurb: A haunting deconstruction, worthy of Hitchcock, of a vulnerable socialite's very fragile psyche.

Although the picture is ostensibly aimed at the Christian demographic, it has a complicated enough storyline, including a love triangle and intriguing plot twists, to appeal to more than merely Bible-thumping Evangelicals.
Confirmation that opposites do, in fact, attract, even shrinks dispensing diametrically-opposed dating advice!
If you only see one movie this year, you need to get out more. That being said, this endlessly enchanting, panoramic homage to the Hollywood musical is the picture to catch!
Refreshing familiar roles which are obviously second nature to them, Denzel and Viola deliver emotionally-provocative performances likely to garner Academy Award nominations in Oscar season.
A searing indictment of the criminal justice system as a shameful vestige of chattel slavery.
An emotionally-engaging tale of redemption certain to garner its share of accolades over the course of the awards season.

A worthwhile, teachable moment about the indignities suffered by three heroic NASA mathematicians simply because they had the misfortune to be black during the South's shameful days of Jim Crow segregation.
A headscratcher apt to keep you guessing whether what you're watching is real or simply staged... Overall, mildly amusing, but nothing to write home about.
A visually-enchanting, if fateful, fairy tale.
A tribute befitting Boston, readily comparable to Woody Allen's bittersweet homage to his own beloved Manhattan. Appreciate Damien Chazelle now and avoid the rush!
movie_title: Guy and Madeline on a Park Bench (2010)

movie_review_blurb: A thought-provoking, historical drama chronicling the ultimate test of faith.
A bittersweet variation on the 'I was lost, but now I'm found' theme of the parable of the Prodigal Son.
Anything is possible, with cartoon physics on your side!
Though there isn't much of a message to glean from this inappropriately-titled homage to the dawn of female empowerment, one can easily appreciate its vivid triptych of poignant personal portraits.
Given the precarious state of race relations, the late visionary's prescient insights perhaps prove more timely, posthumously, than in their own day.
A mix of mirth and mayhem so mesmerizing, it's easy to forget you're watching LEGO figures. More fun than a barrel of monkeys, not that anybody still gets a kick out of watching primates at play.
A twisted Wick continues to burn bright!

A relentlessly-profane romp which might have set a record for the use of the F-word. Since the closing tableau sets up the sequel, might I suggest that the next installment cut down on the curses in favor of more jokes.
Let's say, 'Loving,' African style!
A deja vu-driven, surrealistic morality play designed to leave you deep in reflection and weeping as you walk up the aisle.
A riveting retrospective revisiting an array of Barack Obama's defining moments!
movie_title: The Obama Years: The Power of Words (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Reminiscent of being forced by your proud, if tipsy, aunt to watch a shaking-camera home movie of a cousin's poorly-recorded school play or chorus recital.
Peripatetic bus driver personifies poetry in motion!
A moving portrait of an unorthodox war hero who contributed considerably to the effort without ever wielding a weapon against the enemy.
90 minutes straight of the sort of overstimulation kids of the Attention-Deficit Generation crave!
Between the sophisticated storytelling and the state-of-the-art special f/x, War for the Planet of the Apes turns out to be a touching swan song well worth the wait.
movie_title: War for the Planet of the Apes (2017)

movie_review_blurb: very patriot owes a debt of gratitude to 'Chappy' Roberts for such a searing, cinematic memoir illustrating the unfortunate paradox that the road back from war is often far longer than the one there.
The Nativity revisited as a kiddie cartoon adventure guaranteed to enthrall tykes of any race, color or creed.
An amusing idea that runs out of steam not long after the premise is established.
How did Nina Simone put it? 'Mississippi Goddam!'
Look for Frances McDormand to land another Oscar nomination for a superb performance where she convincingly conveys the profound distress of a grief-stricken mother desperate for answers.
Merry Capitalism!
A cinematic disaster that makes The Room look like Citizen Kane. Fuhgeddaboudit!
A fantastic, female-centric, instant classic reminiscent of both Juno (2007) and Bridesmaids (2011).
Oxymoronic, Oscar-quality acting that's simultaneously godawful!
Luckily, some cliches die hard!
Gary Oldman might finally win the Oscar that has long eluded him for his sterling portrayal of the British Bulldog.
A sobering expose' issuing a dire warning about the whole damn nation's being on the brink of ecological collapse!
While the movie is certainly worth seeing, it's nevertheless a disappointment, given the cast and crew's impressive pedigree.
Denzel Washington is quite convincing as well as moving, here, as a beleaguered soul afflicted with Asperberger's syndrome.
Not just a fake biopic, a totally fake biopic!
A fitting tribute to a rare talent who dedicated her life to the liberation of oppressed people all over the world.
Even for a former, world-class athlete, crime does not pay!
A must-see expose' suggesting justice ain't blind, but rather inclined to dispense a color-coded brand of justice when it comes to child support.
This seminal offering in the gay drama genre features remarkable performances by Michael Stuhlbarg, Armie Hammer and Timothee Chalamet, who also plays the love interest in Lady Bird.
Certainly sufficiently engaging and visually-captivating to recommend for open-minded fans of the supernatural.
A shaky, Bollywood-style musical worth a watch just to see Oscar-winner Brie Larson give it her all.
An unremarkable 'fly on the wall,' or should I say, 'roach on the wall' documentary strictly for political junkies and Obama fans who might miss the man.
An old school religious epic harking back to Cecil B. Demille, replete with mob scenes and breathtaking panoramas.
Simply 'Marvel'-ous!
An anxiety-inducing meditation on of the loss of a child.
There's never a dull moment, though never a deep one either, for the duration of this hyperbolic homage to incessant overstimulation.
A touching travelogue with just enough heartfelt moments combined with comic relief to warrant this critic's stamp of approval.
An overblown, intergalactic saga certain to tug on your heartstrings during unapologetically-sentimental breaks in the action .

Reminiscent of such John Wayne classics as The Longest Day (1962) and Sands of Iwo Jima (1949), this unapologetically patriotic war flick is a crowd-pleaser most likely to resonate with the flag-waving 'God, mom and apple pie' demographic.
Though Casey is earnest in his attempt to convey a range of emotions from under the sheet, ultimately, it's the cinematic equivalent of watching a little kid try to fight his way out of a paper bag.
An Agatha Christie classic whodunit solved the old-fashioned way... by the extraordinary deductive reasoning of the legendary Hercule Poirot!
A bittersweet tribute to a man of great faith who always opted to follow humbly in the footsteps of his Lord and Savior Jesus Christ.
I saw the film in a theater full of sisters who laughed so loudly that I must have missed half the picture's punchlines.
All I can say after watching it is, 'Wow!'
movie_title: Valerian and the City of a Thousand Planets (2017)

movie_review_blurb: An inspirational tribute to Britain's Greatest Generation that just might be Chris Nolan's best picture yet!
A poignant character portrait capable of catapulting Kyle Mooney from SNL support player to bona fide matinee idol!
Riveting revisionist history setting the record straight in a way which will undoubtedly resonate with the Black Lives Matter Movement.
A moving concert flick that'll make you laugh while bringing a tear to your eye in appreciation of our soldiers' selfless sacrifices.
It's Halle vs. hillbillies in a high-octane showdown where there's never a doubt about whether 'Mommy Driver' will prevail.
The best sci-fi Western since Cowboys & Aliens!
See if they'll sell you a discount ticket for half-price, since you'll never bother to sit back during this edge-of-your-seat thriller."
A timely morality play, indeed, given the dire apocalyptic threats currently being traded between the unhinged leaders of America and North Korea.
movie_title: In This Corner of the World (Kono sekai no katasumi ni) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: An eye-popping, stunt flick chock full of implausible fight and chase scenes orchestrated in accordance with the laws of cartoon physics!
A soulful cinematic sermon elevating a sinner to sainthood for the sake of an uncritical Amen choir still in denial about the truth of the Mike Brown case!

A sobering indictment of the legal system that'll leave you wondering how many other Colin Warners might be incarcerated by a heartless prison-industrial complex routinely doling out a color-coded brand of criminal justice.
A righteous bloodbath in the boardroom!
I can't pass a sewer anymore without half-expecting Pennywise's frightening face to appear!
An overdue tribute to a selfless hero who put into action his heartfelt belief that we are all here to care for one another. A must see documentary guaranteed to leave you in tears!
A lighthearted look at the pursuit of the elusive American Dream from the perspective of a lovesick expat from the Subcontinent.
An alternately high-octane, hilarious and heartwarming cinematic treat that's hard to beat!
A visually-captivating, higher-octane sequel that ups the ante in terms of everything from star power to fight scenes to eye-popping special f/x!
A very moving tale of redemption which not only reveals God's grace but makes a case for cross-cultural tolerance that's sorely-needed in these divided times.
A cautionary tale warning about the folly of trying to keep up with Joneses, especially where the Joneses are all members of America's wealthiest 1%.
A riveting disaster flick and a steamy bodice ripper rolled into one!
Thanks to these more enlightened, LBGTQ-embracing times, William Moulton Marston can finally be fully appreciated, polygynous relationship and all.
Thurgood at 32, but once removed, as channeled by a nerdy mercenary.
Kudos to Cruise, a proven master at consistently cranking out satisfying cinematic fare certain to keep you glued to the edge of your seat.
A novel adventure offering a plausible look at the internal angst of a female weighing whether or not she's meant to be a nun.
A powerful parable of Biblical proportions, illustrating both man's inhumanity to man, as well as his capacity to forgive, if not necessarily to forget.
A sobering account of our wounded warriors' tragic misfortunes.
Finally, a relatively-sophisticated, female-centric comedy revolving around romance rather than raunch. What a refreshing treat!
A passable, nostalgic period piece which does a far better job of recreating Cold War ambience than intrigue.
Easily, the most accessible, engaging, entertaining and cinematic adaptation of a Dan Brown thriller yet!
A bittersweet tale of undying love marking the directorial debut of actor Drew Waters (Parkland).
The best adaptation of a classic play into ghetto fabulous fare since the inspired reinterpretation of Romeo and Juliet as Romeo Must Die (2000).
Michael Caine and Harvey Keitel excel as BFFs in this surrealistic meditation on mortality.
A warts-and-all biopic which reveals Mother Teresa as a tortured soul who felt abandoned by the same God she served so selflessly.
Tom Hardy's performances as two-fisted, twin gangsters elevates a Sixties mob saga that will never be confused with The Godfather.
Dry, if painstakingly-detailed, account of how four of the proverbial smartest guys in the room accurately predicted the global financial collapse of 2008.
Redmayne would be the favorite to win another Academy Award for his seamless metamorphosis into a woman, if he hadn't just netted an Oscar a year ago.

Make no mistake, Concussion is a marvelous Will Smith vehicle, one that he'll undoubtedly get to drive for the duration of awards season, possibility all the way to the Oscars on Sunday, February 28th.
A relentlessly-gruesome, gritty and grim adventure reminiscent of how the West was won.
Disposable, dopey humor designed to make you laugh out loud in the theater but to leave no lasting effect once the closing credits have rolled.
A thrilling outer space epic breathing new life into a once flagging franchise!
movie_title: Star Wars: Episode VII - The Force Awakens (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Yet another progressive political primer from a proven master at questioning authority!
A timely reminder of our First Amendment rights which which simultaneously settles the score in favor of a disgraced Freedom of Speech proponent.
A blackface variation of Babe (1995) with street cred!
Jake Gyllenhaal floating like a butterfly and stinging like a bee in an Oscar-quality performance!
An earnest examination of the loss of innocence this critic might have appreciated even more if the subject-matter hadn't be so relentlessly dark and disturbing.
A visually-captivating and remarkably-moving recreation of what, to this day, remains the most daring Coast Guard rescue on record.
America redefined as a civilization in sharp decline and on the verge of collapse because of the very greedy's systematic elimination of class mobility from the society.
Kid-friendly fare amusing enough to entertain adults, too, provided their brains are on pause!
A descent into depravity far more shocking than funny that's morally-objectionable in part for all.
An eerily-unsettling examination of pedophilia from the perspective of the perpetrators.
A relentlessly-hilarious cross of Kick-Ass (2013) and Watchmen (2009) that leaves your appetite whetted for a sequel.
A poignant character study which sensitively portrays the toll exacted by Alzheimer's not only on a victim, but on her caregivers and loved ones, as well.
movie_title: Una Vida: A Fable Of Music And The Mind (2016)

movie_review_blurb: An utterly unfiltered salute to the Age of Indiscretion.
A survival saga reminiscent of the The Revenant, except with demonic forces added to the frontier endurance test.
A visually-captivating Biblical drama harking back to such faith-based classics as Ben Hur (1959) and The Greatest Story Ever Told (1965).
A very inspiring, long overdue tribute to a great patriot and African-American icon.
A sentimental tearjerker which manages to make you weep, even though you see the manipulation coming a mile away.
An alternately visceral and cerebral, high body-count crime thriller not to be missed!
An unconvincing melodrama indicting money's power to manipulate as the root of all evil.
A cautionary expose capturing the ugly fallout of an unavoidable clash of modern and medieval civilizations.
movie_title: They Will Have to Kill Us First (2016)

movie_review_blurb: 'Rocky' and the next Roman numeral might not be in the title, but this engaging and faithful seventh episode includes all the fixins for a highly-recommended spin-off of the storied franchise.
A poignant period piece which serves as a telling reminder of how far we've come from the days when homosexuality was still considered a crime of moral turpitude
A delightful summer sleeper not to be missed!
An uplifting testament to the notion that it's still possible for a sinner to find his true calling and turn his life around after first paying his debt to society.
A harrowing heart-pounder that delivers even more excitement per-minute than is suggested by its very compelling trailer!
A prayer-ordained, Prodigal husband parable preaching primarily to the choir!
