The Black Panthers revisited less as a political party concerned about the welfare of the people than as an internecine power struggle between a couple of larger than life egos.
movie_title: The Black Panthers: Vanguard Of The Revolution (2015)

movie_review_blurb: A delightful documentary exploring whether a thoroughly-American, 29 year-old bachelor of East Indian extraction can turn on a dime and agree to an arranged marriage when it's time to settle down?
A textbook primer on how a united community ought to respond to the arrival of racist bullies before the creeps have a chance to ruin the neighborhood.
A goner granted a miraculous reprieve by God ostensibly to let us all know that paradise really exists.
Johnny Depp is at the top of his game, here, as Whitey Bulger, a very intimidating, larger-than-life monster without a functioning conscience.

The cinematic equivalent of a canary in the coal mine which issues a dire warning to the government to get SWAT teams under control before either the people revolt or the U.S. turns into a Fascistic police state.
A riveting, psychological thriller recounting a nationally-known standoff, but from the fresh perspective of the two troubled souls barricaded in a home surrounded by a SWAT team.
A mysterious mindbender about a deceptively-serene sanctuary with a chilling hidden agenda.
A genre-blending adventure which somehow successfully combines elements of the coming-of-age and last hurrah formulas.
A touching historical drama featuring an elegantly understated performance by Saoirse Ronan likely to land the 21 year-old ingenue her second Oscar nomination
Easily, the best film of 2015 thus far!
The movie's message, if any? If you're a successful rap star, you might want to think twice before returning to the ghetto to track down the deadbeat dad you never knew. .
Think Robinson Crusoe on Mars, though sans any primitive manservant named Friday.
A family-friendly romp providing just the perfect blend of light-hearted humor and spine-tingling fright fare to scare and delight kids of all ages!
A riveting tour de force featuring a pair of powerful performances by co-stars Brie Larson and Jacob Tremblay.
A heart-stopping spectacular!
The domestic War on Terror uncovered as an overzealous violation of Muslims' Constitutional rights.
A squirm in your seat saga serving up castration as a eunuch experience!
A light-hearted primer in how to mount a smear campaign and thereby manipulate a banana republic to vote against its own self-interest.
An iconoclastic drama that makes a convincing argument in support of the incendiary axiom, 'The closer to Church, the further from God.'
A poignant reminder of just how far women have come over the past century.
A multi-layered mystery where just about everybody but the butler proves to be a prime suspect.

While it's no surprise that Jennifer Connelly and Anthony Mackie might turn in powerful performances, a salute is also in order for Paul Bettany for making such an impressive and audacious directorial debut!
An uplifting testament to an old-fashioned, real-life hero that time forgot.
A special f/x-driven prequel very loosely based on the J.M. Barrie offering a riveting roller coaster ride well-designed to enthrall tykes for two hours straight.
Brace yourself for the specter of self-righteous Madea serving up street justice to clowns, collegiates, ghosts and goblins!
movie_title: Tyler Perry's Boo! A Madea Halloween (2016)

movie_review_blurb: An adrenaline-fueled thriller that follows the 'Bigger Is Better' Golden Rule for sequels.
A plausible, cinematic parable presuming to fill in gaps in the Biblical narrative of the Lord's early life.
A thoroughly enjoyable screamfest reminding us that it's still not safe to swim in the ocean.
An overdue history lesson about an important chapter in America's long march to freedom.
Aaaaaaaargh... Aaaaaaaaarghaaaah... Aaaaaaaaaaaargh!
Expect sweaty palms as the pressure mounts, since your apprehension skyrockets when watching monsters who'd murder at the drop of a hat.
An alternately penetrating and poignant portrait of a true trailblazer!
movie_title: Norman Lear: Just Another Version of You (2016)

movie_review_blurb: A laff-a-minute, female empowerment fantasy far funnier than the original.
Proof positive it's still possible to mount a decent B-horror flick on a very modest budget.
A moving collection of poignant personal portraits powerfully illustrating the utter indomitability of the human spirit.
A flagging franchise thoroughly revived courtesy of another inspired collaboration by Messrs. Damon and Greengrass!
A cautionary tale bemoaning the chilling effect of political correctness on free speech.

Most reminiscent of a couple of other equally-outrageous animated adventures, namely Team America (2004) and South Park (1997), this is a take no prisoners comedy which will undoubtedly resonate with fans of such politically-incorrect shock-fare.
Although the movie doesn't really break any new ground in terms of romantic, overcoming-the-odds sports flicks, it remains recommended as Evangelical fare that's more entertaining than heavy-handed.
A very entertaining variation on the original that's well-worth the investment.
I must confess that it held me in its thrall from start to finish purely on the strength of the over-stimulation of its incessant visual capture.
A poignant coming-of-age tale which resonates as realistic from its heartbreaking beginning clear through to a satisfying resolution.
A touching, revisionist tale of redemption presenting the sensitive side of a pulverizing pugilist.
Though he's certainly no Chris Tucker, Johnny Knoxville does prove a decent enough accomplice for Jackie Chan's endearing combination of antics and acrobatics.
A tentative tale of woe every bit as bleak as it is hopeful that there's an exit at the other end of a disturbingly dystopic tunnel.

Kudos to the team of Clint Eastwood and Tom Hanks for successfully conveying the enviable amalgam of guts, smarts and stoicism exhibited by level-headed Captain Sullenberger in the face of impending demise.
A Scandinavian splattefest staining the snow-capped mountainsides of an otherwise-breathtaking Norwegian wonderland!
Overall, a mildly-recommended period piece, provided you're prepared to take seriously the same Eddie Murphy who kept you in stitches as Buckwheat in that hilarious Saturday Night Live skit. Otay?
Congrats to Oliver Stone for crafting a reverential biopic which convincingly repositions a supposed traitor as an altruistic hero of the highest order.
The Wild, Wild West revisited as an ethnically-diverse fantasy land Hollywood has never imagined before!
A harrowing tale of survival topped off by justice being duly served. What more could you ask for from an action-oriented morality play?
An emotionally-unsettling alternate version of a controversial chapter in America's slave legacy!
A poignant portrait of a sex abuse survivor's unlikely path from abandoned street urchin to consummate poet laureate!
movie_title: Maya Angelou: And Still I Rise (2016)

movie_review_blurb: A clever and compelling, multi-layered masterpiece deserving serious consideration come awards season!
Effectively delivers a timely message that if we can all laugh together, then we can all live together, too!
This plausible account of the blossoming of love between Barack and Michelle serves up a pleasant, if sanitized version of their romantic launch en route to an historic rendezvous with destiny!
It's too bad that Taylor Ri'chard lifted so many ideas from The Blair Witch Project, otherwise I'd probably be lauding his efforts as a decent directorial debut.
A riveting retrospective plumbing the depths of the brilliant mind of a bona fide Renaissance man underappreciated in his own time.
movie_title: Eat That Question: Frank Zappa in His Own Words (2016)

movie_review_blurb: The ever-escalating, magical feats make great fodder for an eye-popping blockbuster, even if what's served up on screen is purely a product of cartoon physics.
Overall, this delightful ensemble dramedy is reminiscent of a couple of other great urban classics, Love Jones (1997) and The Best Man (1999). That's good company!
The Lord working in mysterious ways designed to elicit an 'Amen!' from believers in the Amen Corner.
A deeply moving reminder of man's inhumanity to man in less enlightened times.
A trendy, Millennial Generation variation on The Big Chill which gives that beloved classic a real run for its money.
A thought-provoking examination of the media's effect on Boobus Americana.
Let's face it, Christian Bale's Batman was going to be a hard act for any actor to follow.
movie_title: Batman v Superman: Dawn of Justice (2016)

movie_review_blurb: A paint-by-numbers production recommended for folks who can never get their fill of post-apocalyptic zombie fare.
Alas, an expletive and N-word laced descent into modern minstrelsy.
An improvisational cinematic portrait of a jazz giant whose prodigious cultural contributions play second fiddle to a plethora of his personal failings.
A fascinating airing of dirty laundry leading to an overdue reconciliation between a browbeaten daughter and her merciless abuser.
Kudos to Kim Conner and company for managing to make a thought-provoking, cinematic treat for African-Americans designed to simultaneously elevate, enlighten and entertain.
Third time's a charm for Ice Cube & company!
A novel enough spin on the brain switch theme to recommend, provided you're very willing to suspend disbelief and you've got a strong stomach for senseless gore.
Too bad whoever directed the promising trailer probably didn't direct the movie.
Ignore all the politically-correct, blackface haters. Singing aside, Zoe Saldana delivers a decent enough Nina Simone impersonation here to make you wonder what all the brouhaha was ever about.
A touching tale of empathy blessed by a couple of equally-endearing performances that are nothing short of inspired.
'Dough'-lightful!
That's irritainment!
An exhilarating tribute to an overachieving underdog that turned a barmaid's fanciful dream into a reality.
An underwhelming exercise in sound and fury striclty for brains on pause. .
A riveting thriller featuring classic screen chemistry coming courtesy of the eternally bankable Clooney and Roberts!
A heartwarming reminder that there but for fortune, may go you or I.
A kooky, kitchen sink comedy with lots of laughs for kids of all ages!
This touching collection of truly heartfelt remembrances paint a poignant portrait of a short-lived, idyllic oasis.
Let's just hope that Princess Shaw is able to turn the corner with the help of this uplifting biopic and Kutiman's mashups of her soulful ballads.
This episode is the 4th directed by the series' originator, Bryan Singer, whose sophisticated touch always allows an audience to enjoy a relatively-cerebral cinematic experience.
Highly recommended, provided you're in the mood for a campy, low-budget sci-fi whose cheesy special effects are more than offset by a profusion of insightful social statements.
A mellow meditation on a beautiful, little black girl beginning to bloom!
A fascinating examination of the mind, motivations and legacy of one of the 20th Century's most important, modern artists.

A timeless tribute to a selfless martyr who led his people to the Promised Land by holding fast to his fervent faith that their willingness to endure suffering along the way would exceed their enemies' capacity to inflict suffering.
movie_title: King: A Filmed Record...Montgomery to Memphis (1970)

movie_review_blurb: A neo-noir masterpiece not to be missed!
A tautly-edited, harrowing adventure that kept this critic on the edge of my seat and constantly reminding myself that 'It's only a movie.'
The only reason you root for a reunion at the end of this unromantic romp is because these two jerks really deserve each other.
A mind is a terrible thing to lose!

More insulting than the stereotyping and the horrifying horror clichés is the fact that the formulaic tale even has the nerve to end on a cliffhanger, setting us up for yet another sequel. Fool me once, shame on you. Fool me five times? I don't think so.
A lighthearted sitcom with enough slapstick and sheer silliness to generate laughs galore for the duration.
New York City as a disturbing dystopia where it's hard out there not just for a pimp, but for an African scam artist, too!
A Stockholm Syndrome saga giving new meaning to the term 'Shotgun Wedding!'
A discouraging documentary about the Chocolate City where HIV has been quietly decimating the ranks of the black community practically in the shadow of the White House.
A priceless primer on the flip side of strutting up the catwalk designed for impressionable young female minds fantasizing about becoming the next ingénue of the moment.
A riveting, immorality play establishing Ben Affleck as a director to be reckoned with.
A character-driven adoption drama blessed by compelling performances by a talented ensemble topped by Barry Pepper and Mira Sorvino.
Is this real or a Memorex mockumentary? You'll have to judge for yourself, because even this critic couldn't tell the difference.
Crime might not pay, but greed is still good!
A titillating tribute to the novel notion of strangers with benefits.
A poignant primer on making the most of a last chance at romance!
An iconoclastic expose' featuring fresh cultural slants apt to leave the average armchair economist reevaluating a lot of conventional wisdom they've taken for granted.
The scariest screen villain in a half century, since Psycho's Norman Bates, given that this inscrutable creep actually exists in real life.
Might not be Wes Craven's best film, but it's certainly his worst.

After offering medicinal, religious, monetary and recreational rationales, Cash Crop concludes that it's high time that California stop squandering tax dollars by prosecuting folks for mass-producing marijuana. Are you listening, Governator?"
A delightful yarn revolving around an age-old showdown between good and evil.
An Oscar-quality expose' laying the blame for the escalating dropout rate right at the feet of a greedy and selfish teachers' union which could care less about educating the country's kids.
Geezer G-Men gone wild!
Harry Potter-style hocus pocus only aimed at folks who came of age in the era of the Ouija board.
An emotionally-engaging film featuring folks truly moved on what many will undoubtedly mark for posterity as the day they were most proud to be an American.
Dozens of eye-popping displays of depravity not for the weak of stomach!
All that was missing was a pistol-packing granny in drag, chirrun!
A relentlessly-offensive bottom-feeder of no redeeming social value which I learned in law school is the Supreme Court's definition of obscene.
How long are you willing to watch an out-of-control locomotive barrel all over Pennsylvania while waiting for the altruistic heroes to enjoy their climactic moment? 90 minutes, I hope
A high-octane thriller that plunges you headlong on a thrill-a-minute roller coaster ride where a desperate man's conscience is your only guide.
Are you a pimp or a ho? You're either one or the other according to E. Raymond Brown.
movie_title: GhettoPhysics: Will the Real Pimps and Hos Please Stand Up! (2010)

movie_review_blurb: Sex and the City for the Millennial Generation!
The hangover must be crazy, if you catch my drift.
Mindless mayhem perfect for fans of pyrotechnics for pyrotechnics sake!
Inception-lite!
A Xmas where neverending nightmares instead of sugarplums dance in children's heads

A patently-preposterous, endlessly-elliptical mindbender that's worth the investment just to be able to say you sat through it, even if you can't follow all of its meandering machinations. It's that hip!
A tragic, true tale exposing America's ugly, two-tiered system of justice defined by the color line.
My Big Fat Jewish Wedding!
Well-enough executed by a capable cast to recommend, especially for heathens unfamiliar with the Biblical tale which ostensibly served as the source of inspiration.

A bombastic, bells-and-whistles spectacular featuring a fetching, two-fisted femme fatale and offering precisely the sort of riveting roller coaster ride that amounts to a very welcome diversion in the midst of a sizzling, summer heat wave.
Hats off to Mendoza for delivering this intimate peek at the intractable state of Third World poverty.
A well-deserved tribute to an American icon that manages to turn the nation's most-famous dirty old man into a champion of racial justice right before your very eyes. Who knew?
movie_title: Hugh Hefner: Playboy, Activist and Rebel (2010)

movie_review_blurb: If you'd like to get a load of what life is like in the slums of the Philippines, then you ought to check out this intimate peek at the intractable state of Third World poverty.
A mediocre sitcom serving up a half-baked, TV dinner. Check please!
It's still better to flameout than to fade away.
What will creatively-bankrupt Hollywood think of next?
The cinematic equivalent of a PSA shedding light on an underreported vacation risk the Mexican Board of Tourism will never mention in its beckoning commercials.
A cinematic sifting through the ashes of Mississippi smoldering!
An alternately jaw-dropping and lighthearted look at 21st Century mating habits as apt to leave you in stitches as in shock over the ever-evolving state of the human relating.
From 'Shots! Shots! Shots!' to 'Hot! Hot! Hot!'
About the best you can expect from a 21st Century Cinderella with a book deal who had probably already optioned the rights to turn her story into a Hollywood bio-pic.
Never underestimate the nostalgia factor!"
A ROFL treasure hunt which unfolds like an inner-city variation of It's a Mad, Mad, Mad, Mad World. What more can you ask for from a ghetto-fabulous, escapist fantasy?

Bravo to Rehana Mizra for making such an impressive writing and directorial debut here, crafting a poignant, character-driven drama bravely tackling a taboo subject in such an absorbing, entertaining and ultimately satisfying fashion.
A fascinating character study serving up as sharp a contrast in leading ladies as you're ever likely to encounter onscreen.

You know you're watching a groundbreaking documentary when it not only forces you out of your comfort zone but also manages to persuade you to reassess your point-of-view without resorting to potentially-alienating polemic.

Credit Carolyn Battle Cochrane for having the guts to pose the tough questions to elicit the heartfelt, sobering reflections from members of a momentarily marginalized group collectively poised to emerge as the face of 21st Century America.
A moving morality play about the steep price guilt is capable of exacting on a tortured soul consumed with overwhelming regret.
A walkout-bad, 'bait and switch' rip-off bearing less resemblance to Juno or Little Miss Sunshine than to terrible TV sitcoms revolving around the shopworn 'one big lie' plot device.
Hell hath no fury like a school of hungry, teen-eating piranhas!

An evocative character study painting a grim, if visually-captivating, portrait of a tormented soul suffering in silence while delivering a powerful message about the consequences of rape radiating across generations like ripples on a pond.
movie_title: The Milk of Sorrow (La Teta Asustada) (2010)

movie_review_blurb: Ferrell at his funniest!
Given the escalation of the host of woes afflicting the black community over the intervening years, that makes this memento of more optimistic times all the more priceless.
A water-treading sequel with no emotional momentum ostensibly serving as a setup for next summer's grand finale
movie_title: Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows - Part 1 (2010)

movie_review_blurb: A Prodigal Panther pays the price to make peace with a turbulent past.
Worth its while for the next generation special f/x alone, especially when witnessed in 3D.
An authentic tale of survival offering insight, hope and wings!
Have you ever noticed how few African-American Republicans there are? That fundamental question rests at the heart of this eye-opening expose' offering a variety of intriguing answers.
Have you ever noticed how few African-American Republicans there are? That fundamental question rests at the heart of this eye-opening expose' offering a variety of intriguing answers.
A worthy sequel certain to scare the bejesus out of Scream franchise fans with a strong stomach for gratuitous gore.
Melodramatic tough love as meaningful group therapy!
Another dazzling display of stunt driving and death-defying car chases involving souped-up, stolen automobiles.
Not merely an entertaining enough intro to Thor, but a roots adventure cleverly laying the groundwork for what's in store from The Avengers and other planned extensions of the Marvel franchise.
The African-American answer to 'Meet the Parents!'
An incendiary expose' illustrating how agribusiness has successfully exploited our biological urges for generations, often with the help of government-sponsored propaganda
Advance token to Boardwalk!
movie_title: Under The Boardwalk: The Monopoly Story (2011)

movie_review_blurb: A fitting tribute to a true American icon, a half century after she subtly helped shape the course of history while leaving an indelible mark on the country's conscience.
movie_title: Hey, Boo: Harper Lee and 'To Kill a Mockingbird' (2011)

movie_review_blurb: An estrogen-fueled adventure featuring madcap hilarity ranging from the scatological to the sublime!
An ill-advised remake of the 1981 classic romantic comedy co-starring Dudley Moore and Liza Minelli
An emotionally-evocative poetry slam blasting the King's English to smithereens leaving Ebonics as the last language standing!
Triggers fewer belly laughs-per-minute than the original, yet nevertheless generates more than enough yucks to satisfy fans of the gross-out genre.
Takes an amusing look at the state of black-on-black romance in the 21st Century.

Congrats to rookie Reid for crafting such an endlessly-amusing screenplay, for finding the right cast to execute that vision, and for the rest of just the right ingredients to serve a satisfying, cinematic stew.
Proof positive that hermaphrodites are people deserving of Hollywood endings, too!.
What's next? How about a flick where the D-Day assault on the beach at Normandy is led by the Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles.
Can I get an Amen?
J.J.'s Close Encounter with E.T., Gremlins, Jaws and Jurassic Goonies!
Jim Carrey's silliest animal vehicle since Ace Ventura!

Fortunately, Ryan Reynolds' combination of suave self-assuredness, seasoned comic timing and old-fashioned ability to kick butt outweigh the film's minor flaws to make for a satisfying cinematic experience that just screams sequel.
The un-Tarzan!
A captivating primer on tripping the light fantastic with your arms pinned to your sides!

Provided you're in the mood for salacious fare, this titillating teensploit does deliver the requisite number of raunchy rib ticklers to be worth the investment for the testosterone-driven demographic.
Mindless escapist fare designed with the attention-deficit millennials in mind.
A battle-of-the-sexes farce where vindictive females force their unsuspecting prey to be friends with benefits, whether they want some or not!
What do you get when you let Danny Boyle put his spin on a fact-based cross of Cast Away and Into the Wild? An exhilarating episode of 'Who Wants to Be a Slumdog Mountaineer?'

Mixing memorable elements of everything from Memento to Avatar to The Twilight Zone to The Manchurian Candidate, this thought-provoking mindbender even pays homage to Ronald 'Where's the rest of me?' Reagan in King's Row.
'Elektra'-fying!
An intriguing mindbender certainly deserving of all the attention it is apt to earn over the course of awards season, with Natalie Portman certainly a shoo-in for an Oscar Award nomination.

A revisionist history bio-pic, reminiscent of Charlie Wilson's War, which recasts an arrogant influence-peddler behaving like he's above the law as merely a bad-boy bon vivant with the best of intentions.
Zany and hilarious, yet simultaneously touching and thought-provoking, Sophie serves up revenge as a thoroughly-satisfying cinematic dish not to be missed.
A fitting tribute to a real-life Rocky and Adrian featuring a quartet of inspired performances by Mark Wahlberg, Christian Bale, Melissa Leo and Amy Adams.
Jeff Bridges must be commended for his fresh interpretation of the roguish Rooster Cogburn.
A lackluster effort and a preposterous plot which add up to a flagging franchise that just 'jumped the shark.'

At its best when highlighting the delightful badinage between Colin Firth as the recently-crowned King George VI and Geoffrey Rush as his not so humble servant, a charming rogue if there ever was one.
A fond tribute to a troubled, traveling troubadour!
movie_title: Phil Ochs: There But For Fortune (2011)

movie_review_blurb: A mediocre sitcom serving up a half-baked, TV dinner. Check please!
A plausible portrait of what transpires when bad things happen to good people without faith in God or a lucky rabbit's foot.
An alternately earthy and stylized cross of Robert Altman and Federico Fellini where the freaks trump the tramps as the main attraction.
The un-Rush Hour!
Good girl goes bad, and then some!
movie_title: Gabi on the Roof in July (2011)

movie_review_blurb: Wimps still rule in this upside-down universe where it's cool to be square!
movie_title: Diary of a Wimpy Kid 2: Rodrick Rules (2011)

movie_review_blurb: Mindless mayhem perfect for fans of pyrotechnics for pyrotechnics sake!
Bruce Lee lives! (Or at least his mentor does.)
movie_title: Ip Man 2: Legend of the Grandmaster (2011)

movie_review_blurb: A poignant, cinematic memoir of growing up Muslim in America from the perspective of an anguished soul who just wanted to enjoy a normal childhood.
A depressing deconstruction of a marriage that clearly was never meant to be.
A suspense thriller sans the element of suspense is apt to disappoint even an audience arriving with low expectations.
An eye-opening, cautionary tale unveiling a diabolical corporate conspiracy to turn healthy people into patients by medicalizing everyday aspects of the human condition.
A sobering documentary which makes a convincing case that climate change is a national security issue.
Just run from it!
The most sexplicit romp you'll encounter in theaters this year, guaranteed!
What's funnier than a black dude in drag? How about two black dudes in drag?
movie_title: Big Mommas: Like Father, Like Son (2011)

movie_review_blurb: A modern morality play offering a satisfying reminder about the real meaning of forgiveness.
A bawdy, shock comedy laced with coarse dialogue, full-frontal nudity, sophomoric slapstick and bodily-function fare. The tried and true Farrelly Brothers formula, if that's your taste!
An entertaining, if blasphemous mindbender suggesting that love conquers all, even the will of God.

Congrats to Salli Richardson-Whitfield for delivering a career performance, here, and to Ava DuVernay for shooting such a thought-provoking meditation on mortality in just a couple of weeks and on a micro budget.
A vulgar exercise in depravity radiating such bad karma that you'll need to take a cleansing shower right after watching it
Oedipus wrecks!
What's next, a full-length documentary about the life and times of Chris 'Leave Britney Alone' Crocker?
A compelling enough sequel certain to enthrall the target demographic apt to agree that it's a big improvement over Twilight 2, though not nearly as enchanting as the original.
Ultimately uplifting, this endearing bio-pic offers a wonderful warts-and-all look from the inside out at both the blessings and challenges of trans-cultural adoption.
A melodramatic morality play which sends the sobering message that suicide bombing does not pay, especially when you could just as easily seduce as splatter the sexy object of your detonation.
movie_title: For My Father (Sof Shavua B'Tel Aviv) (2010)

movie_review_blurb: A high-octane, high body-count thriller posing the question, how do you stop a psycho vigilante on a killing spree? Apparently, by any means necessary."
A cross of The Lovely Bones and No Way Out, only in Bostonese!

Well-enough executed for a flick on a modest budget to forgive the tendency towards melodrama. With a tenderhearted payoff arriving when the Prodigal Daughter asks her father for forgiveness during a teachable moment of mutual redemption.

A brilliant examination of Chinese culture and cuisine which subtly uncovers a telling microcosm of the myriad contradictions that the communist nation has manifested en route to its embrace of elements of capitalism.
movie_title: The Biggest Chinese Restaurant in the World (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Is this sequel bad? Not by a long shot. Just disappointing, if you're expecting it to measure up to the original.
A splatter flick featurng an almost infantile Ugly American in Paris with access to an infinite supply of live ammo, and misbehaving like the proverbial bull in a china closet.

An alternately entertaining and thought-provoking, irreverent romp so unpredictable and engaging that you quickly forget the low production values as you become immersed in the plight of the members of the motley ensemble.
Paints an empathetic picture of a passionate Palestinian apologist as a loony loudmouth whose rants deserve respect if only because virtually all of his relatives were exterminated in the Holocaust.
movie_title: American Radical: The Trials of Norman Finkelstein (2010)

movie_review_blurb: Unoriginal sitcom squanders bounty of A-List stars.
Riveting historical drama revisits infamous Civil Rights case.
A chilling, cautionary expose' of Orwellian dimensions.
A syrupy saga which somehow proves moving, in spite of a fairly formulaic, Hollywood approach to a truly inspiring, real-life triumph.
Good guy finishes last and makes mediocre movie.
How do you say Tawana Brawley en Francais?
movie_title: The Girl on the Train (La Fille du RER) (2010)

movie_review_blurb: The cinematic equivalent of a bait and switch scam.
Hell hath no fury like a sister scorned, especially for a wigger!
A moving bio-pic about an unsung hero with a winning education formula which ought to be replicated in inner cities all across the country.

An anachronistic rip-off which implies that the idea of male beauty pageants originated with African-Americans in the 1930s, instead of with Zulus in the 1990s. Is the film otherwise worthwhile? Yes, but it still weirded me out.
Silent Bob strikes out!

An extraordinarily-insightful endeavor urging Evangelicals to examine their own morality in relation to Jesus' words instead of conveniently pointing fingers at folks they've long since dismissed as heathens.
movie_title: Lord Save Us From Your Followers (2010)

movie_review_blurb: A riveting thriller offering an array of history lessons and teachable moments about freedom.

All roads in this cleverly-concealed, triangulated tale serendipitously lead to some godforsaken projects in Brownsville where live ammo is routinely employed as the ghetto equivalent of a calling card.
21st Century Alice matures and enters The Matrix!
A 21st Century take on downsizing and dating in this no-strings attached age of outsourcing and friends with benefits.
No wonder they call screenwriters egomaniacs with low-self esteem.
A fairy tale strictly for anyone still in denial or naïve enough to believe in Santa Claus, the Tooth Fairy or even Saddam's mythical Weapons of Mass Destruction. It's fun to pretend!
A measured, minimalist masterpiece which is mostly a sweet homage to such rapidly disappearing Manhattan trademarks of yore as the neighborhood bar and the corner diner.
I just saved you a lot of aggravation. You owe me.
It's a wonderful life where every time you hear a whelp ring out, another angel gets his head blown off!
Yetta nudder cautionary tale issuing dire warnings about the pitfalls of technology run amuck.
A high-octane thriller that might be best described as Taken meets Speed meets Ransom... Unfortunately, the execution leaves a lot to be desired.
A charming cartoon classic coming courtesy of a successful collaboration by the good folks at Disney and Pixar.
An instant cartoon classic coming courtesy of a successful collaboration by the good folks at Disney and Pixar.
Borat hunts for neo-Nazis!
An East meets West splatterfest unfolding like a lethal cross of Crouching Tiger and Sam Peckinpah.
An antiseptic answer to Precious designed for the tweener demographic.
A review-proof adventure certain to keep its intended demographic enthralled for a couple of hours.
Street musicians prove that the world is indeed a global village!
Street musicians prove that the world is indeed a global village.

A creepy cartoon filled with inappropriate inside jokes that are mostly over the head of the desired tyke demographic, exactly what one would you expect of a claymation vehicle crafted by the cerebral Wes Anderson.
Jim Sheridan directs disappointing remake of Danish dysfunctional family saga.
The rainbow nation starts here!
A host of hoaxes far funnier than the best of Candid Camera!
Who needs The Wrestler when you have The Crooner?"
Forget dancing with wolves, howzabout doing the Funky Chicken with aliens?
A down-to-earth look at 21st Century dating habits in this no-strings age of friends with benefits.
A slow to unravel crime saga laced with the trademark super-realism we've come to appreciate from the New Wave of Romanian cinema.
Vicky Cristina Madrid!
The scary specter of all-out Holy War as a self-fulfilling prophecy.
An eye-opening expose' about a godforsaken town long past its glory days and now in need of far more than an image makeover, if it ever wants to be considered livable again.
A precursor to all those radiation fallout monster flicks of the Fifties. A telling cautionary tale worth a watch for far more than the nostalgic factor.
Ferris Bueller's Jungle Fever!
As for Michael Cera's career? Look a falling star! Make a wish!
An epic snuff flick which fails to engage the viewer on an emotional level.
Trouble in Cockneyland!
The cleverest Holocaust humor since Mel Brooks' 'Springtime for Hitler' skit in The Producers.
movie_title: Mein Führer - Die wirklich wahrste Wahrheit über Adolf Hitler (My Fuhrer) (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Despite Denzel Washington turning in a trademark, charismatic performance underscored by appropriately monochromatic cinematography, the film is still surprisingly unengaging.
A stunt-driven, Matt Damon vehicle about a relentless killing machine without a memory caught up in manic, mindless mayhem not of his own making.
An instant animated classic destined to delight kids of all ages for generations to come!
Exhibit A as to why every generation needs to be reminded about the horrors of the Holocaust afresh.
movie_title: Harlan - Im Schatten von Jud Süss (Harlan: In the Shadow of Jew Seuss) (2010)

movie_review_blurb: A great time killer for anybody who needs help being bored.
A paranoid fantasy of what's over the horizon if the macabre rumors about the Obamacare death panels are true.
A "sleazy does it" production that looks like it was improvised on the spot with a lack of conviction by a bunch of naughty 12 year-olds desperate for attention.
A fascinating and informative, must-see documentary for any serious cinephile
movie_title: Two in the Wave (Deux de la Vague) (2010)

movie_review_blurb: A dumbed-down ripoff strictly for the tyke demographic too young to notice that the flick's a thinly-veiled retread.

A 2 1/2 hour test of patience featuring four embarrassingly-entitled Ugly Americans agonizing over trivia and assorted soap opera drama that is, quite frankly, so patently superficial, you almost wish they'd be cursed with some real problems
A more cerebral means of cinematically satiating one's wanton bloodlust craving!
A psychological thriller highlighting how hell hath no fury like a frustrated knight in shining armor, even if he only has a plastic sword at his disposal!
A heartwarming bio-pic about three brilliant, young brainiacs guaranteed to restore your faith in America's future while bringing tears to your eyes.
A marvelous, multi-media mockumentary about Hitchcock certain to add to the already lofty stature of the revered cinema icon.

Worth the investment for the cinematic capture of the Southern France backdrops, as well as the badinage between Heigl and Kutcher reminiscent of those classic Doris Day-Rock Hudson exchanges in flicks like Send Me No Flowers. Send Me No Hit Men!
You'll O.D. on your own laughter!
A steamy sitcom which could have benefitted immeasurably from less carnality in favor of character development.
A bio-pic of Biblical proportions featuring a showdown of Dr. David versus a government Goliath!

An extraordinary expose' illustrating what a crying shame it is that the public schools in the inner cities have degenerated to the point that you have to rely on the luck of the draw for a decent education.
A bittersweet saga chronicling both the rough lot of the recent immigrant and the indomitability of the human spirit!
A sobering deconstruction of an enduring showbiz career by an introspective icon whose been at it non-stop since '66.
movie_title: Joan Rivers: A Piece Of Work (2010)

movie_review_blurb: A powerful, mythbusting documentary which manages to humanize America's unfairly-marginalized indigenous peoples, albeit belatedly.
Wah do dem? 'Dem a loot, dem a shoot, dem a wail!' in shanty towns as the late Desmond Dekker might say, since the harder they come, they harder they apparently still fall.
No movie for old men, or any other demographic for that matter.
A fitting finale for a Disney trilogy guaranteed to resonate with kids of any age for generations to come.
The epitome of escapist summer fare!
makes it clear that the prospect of being outnumbered 10-to-1 can turn any kid with a sense of self-preservation into a fine-tuned killing machine.
An optimistic outing of America's predatory exportation of capitalism.
Blacks serve as brunt of the jokes in insensitive buddy comedy.
How do you say, 'I am lust' in Italian?

A heartbreaking expose' which leaves no doubt that dramatic environmental changes are unfolding at every latitude, whether they be the consequences of human overconsumption of fossil fuels or merely the hand of God.

Co-directors Pierre Coffin and Chris Renaud understand exactly how to employ the latest 3-D technology in a fashion that the frenetic action keeps you ducking from and reaching out to touch objects as if you're right in the midst of a virtual reality.
A chilling expose' revealing the TSA's approach to protecting the public as little more than an elaborate, ineffective facade.
A charming romantic comedy that lets Mr. Wrong win at love for a refreshing change of pace.
Escapist summer fare doesn't come any more mindless than this!
A powerful, PTSD PSA for 'Don't ask, don't kiss and tell' advocates.
A gross indulgence in the uncertain that is less a scary, 'found tape' whodunit than a jaw-dropping shocksploit with one very weird agenda.

Juxtaposing a litany of opposing thematic elements, ranging from honor vs. disgrace to tradition vs. modernization to trust vs. duplicity, this multi-layered mystery shapes up like a modern morality play of Shakespearean proportions.

An overambitious production which, while not quite ready for primetime due to techical flaws, at least exhibits enough promise in terms of acting, plot and camera angles to make this critic curious to see Papas's next picture. Dante's Purgatory!
A literary lass finds more than she bargained for while looking for love on the Emerald Isle.
A kinky cross of Caligula and Back to the Future!
An entertaining enough diversion, though in this critic's opinion it veers sharply from the sublime to the ridiculous.
100 minutes of Hell that had me reaching for my meds.
100 minutes of Hell that had me reaching for my meds.

Too bad this flick lost the race to the theaters with Cadillac Records, otherwise director Jerry Zaks might've had a hit on his hands instead of a Johnny Come Lately destined to be forever thought of as a cheap imitation.
Love in the time of lipstick on the collar!
A high attrition, haunted house throwback certain to send chills up your spine!
movie_title: The Black Waters of Echo's Pond (2010)

movie_review_blurb: A lighthearted, low-budget remake likely to work well for those capable of approaching it more as a novelty than a knockoff.
movie_title: The Good, the Bad, the Weird (Joheun-nom, Nabbeun-nom, Isanghan-nom) (2010)

movie_review_blurb: On his riveting reality show, Bear Grylls's parachuted, paraglided, shot the rapids, climbed glaciers and dined on everything from snakes to elephant dung to his own urine to survive. Jaw-dropping survivalist fare which speaks for itself!
Worthwhile not merely for the office soap opera but for its realistic revelation of unspoken social sensibilities simmering beneath the surface during the Sixties.

A chilling contrast of the sustainable and corporate approaches to agriculture which makes a persuasive argument that your daily choices matter in terms of the long-term prospects of both humanity's and the planet's survival.
The perfect date movie!

Katie Madonna Lee makes an impressive writing, acting and directorial debut with this alternately terrifying, thought-provoking and unabashedly empathetic look at life from the harrowing perspective of a never-protected female.
What will creatively-bankrupt Hollywood think of next? How about a remake of Slumdog Millionaire, only set in an L.A. barrio with an all-Chicano cast? I shouldn't give them any ideas.
The best comic book screen adaptation since The Dark Knight!
Renaissance Man Tyler Perry proving he still has his finger on the pulse via yet another, madcap, marital melodrama apt to resonate with the collective conscious of the black community.
movie_title: Why Did I Get Married Too (2010)

movie_review_blurb: Love, Long Island style!
A very moving tribute to an underappreciated hero who spent his life as a tireless defender of the defenseless.
J-Lo's worst outing since Gigli!

You know how Zoe Saldana's multiple Oscar-winning film, Avatar, has been lauded for its breathtaking, state of the art of technical wizardry? Well, don't expect to see anything like that in this under-budgeted homage to bad B-movies.
A fun-filled tribute which elevates the Golden Age of Burlesque to its rightful place in history while belatedly restoring a little dignity to its underappreciated, socially-ostracized performers.

A worthwhile walk down Memory Lane as likely to keep you in stitches as appreciating the long line of African-American geniuses who have made it their business to challenge the status quo, but always eliciting lots of laughter in the process.
movie_title: Why We Laugh: Black Comedians on Black Comedy (2009)

movie_review_blurb: A sentimental sitdram about whether or not a long-distance liaison between an artist and his worst critic has a fighting chance of blossoming into love.
Robert Downey, Jr. reprises his role as the genius, billionaire inventor with a superhero alter ego.
It doesn't get any worser than this.

An alternately frightening and exhilarating, guerilla-style documentary showcasing the downs and ups of an amoral thrill-seeker lucky enough to bottom out and find redemption before it was too late to be given a last shot at rehabilitation.
movie_title: Dirty Hands: The Art & Crimes of David Choe (2010)

movie_review_blurb: A pleasant, if predictable, period piece to be savored as much for the breathtaking seascapes as for the deliberately-paced romantic roundelays.
A particularly poignant examination of love which magically ushers the audience right into the middle of the romantic relationships of a variety of native New Yorkers.
An overindulgence in coarse language exposing profanity as the hobgoblins of small minds and unimaginative scripts.
An eye-popping, insult to the intelligence strictly for the kiddies and crackpot doomsday enthusiasts.
A fitting capstone on a fabled film franchise for the ages!
movie_title: Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows - Part 2 (2011)

movie_review_blurb: Yes, Virginia, there is not only a Santa Claus, but a Tooth Fairy, a Jack Frost, an Easter Bunny, and a Sandman, too!
A bloody free-for-all so gruesome, it makes Peckinpah look like Winnie the Pooh.
A sumptuous cinematic feast!
An intriguing cat-and-mouse caper featuring both bullets and brains. The question is how long can they keep up the 'good perp, bad perp' charade before their luck finally runs out?

A moving, must-see documentary about the demise of one of the last vestiges of segregation. Could it be more fitting that the plaintiffs in the landmark case eradicating the crime of loving a person of a different color would be named Loving!
A cinematic treat offering rare peeks behind the scenes and behind the closed doors of a legendary director and the love of his life.
A midlife crisis comedy marking the milestone with a tribute to immaturity!
A heartbreaking expose' about a rush to judgment which ruined five, innocent young lives.
A tenderhearted tale about two terribly wounded souls who survive by grudgingly leaning on each other's shoulder.
Slavery reimagined as a messy splatterfest where massa gets exactly what he deserves, and then some!
A transparent message movie which might deserve to be forgiven for moralizing and politicizing, given the urgency of the underlying environmental issue.
An edge-of-your-seat thriller not to be forgotten at Oscar time!
Agent Strangelove, or how I learned to stop worrying and love waterboarding!
A poignant portrait of Lincoln's last days, time spent as a marked man making his appointed rounds en route to his rendezvous with destiny.
Forget National Lampoon, this is the real vacation from Hell!
A delightful dramedy directed by Dustin Hoffman revolving around a couple of unexpected encores.
A compelling cross of Life of Pi and Lifeboat, a seafaring tale of survival sans the Bengal tiger and Tallulah Bankhead.

A reverential biopic that wisely leaves the damning evidence on the back burner in favor of focusing on everything about Mumia Abu-Jamal except what exactly transpired at the corner of 13th and Locust in the wee hours of December 9, 1981.
A disgusting, cinematic descent into depravity destined to leave its victims, sitting slack-jawed and speechless in stunned disbelief.
Rome might not have been built in a day, but this picture proves that a captivating, Broadway-quality musical can be mounted in 24 hours. Who knew?
Vintage Sly in his best outing since Cop Land!
A poignant tale of undying love!
The Girl with a Dragon of a Depression!
The rise and fall from grace of a good Jewish boy gone bad who ostensibly sold out the Big Apple but never summoned up the courage to come out of the closet.
A fresh take on The Great Emancipator from the point-of-view of a trusted companion who had been at the President's side at Gettysburg and for many historical moments but not on the day he died.
A viable jumpstart of yetta nudder escapist fantasy franchise.
An implausible, action adventure featuring a couple of bomb and bulletproof protagonists more resilient than Wile E. Coyote, thanks to the miracle of cartoon physics!
movie_title: A Good Day To Die Hard (2013)

movie_review_blurb: 21st Century Africa presented as a godforsaken wasteland conjuring up primitive images reminiscent of the ghoulish dystopia chronicled by Conrad in Heart of Darkness.
A high body-count showdown featuring all the staples of the genre, from flashy Zoot suits to Tommy guns to street smart dialogue mixing slang and savoir faire in a manner reminiscent of Damon Runyon.
Fee! Fi! Fo! Fum! I smell a hit with the little ones!
Crouching tiger, hidden Siegfried! (sans Roy)
Better brace yourself for the best Bond episode in ages, thanks to Daniel Craig's coming of age to make the role his own.
Ferrell and Galifianakis hit the campaign trail as the funniest candidates money can buy!
Hedonistic playboy tries Platonic relationship in offbeat romantic romp.
Ferrell and Galifianakis hit 'The Campaign' trail as the funniest candidates money can buy!
An enchanting fairytale designed for young and old alike with a satisfying payoff for anyone willing to suspend disbelief in the face of a supernatural storyline with an implausible premise.
movie_title: The Odd Life of Timothy Green (2012)

movie_review_blurb: A primer on how to make a successful sequel sans a hit franchise's title character, star or source material from the series' creator.
Delivers just enough laughs to remain recommended, despite the fact that this hard to pigeonhole head-scratcher would have benefited from making a total commitment to either comedy or a drama.
An enchanting fairytale designed for young and old alike with a satisfying payoff for anyone willing to suspend disbelief in the face of a supernatural storyline with an implausible premise.
movie_title: The Odd Life of Timothy Green (2012)

movie_review_blurb: A must-see, between Whitney's sentimental Swan Song and Carmen's coming out party.
Brother, can you spare me the aggravating agit-propaganda?
movie_title: Brother, Can You Spare a Dollar (2012)

movie_review_blurb: A Tour de Gridlock unfolding at a breakneck pace that doesn't give you a chance to pause to consider whether what you're watching is even credible.
The only thing worse than a movie without an ending, is a ninety-minute endurance test without an ending.
An over-the-top indulgence in sadism strictly recommended for folks with a stomach for gangster fare so gruesome as to border on the cartoonish.
Pollyanna does 'Frisco!
John Hawkes and Helen Hunt generate an endearing chemistry, here, turning in a couple of virtuoso performances deserving of serious consideration come Oscar season.
A visually-captivating fantasy for teenage males with raging hormones, the demographic most apt to enjoy watching an invincible vixen in spandex waste wave after wave of mindless mutants.
A mind-bending masterpiece that's a must for more cerebral fans of the time-travel genre.
In the tradition of Norma Rae and Erin Brockovich, say hello to Jamie Fitzpatrick and Nona Alberts!
A bittersweet tale of survival, as well as a priceless history lesson for the ages illustrating man's capacity for inhumanity to his fellow man.

An entertaining and uplifting star vehicle showcasing Kevin James' comic genius at its best, whether he's doing pratfalls in a mask and ill-fitting stretchy pants or futilely wooing the woman of his dreams.
A presidential-year docudrama about a Tea Party conservative's futile search for a candidate that leaves her no option but to pull the lever for Obama in November.
A transparent, bait-and-switch disappointment strictly for suckers.
A poignant portrait of an inveterate iconoclast who couldn't help but push the envelope.
movie_title: Diana Vreeland: The Eye Has To Travel (2012)

movie_review_blurb: A refreshing alternative to the superficial mainstream fare that tends to stereotype sisters as either sassy mammies or compliant sex objects.
A cleverly-concealed, centuries-spanning headscratcher constructed with fans of the original sextet of stories in mind.
A sensitive character study chronicling the considerable challenge of coming-of-age Jewish with the specter of the Third Reich lurking just over the horizon.
Janks Morton, Jr. is back with this equally thought-provoking sequel to What Black Men Think, his groundbreaking directorial debut.
An instant screen classic destined to be deemed among the very best of Zemeckis, alongside Forest Gump, Back to the Future and What Lies Beneath.
PTSD documentary provides a poignant portrait of wounded Irag and Afghan War vets as they scale Himalayan mountain.
A tyke-friendly, Halloween adventure teaching a universal message of tolerance via the oft-repeated maxim that monsters are people, too!
Picture a two-hour episode of Amos 'n' Andy on crack. Holy mackerel, Sapphire!
Everything you ever wanted to know about Hava Nagila but were afraid to ask, except:: 'What's the deal with the ritual of raising a chair in the air like you don't care?'
A 'Salt of the Earth' saga plumbing the depths of the human soul.
movie_title: De rouille et d'os (Rust and Bone) (2012)

movie_review_blurb: A cerebral screamfest certain to give you goosebumps!
A riveting reinterpretation for the Hip-Hop Generation apt to be best appreciated by fans of gangsta' rap videos weaned on shallow, hedonistic displays of misogyny and materialism.
A righteous, riveting relaunch leaving no doubt that, even after 80 years, you still don't tug on Superman's cape!
A reverential retrospective representing the first tip of the cap to backups I can remember since Lou Reed warbled 'And the colored girls go!' on the gritty ditty 'Walk on the Wild Side.'
Armageddon never looked like so much fun!
A bona fide summer blockbuster any way you slice it, with all the fixin's to assure any audience its money's worth of viewing pleasure and excitement.
A step-by-step instruction video I fear might inadvertently influence some impressionable young minds to try an ill-advised line of work that will only land them in a lot of trouble.
movie_title: How To Make Money Selling Drugs (2013)

movie_review_blurb: A very good movie about a very bad band!
You know he's still humble enough to remember where he came from when tears can be seen streaming down his face as he takes bows at Madison Square Garden.

Don't be surprised to shed a few tears as the curtain comes down on this tale of female empowerment about a pair of polar-opposite lady lawmen who set aside their differences to get their man while forging an enduring friendship worthy of a sequel.
Sure, the pat Hollywood ending is a foregone conclusion, but nobody's complaining when the roller coaster ride is so thoroughly enjoyable!
Whether Oscar Grant deserves to be remembered as a martyr or a provocateur, this poignant portrait of him as a flawed free-spirit is moving enough to be remembered come Academy Awards season.
A mesmerizing, if mindless, apocalyptic adventure that doesn't ask anything more of an audience than to enjoy the action and root heartily for the heroes while consuming a copious amount of popcorn.
A nutty kitchen sink comedy ending on a cliffhanger designed to keep diehard fans of the depraved franchise in suspense about whether yetta nudder sequel might be in the works.
A hilarious, high-octane variation of Aesop's fable about The Tortoise and the Hare!

A poignant portrait of a very eventful day in the lives of a trio of African-Americans too self-absorbed to care about the fact that Barack Obama was about to win the Presidential Election that night.
R.I.P.D. is D.O.A.!
Israel captured through the eyes of ordinary citizens as a vulnerable refuge where tragedy has become the norm, and where peace invariably leads back to war.

An admirably informative and empathetic effort clearing up common misconceptions about dyslexia, explaining that it's not a character flaw but merely a neurological issue affecting as many as one out of five individuals.
Crouching Viper, Hidden Wolverine!
An inspirational illustration of how the Olympics came to serve as a unifying step in terms of exorcising the demons ever haunting Rwanda's grisly killing fields.
A remarkably unengaging adventure, given its incessant attempt at overstimulation.
Picture Cheech & Chong on a National Lampoon Vacation!
An alternately informative and hilarious documentary featuring reflections about the roots of the comedy icons who got their start in the Borscht Belt.
Kudos to Lee Daniels for crafting such a gut-wrenching tour de force which never hits a false note while chronicling critical moments in the African-American fight for equality.
An underwhelming, sci-fi adventure more akin to After Earth than District 9.
Why Occupy Wall Street when you can occupy the desert?
You almost need a score card to keep track of all the coupling, uncoupling, and re-coupling, but the out-of-the-closet antics are amusing enough to intrigue.
The most spine-tingling exorcist flick since, well, since The Exorcist!
Even though this overambitious mockumentary misses the mark, first-time writer/director Wendy Jo Cohen exhibits sufficient potential to make me curious about her next venture.
movie_title: The Battle of Pussy Willow Creek (2013)

movie_review_blurb: Between a host of memorable performances by a cast of relative newcomers, and a haunting, grungy score, this coming-of-age comedy is a bona fide sleeper not to be missed.
A fascinating character study of an arrogant, cold-hearted, self-hating Jew who had the nerve to blame 6,000,000 of her own people for their extermination in concentration camps.

Though the wheels gradually come off the increasingly-preposterous production, all is forgiven on account of the convoluted adventure's compelling storyline, arresting special f/x, and satisfying, if farfetched resolution.
A battle of competing comedy styles won hands-down by the rambunctious, rubber-faced run-a-muck!
A side-splitting, thrill-a-minute adventure reminiscent of the best of The Flintstones. Wilma!
A well-deserved tribute to four Aussie lassies who risked their lives to entertain the boys.
An alternately comical and thought-provoking cautionary tale that's every bit as hilarious as it is sobering.
An eye-popping, patriotic, high-octane adventure that leaves no doubt about who's the vindicated hero that kept the world safe for democracy. The Butler did it! Gerard Butler, that is.
A present-day parable preaching to the choir with sobering warnings about taking your mate for granted and the love of money as the root of all evil. The Gospel according to Tyler Perry!
An unlikely-buddy horror flick which figured a viable way of walking a fine line between the sadistic and the sublime.

This compelling, modern morality play marking the noteworthy directorial debut of Jon Van Dyke amounts to a searing indictment of India's shameful caste system for its enslavement of females based on the color of their skin.
An emotionally-draining biopic featuring Oscar-quality performances from Harrison Ford and Chad Boseman in what is easily Hollywood's best offering of the year thus far.
A fascinating biopic as much about a possible miscarriage of justice as about a case of arrested development who looks like a little girl playing house with an imaginary mate.

This vapid, vulgar insult to the intelligence couldn't possibly have been tested on any focus groups. Can we all now agree that we've reached the cinematic saturation point with the rapidly-expiring, Scary Movie franchise?
A moving tribute to an overlooked American icon who invariably exhibited an admirable combination of integrity, humility and loyalty.
movie_title: The Life and Times of Hank Greenberg (2000)

movie_review_blurb: A riveting biopic about a rich kid-turned-rabid bully and pathological liar desperate enough for the limelight to sell his soul to the devil.
movie_title: Évocateur: The Morton Downey Jr. Movie (2013)

movie_review_blurb: A fitting tribute to the enviable exploits of the legendary Thor Heyerdahl.
Ghetto psychobabble strictly for the attention-deficit, Jay-Z demographic.
What happens in Nairobi, stays in Nairobi!

Carefully crafted with Evangelicals in mind, this modern parable will certainly resonate with the faith-based demographic as well as secular individuals interested in an entertaining, wholesome family flick with a sobering message.

An incoherent string of crude skits, including one where Robert De Niro sheepishly sports a substance-eating grin after being caught performing cunnilingus between a widespread pair of naked legs. Look! A falling star! Make a wish!
An eye-opening expose about the surprisingly-conventional concerns of some of the most hyper-sexualized women in the world.
A comical account of a year-long, money-burning party which ought to serve as a sobering warning for any equally-naïve entrepreneurs considering investing in China.
An amusing, if not exactly original, African-American variation on Meet the Parents.
A worthy addition to the vaunted Marvel franchise!
Revealing biopic examines roots and rise of world-class Williams sisters.
A powerful, empathetic portrait of a selfless, planetary patriot willing to sacrifice his liberty for the sake of Mother Earth's long-term prospects.
A safe sequel which, while certainly engaging and entertaining enough to recommend, fails to live up to the franchise's daring, appointed mission 'to boldly go where no man has gone before.'
The epitome of a summer blockbuster. Just remember to check your brain at the box office, and you won't be disappointed.

A simplistic, father-son morality play strictly for little kids and diehard Will and Jaden Smith fans. Destined to be added to the pantheon of inadvertently-funny blaxploitation flicks with a devoted cult following.
A reminder that while crime does not pay, it does sometimes serve as fodder for lurid headlines and hilarious hijinks.
A comfy, feelgood comedy that's fun for the whole family!
movie_title: Diary of a Wimpy Kid: Dog Days (2012)

movie_review_blurb: A very informative, thought-provoking and ultimately moving documentary exploring both the bright and dark sides of the Asian adoption controversy.
A dysfunctional family documentary which invites the audience to take pleasure in the misfortunes of some decidedly-decadent 1%ers.
A touching, tale of female empowerment serving as a worthwhile reminder that girls weren't always encouraged to play sports.
An ornithological delight designed with the bird fancier in mind!
Proves to be a riveting roller coaster ride from beginning to end, basically because it relies on a winning recipe featuring all the fixins needed to hold your undivided attention.

An intriguing, Marjoe-esque adventure, highlighting how a corporate position at IBM might have belatedly led a reluctant, designated-demigod down a path of enlightenment lined by throngs of gullible devotees-in-waiting.
All the fixins for a convoluted, costume drama of, dare I say it, Shakespearean proportions.
Despite a big, Hollywood budget allowing for a more grisly and more graphic, high attrition-rate adventure, this disappointing remake somehow still adds up to less. Rent the original.
A raunchy and religiously-incorrect roller coaster ride for the very-open minded, not to be mistaken for one of those sentimental Christmas yarns you usually see during the holiday season.
A romantic reminder of less-enlightened times when asking a woman her astrological sign was actually a viable pickup line.
A funny, if farfetched, revenge fantasy for folks bilked by the likes of Bernie Madoff.
A far more revealing look at the real Rampling than any of her nude scenes.

You can add The Story of Lovers Rock to the short list of must-see, politically-tinged documentaries which shed light on the cultural roots of a lesser-known musical genre, ala Calypso Dreams and Buena Vista Social Club.
Between the cross-dressing and pleas of 'Please don't leave me, Clyde!' brace yourself to see the vulnerable underbelly, literally and figuratively, of an anguished icon knocked off his pedestal.
Suggested solely for Twilight diehards, this underwhelming, unfunny melodrama amounts to little more than an uneventful setup for next year's grand finale.
A priceless reminder about the value of being able to accept yourself just the way you are without succumbing to the societal pressure to measure up to an unattainable, ideal body-type.
movie_title: America The Beautiful 2: The Thin Commandments (2011)

movie_review_blurb: A fascinating biopic as offbeat, engaging and readily-accessible as its endlessly-inventive subjects.
movie_title: Eames: The Architect And The Painter (2011)

movie_review_blurb: A bittersweet reminder that despite the debate surrounding the easy availability of Ritalin and Adderall, we've still come a long way from some less-enlightened methods of dealing with rebellious adolescents with attention-deficit issues.
A concatenation of scatological humor likely to keep only tiny tykes in stitches and howling away at a poop and fart jokes.
movie_title: Spy Kids: All the Time in the World in 4D (2011)

movie_review_blurb: A touching enough to recommend tale about an absentee father's belated, if bittersweet, quest for redemption.
An inspirational, modern morality play apt to restore your faith in humanity.
To think that in just one generation we've gone from Chico and the Man to Chica and the Girl!
A well-crafted, harrowing whodunit of Hitchcockian proportions!

It's impossible to guess what the end of the world might look like or how you might behave, but this alternately surreal, seductive and sobering descent into dystopia is as entertaining and good a guess as anybody's.
Welcome to the 21st Century edition of Sherlock Holmes, a well-rounded gent as likely to flex his brawn as his brain!
movie_title: Sherlock Holmes: A Game of Shadows (2011)

movie_review_blurb: A rarity in that it is an improvement over the Swedish language original, this intricately-woven, edge-of-your-seat whodunit is as graphic and grisly as it is cerebral and mind-bending.
movie_title: The Girl with the Dragon Tattoo (2011)

movie_review_blurb: A sobering look at what it might very well be like to grow up lesbian in the 'hood.
A mature Tom Cruise is in top form here, displaying a relatively-sophisticated savoir faire in lieu of the easy boyish charm that's served him so well in the past.
A potentially-underwhelming production elevated singlehandedly by another tour de force turned in by the ever-astounding Meryl Streep.
A silent love song that anyone who adores film can nonetheless hear, loud and clear!
A relentlessly-grim yarn revolving around a tragically-flawed trio being slowly swallowed whole by the emotional quicksand of a blue-collar wasteland where there really aren't any winners.
They don't make 'em like Prof anymore!
A glorious tribute to a bi-partisan sisterhood of Christian and Muslim women fed up with having to raise their children amidst the incessant slaughter, raping and looting of the Liberian civil war.
movie_title: Pray the Devil Back to Hell (2008)

movie_review_blurb: A hatchet job or an accurate portrait of a Machiavellian manipulator? That's apt to depend on whether you lean to the left or to the right.
A thought-provoking picture raising the question: Can a woman rape a man, or is it merely assault with intent to please? You be the judge.
A talky, tortoise-paced teensploit which teases far more than it titillates.
movie_title: The Myth Of The American Sleepover (2011)

movie_review_blurb: A refreshingly-tasteful, romantic romp which manages to entertain and elicit lots of laughs without relying on a vulgar brand of humor.
A benign, tot-oriented fable sharing a heartwarming message about the true meaning of friendship.

Paris has served as the backdrop for several superb revenge flicks recently, such as 'Taken,' 'District B-13' and 'From Paris with Love,' and this adrenaline-fueled thriller measures up well in comparison with the best of the genre.
A riveting documentary which chronicles the efforts of several intrepid community organizers to bring an end to black-on-black crime in the City of Chicago.
A convincing portrayal of the tragic plight of the HIV+ poor in South Africa.
What's next, the Lone Ranger and Tonto take on the Body Snatchers?

An invaluable lesson that there can be social consequences attached to playing a sport without a conscience even if you're the best around at throwing, whacking or catching a ball. Just ask Muhammad Ali.
Truth and reconciliation between blacks and whites in Mississippi belatedly achieved, like a dream deferred.
A feel-good flick which proves that primates are people, too!
movie_title: Rise of the Planet of the Apes (2011)

movie_review_blurb: A cinematic history lesson connecting the dots between Manifest Destiny and The Bush Doctrine.
A clarion call for the Middle East to emerge from the Middle Ages!
Death takes no holiday!
A fascinating account of an unassuming hero's harrowing ordeal during a decade-long effort to bring the truth about Bernie Madoff to light.
A curious cross of sex therapy and psychotherapy where nobody spends much time in bed or on the couch.
A well-intentioned idealist clueless enough to make Forest Gump look streetwise.
Brace yourself to laugh as much at the irreverent funnyman's profane language as at his pain!
movie_title: Kevin Hart: Laugh At My Pain (2011)

movie_review_blurb: An absolute must-see for anyone interested in appreciating the mindset and motivations of the charismatic militants who captured the imagination of an impatient generation of African-Americans in the wake of the murder of Dr. Martin Luther King.

Though paling in intensity to Traffic, Soderbergh' apocalyptic cautionary tale nevertheless presents a chillingly-plausible peek at how quickly civilization might unravel in the face of a rapidly-accelerating, extinction-level, biological event.
An intriguing feminist manifesto suggesting that trying to be more like a man might be a waste of a woman.
movie_title: I Don't Know How She Does It (2011)

movie_review_blurb: Cringe-inducing debauchery courtesy of The Godfather of Rap!
Provided you have a strong stomach for gore, don't miss this novel cinematic treat offering both an adrenaline fix and a compelling love story.

The unsmiling, ungracious, completely unfunny Reacher doesn't have a fraction of the personal charm of Ethan Hunt. But as one of a dying breed -- an action dude from the old school -- he deserves a measure of our understanding and sympathy... kind of.

This could be the best performance of Emily Blunt's excellent career, but she's often too good -- enacting a woman far less likable and much more screwed up than Hollywood heroines are usually allowed to be. In fact, it's ultimately hard to root for her.

This is much more than a film about women demanding to vote; it's about women's struggle to be heard and taken seriously, most notably in the workplace as well as in their own homes.

movie_title: Miss Peregrine's Home for Peculiar Children (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Free State of Jones is a worthy experience, both instructive and provocative -- a lot of what goes on here is starting to look too familiar for comfort.
Smith is splendid here -- her whole demeanor is testament to the resilience and toughness of a woman determined to survive, be it through old age or nuclear disaster.
"Ricky" also has its share of weirdness, but it's un-Ozon-like in that the queasy sense of distorted reality isn't in the details, but in the overall story itself.
While Hot Girls Wanted presents a damning portrayal of an industry in crisis, the wider issues at play are more complicated and nuanced than a 90-minute documentary allows for.
"Bad Moms" was written and directed by men, and you can totally tell that they tried really hard to write a movie that women would enjoy and identify with. Emphasis on tried.
Cheap thrills and a gimmicky twist at the climax keep The Uninvited in the realm of the subpar horror movie.
Had Confessions been truer to its chick-lit novel inspiration, the movie could have been fizzily enjoyable instead of sickening.

As Valentino's team of seamstresses pore over a sequined white dress, entirely hand-sewn, and finally premiere it to the designer in its flawless, couture glory, it's all you can do not to gasp with pleasure.

And though Bullock and Reynolds have snappy chemistry to spare, their love affair stops just shy of being believable. There are too many awkward 'tender' moments and not enough vigor for a real romance.
Despite the fact that it swims in a veritable ocean of romantic comedy clichés, The Ugly Truth should manage to captivate and charm men and women alike.

Instead of the vapid drivel you'd expect from their Disneyfied crowd, Bandslam turns out to be a charming (and well-soundtracked: Hello, Wilco!) little parable for the tween set about first crushes, friendship and like, duh, the power of music.
The Fourth Kind is legitimately scary enough to keep you in your seat. (Just don't Google the flick before you see it.)
The cinematography is what makes Leap Year worth seeing. Turns out Ireland is kind of pretty!
The Spy Next Door is so hokey that I couldn't help but wonder if I was watching a campy sendup. It opens with "Secret Agent Man," for god's sake!

Sure, the movie is predictable (a convenient storm causes power outages and therefore the dark house is creepily candlelit and who knows who's lurking behind the door), but it keeps its audience on edge.
movie_title: The Last House on the Left (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Aniston isn't the world's greatest actress, but the main reason The Bounty Hunter stinks is the script.
Hot Tub Time Machine is a surprisingly enjoyable way to waste 90 minutes if you're into dude humor and penis jokes.
[It] produces tons of laughs in its compact 90 minutes and doesn't overstay its welcome. The bad jokes are bad, but the good ones are great.
"Part of Me" succeeds because it's not afraid to let its big star be vulnerable.
Though incredibly predictable from start to finish, "We're the Millers" did make me laugh.
"The Kill Team" is emotionally heavy; as you watch, you feel conflicted about Winfield's role and about your own perception of right and wrong.

All in all, Bell and Duhamel (gee, that rhymes!) are not tearing down any barriers, but it's clear that they're having fun and their chemistry is palpable. I wouldn't be opposed to seeing them team up again.
It's a movie that feels perfectly at home in 2014, but wouldn't feel out of place in any other decade.
movie_title: Why Don't You Play in Hell? (2014)

movie_review_blurb: Not high art by any means, but it is pretty entertaining if you like a good slice of crazy horror-movie fun once in awhile.

movie_title: Rogue One: A Star Wars Story (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Her heart is still gold and her sense of humor fully intact, reminding us why we fell in love with her in the first place.
Writer/director Rian Johnson's entry into the Star Wars canon is rebelliously bold at times and full of rousing surprises, which make up for a few lulls in the lengthy two-and-a-half-hour run time.
Kenan Thompson and Kel Mitchell [are] a sensational comedy duo the likes of which haven't been seen since Abbott and Costello.
Like Wong's film stock, whose meager latitude won't let the eye deep into the image, Wong's characters, all 20-something slackers and grotesques, have the same lack of depth.
Sheen is a handsome and resourceful actor, but not enough so to win in this conspiracy of shadows over substance.
The movie belongs to Jai White, whose eyes, voice and movements lock the audience into his heart and struggle.

movie_review_blurb: Arguably the best action director in the world, Woo also manages complex emotional content and a deft way with music.

Director Mark Pellington creates complex characters in his new thriller I Melt With You, but unfortunately fails to deliver a realistic, intriguing story.
In Margin Call, first time writer-director JC Chandor creates a humanizing insight into the lives of the bankers who discovered the fall of the economy.
The film features one-dimensional, married characters who lack distinctive personalities, and fails to include a backstory that proves they ever had any chemistry together.

More madcap than the original, with even more spectacular set designs and production values.
All in all, it's great family fun.
The original Ocean's is fun, fun, fun.
Strauch makes a compelling case for the exhilaration of living, and dying, on your own terms, a freedom so few of us ever truly experience.
About an hour in, it finally dawned on me that perhaps the movie was giving me insights into masochism after all. As the minutes slowly, painfully ticked by I came to accept my punishment.

Some Kind of Monster is some weird kind of wonderful.
