The film equivalent of the blind date described as 'really nice.' It's neither bad nor good, just sort of earnest and well-meaning.
movie_title: A Home at the End of the World (2004)

movie_review_blurb: Thriller is hardly the word for this tedious exercise in clue-hiding.
Low-quality entertainment with only surface polish.
By treating funny women as normal people, Wiig has crafted a game-changing comedy that's even better than The Hangover.
Although adults will find it barely entertaining (even with one rather inappropriate Marilyn Monroe allusion), children will love the little blue folks...

Meticulously researched with great archive footage to accompany the contemporary commentary, the compelling chronicle captures the exciting essence of the time and shows just how famous Fischer became: this was a man who single-handedly made chess sexy.
The problem is that it's not terribly dramatic, despite good central performances from Jesse Eisenberg and Justin Bartha.
Its script seems to have been written by children.
A sharp and very American probe into payback that puts forward a strong, if not entirely watertight, case.
movie_title: Client 9: The Rise and Fall of Eliot Spitzer (2010)

movie_review_blurb: There's a good, snappy screwball comedy buried somewhere in the movie, but director Michael Dowse can't unearth it.
Your Highness is a well-made but lowbrow period comedy with limited appeal.
There's a solid supporting cast, including a long-haired William H Macy and a shamefully underused Marisa Tomei as Haller's ex-wife, while McConaughey more than holds his own in the lead.
Fans of How to Train Your Dragon will certainly be disappointed, much like everyone else.
Michell's seamless, steady direction lets McAdams's energy shine through and allows Ford and his fellow news anchor Diane Keaton to craft beautifully timed comedic performances...
A wonderfully funny comedy that shows young women in their real environment, competing with themselves.
Sometimes it's the little things that make the largest cultural impact, and Vidal Sassoon shows just how pivotal the work of one ambitious hairdresser can be.
Clipping along with a snappy script that isn't afraid to be silly, this rip-snorting swathe of derring-do is thoroughly enjoyable.
Watch it, and laugh at the truth about love.
This seasonal animated offering from Aardman has all the hallmarks of being a perennial festive favourite.
This lavish production of Tarzan creator Edgar Rice Burrough's space adventure has much to recommend it.

Despite a little sag in the middle, where the script could have used some extra punch, this wonderfully imaginative movie succeeds in being that rare thing: a family film that the whole family will enjoy.
The premise may be pretty ridiculous, but this movie surprises by actually making sense.
Let's just say that this is not a film that will endear itself to a female audience.
movie_title: Les femmes du 6e étage (The Women on the 6th Floor) (2011)

movie_review_blurb: The Three Stooges is far more enjoyable than it perhaps ought to be.
A gross, sprawling and barely credible teen comedy.
It's a lightweight confection, but Pitch Perfect is great fun while the fat lady (and the skinny one) sings.
There is nothing startling or challenging about Quartet, but it's a delightful film that touches on themes of ageing and the enduring importance of art.
It's far from intellectually taxing, but Little Fockers is much funnier than it deserves to be.
A fresh and colourful romantic comedy about typing? Surely some mistake? Au contraire.
writer/director Josh Boone has made a quiet romantic fantasy, complete with downbeat indie soundtrack, which in its own way is as unrealistic as any blockbuster but a perfectly pleasant watch.

Working with a tight, well-judged script and sensational animation that makes you want to go home and cook -- as well as be nicer to rodents -- director Brad Bird delivered the best family comedy of that year.
With laughs derived from depression, death and denial, this is Allen at this tartest, tightest and most observant.
Anonymous is poignant and shocking by turns, while maintaining an entertaining pace.
It isn't quite Love Story, but comes close.
The impressive abilities of this ensemble go underused in a clichéd comedy that stalls at nice and stupid on its way to profundity.
At least an interesting failure.

Big River Man is as close to documentary perfection as possible. Tough and vulnerable Strel is masculinity incarnate, and his quest gestures beyond his beloved red wine and beer and towards the mystical. Astonishing.

Julie & Julia is a heartfelt, deliciously shot, and beautifully designed romp, studded with fine performances that are endearingly cheery, inspirational and funny. It's a must-see for anyone who loves to eat.
Despite its schoolroom tone, The Vanishing of the Bees sounds an alarm; it's essential we heed it.
Parker and Grant sleepwalk their way through a flatline comedy in which old jokes can be seen coming a mile away.
movie_title: Did You Hear About the Morgans? (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Mixing elements of frisky French farce with middle-class American comedy, It's Complicated is a daffy and delectable spree.
Sandra Bullock turns in an excruciatingly kooky performance in this ill-conceived stalker romance.
Light, breezy, sentimental and amusing, Valentine's Day is delightful and cringe-making by turns as it sums up the heady pressures and potentially pivotal nature of the event.
The film manages to balance its weepie and thriller elements without ladling on the emotion or wallowing in sentimentality, but ultimately this is TV-movie material with Hollywood movie actors.
A light, frothy romance with just enough blarney to charm the susceptible.
The attempts at being witty end up being more gimmick than skill, and produce stereotypical characters depicted by average performances.
[Travolta and Williams] engage in a torrent of slapstick set-ups that are neither witty nor funny.
Oher's miserable start in life shouldn't have happened, but it did -- and The Blind Side is a film that shouldn't work, but does.
Surprisingly watchable for the third sequel and despite its general predictability it's entertainingly inventive.
movie_title: A Nightmare on Elm Street 4: The Dream Master (1988)

movie_review_blurb: Despite its flaws, this is a wonderfully filmed romance that will have even the toughest of guys dabbing away the tears.
Kids may love this film - they're the target audience after all - but adults should stand well back.
A bemusing black comedy that is as unfocused as it is unbelievable.
Lopez deserves better than this excruciating material. In fact, all actors do.
Nicely weighted performances and the beautiful Italian setting combine to make this an unassuming treat.
The gross-out level is kept to a minimum and the language is reasonably clean, making it a refreshing change from similar testosterone-fueled movies.

Though its production values are on the low side and it flounders a little as it bounces from Hollywood to India, overall it's a fascinating, energetic and enlightening film that'll ensure you'll never look at hair the same way again.
The action sequences, as expected with Chan, are amazing. These, along with a snappy pace, stunning locations and credible performances, counterbalance the film's overlong running time.
A milestone film for both actor and film-maker, Locke is extraordinary viewing.
Undermined by its inability to stand separately from its predecessor.
movie_title: Why Did I Get Married Too (2010)

movie_review_blurb: The cast is spectacular: Roberts looks relaxed, luminous and credible, Javier Bardem is suitably rugged as her new lover, while Richard Jenkins is brilliant as her grumbling prayer pal.
The cinematography and some of the performances are not stellar, but Goldthwait's script is extraordinary, examining the choices we make between surviving and really living.
This take on the classic cop v robbers formula makes for handsome, smart and fast-paced entertainment.
The two leads have screen appeal, but the chemistry between them is thin, while the story wavers between hackneyed clichés and incredibility...
The erratic, barely humorous dialogue here is even more ghastly than your average spoof, while Jason Friedberg and Aaron Seltzer's direction is patchy, to say the least.
So what if the owls' beaks look weird and there's a lot of death, slavery and brainwashing? This is a breathtakingly beautiful film for courageous kids who aren't afraid of heights.
movie_title: Legend of the Guardians: The Owls of Ga'Hoole (2010)

movie_review_blurb: Secretariat's story still feels untold.
A seamless debut feature for Derrick Borte as writer, director and producer.
Poor special effects (with weak echoes of better superhero outings such as Spider-Man) and an uneven central performance contribute to what was one of the flop blockbusters of 2004.
This American remake of the 2007 UK-set farce is superior in every way.
Testament of Youth is tasteful and lyrical, but it still packs a punch.
Despite plodding interchanges and lack of cinematic bravura for some of America's most spectacular scenery, Redford and Nolte are genuinely hilarious together.

Although it doesn't strictly adhere to the facts, McFarland is a treasure trove of sporting goodness, while also being a warm, human tale about love, family and learning that a high pain threshold is part of the ticket to success.
Both educational and entertaining, the rise and fall of the most alluring and controversial black organisation of America's late 60s comes to life via facts, vivid images and unique statements.
movie_title: The Black Panthers: Vanguard Of The Revolution (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Despite its levity and wild shifts in tone, The Dressmaker is a heartbreaking tragicomedy. It's also imaginative, funny, colourful, poignant and unforgettable.
Director Lisa Immordino Vreeland rams this otherwise fairly conventional documentary with glamour and sadness meaning, content-wise, there is never a dull moment.
A story about intergenerational bonding in a non-icky way, it's not for the whole family, but it is one hell of a ride for anyone with a lot of miles on the biological clock.
In the Heart of the Sea is watchable enough. It just doesn't harpoon us the way its maker intended.
movie_title: In the Heart of the Sea (2015)

movie_review_blurb: A fresh-faced crowd-pleaser as smart and informed in the story's lore as it is rousing for Rocky fans and the uninitiated alike.
Credible, hilarious and poignant by turns, Rams is a keenly detailed, well-paced and entertaining tale of family dynamics ...

The movie is wordy, worthy and often bombastic in dialogue, with Blanchett the backbone of the story while Redford's careful, nuanced portrayal of the nation's most trusted news anchor is a study in understatement.
A sequel that ticks off all the right topics but only superficially. It simply doesn't have time to do more.
If Jane Got a Gun is not the rousing feminist western we've been waiting for, it is a pony trek in the right direction.

Joffe conjures superb performances from the perfect cast: this is Firth and Kidman at their best. A sexy, chilling and stylish trick of the light, this psychological thriller knows exactly what it's doing.
Pacey and completely entertaining, this comedy rocks.
Kline and ex-rock star Rick Springfield fit in well while Streep convinces as the failed rock star with a heart of gold-plate - tight leather, dumb hair and all.
Pivoting on a loving couple growing older, not having finances in place, needing to rely on others to get by, Love Is Strange has universal poignancy.
If you like to be scared, The Conjuring 2 is your upside-down crucifix.
Absolutely stonking action like you haven't seen in years.
It's a stellar role for Lively, who ... is amassing a respectable body of work across genres.
Spinal Tap and Zoolander come together in a comedy take on the pop industry that's hot for the first half before it cools into submission.
It's Ben-Hur for sure, but no real improvement on what's gone before; save Morgan Freeman's amazing dreadlocks.
Studded with smart couplets, dance numbers and scenes of grief verging on the Shakespearean, this vibrant, controversial film from director Spike Lee is deft and timely in its message.
Sentimental and just plain mental, this is the comedy we need this holiday season.
A breezy, likeable comedy with the potential to make both slackers and old schoolers smile.
Despite a perky pace and a serious eco message, Monster Trucks is far from fresh.
Lady Macbeth is daring cinema that will chill you to the bone and leave you rooting for its understandably immoral heroine.
Winstone ... enlivens even the simplest dialogue; the reason he's a star is his ability to conjure meaning that may be absent or ambiguous in the script itself.
An honest look at a well-worn subject, this home-grown drama about a boxer's fight back to sobriety packs some punch.
Logan Lucky is like those inline tube slides at a water park: you don't worry about where you're going, because getting there is so much darned fun.

What some will find a surprisingly unpredictable, action-packed bit of entertainment, others may find a politically dubious gun-and-bomb party, but this is one of the freshest political thrillers in years.
Even hardened horror fans will find themselves covered in gooseflesh, as this spooky sequel ratchets up the tension like thumbscrews.
If Wes Anderson met John Hughes and they made a weepy, this would be it.
movie_title: Me and Earl and the Dying Girl (2015)

movie_review_blurb: A solid if lacklustre police caper with some sparkling moments.
A soundtrack of 40 chosen tunes and sideline looks at Daft Punk's genesis makes Hansen-Lve's assured fourth feature a heady trip for all ex-ravers.
As a spoof on popular culture and politics, it's naughty, dumb and patchily funny. And while Franco chews the scenery, Rogen and Park display excellent comic timing.
Argo is one of this year's must-see films which, unlike most, is tremendous entertainment.
Whatever you do, don't go to see Chef on an empty stomach -- it's a feel-good foodie film that will have you salivating within minutes.
The more you know, the more you want to stampede to the museum to see these works in person.
Michael Keaton's performance as ex-leading man Riggan Thomson sees this former star reborn.
A huge contender for film of the year - certainly it is one of the must-sees of 2014 ...
This is real love: there is old age, there is debt, there is misunderstanding. There are also terrific performances that will make this romance a modern classic.
This beautifully designed and photographed period drama, adapted from Andrew Hodges' book The Enigma by debut screenwriter Graham Moore, centres on three important points of Turing's life.

Wallis keeps things watchable, exuding real screen presence. However, even with talented singer Foxx onboard, there isn't a single memorable rendition of the familiar tunes, and 'Tomorrow' hangs around like a kitchen odour.
Night at the Museum: Secret of the Tomb is so laboured and lousy it makes you want to punch yourself in the face.
movie_title: Night at the Museum: Secret of the Tomb (2014)

movie_review_blurb: Alas, although not charmless, it breathes no new life into the rom-com genre, being neither particularly romantic nor comic.
A pristine Cold War lookbook of 1960s spy fashion.
No matter how you felt about him or when you came to know of him or his work, James captures the most poignant and amazing snatches of Ebert's spirit.
A sobering look at what the American government, at least, is doing in the name of security.
This is a film that edifies and also gives hope -- even if that glimmer is currently beyond the realms of reality.
Heartening, heart-warming and heartbreaking, Love Is Strange is a road trip through a durable, fascinating romance.
Certainly, we'd all like to touch, sniff and lick great art and this gives us the opportunity to get up close and personal without getting arrested.
As events (both kind and cruel) unfold, even the most seasoned movie-goer will find something here to surprise -- and shock.
Predestination twists and turns so often you won't be sure which way to look.
Stylish, sleek, sharp and almost glib, this terrific debut by writer/director Justin Simien is a streamlined satire that swaps subtlety for jaw-dropping honesty.
Prediction: more tweets, Snapchats and texts will be sent during this film than during the original.
This is one documentary that's a must-see for anyone interested in film history, or seeing hope and enthusiasm triumph critical and financial success.
movie_title: Electric Boogaloo: The Wild, Untold Story of Cannon Films (2012)

movie_review_blurb: Ozon unashamedly sails straight into the incredible, with fantasies and twists to at least keep the audience guessing.
Strong performances and vivid production design buoy up this evocative, troubling film that shows flashes of brilliance from writer/director Simon Blake, making his feature debut.
Free of violence, death or graphic sex, this romantic fantasy is an easy-going throwback to women's films of yore, complete with a smooth narration filling in the gaps.

Man Up is heaped with wit and insight, and its smart script, sharp direction and crisp performances, all set against buzzing London streets that denizens will recognise, give it the feel of a frisky romantic version of After Hours.
More stirring than National Velvet, less sentimental than Champions, Dark Horse never contrives to make us cry. And, like a well-told tale at the pub, it grips from start to finish.
This is a sleek, wet, near noir, with neon and shadows aplenty. Essentially, it's really rather good.

In this occasionally brilliant, if somewhat uneven, showcase of speedy plotting and even speedier improvisation, Hart and Ferrell's chemistry is such that it seems certain to pair them up in the future.
Packed with montages and non-sequiturs, this is a weird-ass business comedy that still manages to pack a tiny emotional sucker punch in the end.
At points it feels like a competent thriller built on deeply sketchy bones.

An unusual, thoughtful drama that takes a novel look at the fountain of youth, and that afterwards will have those seeking nothing more than a little light entertainment commenting, 'Well, that was quite nice, wasn't it?'
It's an exciting, fast-paced, beautifully photographed and often enthralling race against time, as well as a riveting social commentary on sexism and sexuality.
The parade of increasingly traumatic events results in some glum goings-on, so viewers need to hold on to the film's brighter moments.

The film's complex story of children's natural compassion clashing with the adult-mandated need for decisive power-plays is worthwhile, but it's almost lost in the dazzling display of video-game prowess that dominates most of the screen time.
By turns funny, rousing, intriguing, sad and frustrating.
Testament of Youth is an exquisitely composed portrayal of the despair and futility of World War I as seen from the rarely revealed viewpoint of an idealistic young woman.
At its best, it's handsome and occasionally entertaining; at its worst, it's painful to watch, and not in a poignant, life-lesson, human relationship sort of way.

Witty and not afraid to be occasionally awkward, Rebecca Miller's film zips along at a charming pace before stumbling past a perfectly acceptable stopping point and dragging the whole affair out beyond its ability to entertain.
Where does happiness come from? That's the question at the heart of Trolls, a 3-D feature ablaze with neon color and good cheer from DreamWorks Animation.
The unabashed freedom and high spirits of the film are almost overshadowed by the brutally sobering ending.
Playing a close second in making the film (which is about 15 minutes longer than it needs to be) worth watching is the remarkable footage and photographs of Didion at home and at work.
movie_title: Joan Didion: The Center Will Not Hold (2017)

movie_review_blurb: It's guided by a masterful performer with the unwavering support of a spot-on cast that, like those in the best of Bennett's plays, are all on the same page.

Bleak and beautiful, it's a moody drama built on subtle performances and a stunningly well-written script. Setting it apart is an enigmatic ending that allows viewers to come to their own conclusions.

Pop icon Blige, nearly unrecognizable, is a tower of strength and mercy as her character battles to support her besieged family through one hardship after another -- including one that is mercilessly barbaric.

Jim & Andy: The Great Beyond uses that nearly 20-year-old footage, along with contemporary commentary by a handsomely bearded and gracefully aging Carrey, to tell a story of two men who pretty much become one.
movie_title: Jim & Andy: The Great Beyond - Featuring a Very Special, Contractually Obligated Mention of Tony Clifton (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Even the most attentive viewers to start wondering what's on the menu at the pub across the street. Such distracting thoughts may prevent learning the outcome, which bolts into the film at the speed of light, and fades away almost as fast.
The look, achieved by John Wakayama Carey to reflect a simple beauty of the surroundings, is the finishing flourish of a film that delivers a punch nobody will see coming.

What's the best reaction to news that a young adult is the victim of terminal cancer? There are practically endless responses, and it seems most of them are explored -- with great earnestness but little success -- in Irreplaceable You.
Intoxicatingly complicated and spiked with moral ambivalence, Mute is a sci-fi noir that requires concentration.
Alternately frustrating and disappointing, the film touts its true-story roots. But despite Lawrence's doggedly good-natured work, it's hard to fall in love with a woman and her mop.
It ain't got game.
Ryder, as gamine as ever, delivers her most credible performance to date, while the luminous Simmons and imposing Angelou infuse the film with grace and understated charm.

movie_review_blurb: Bless me, anyone, for I sat stupefied through this film.
Rent Rear Window instead.
Eighty-nine of the longest minutes ever endured in recent cinema.

Will the Mayor learn to dip his fingers in something more filling than holy water? Will Vianne find true love? Will eating too much ganache before finishing your haricots verts give you a stomachache?

The mystery of just what happened to the child unspools almost languidly against the backdrop of wild and gorgeous New Zealand country. The ugliness of humans amid such beauty resounds like a cold slap.
Lewis is a star in her prime, and more smart directors should put her to work.
The star of this Scottish fable, about the mythical Loch Ness monster, looks like a raw chicken breast with teeth when he hatches.
movie_title: The Water Horse: Legend of the Deep (2007)

movie_review_blurb: In a town full of delightful misfits, Waters may be Baltimore's sanest citizen.
What we are seeing is the most rational irrationality-and all sheer artifice anyway.
Enchanting fantasy turns teen into sweet, selfless princess.
[Upside Down] a designer's dream, but the dialogue is forced and the film is dependent on its aesthetic value.
Complex messages for teens save so-so TV movie.
Raw look at teen life more shocking than you might recall.
Inspiring docu tackles a tough topic: racism.
Cute musical sells songs -- and merchandise.
Twisty period drama has dark tone, mature sexual themes.
Teen horror flick is big on blood, cliques -- and revenge.
Classic miniseries tackles weighty women's issues.
Although The Normal Heart is a work of fiction, the stories it tells about the emerging AIDS crisis in America are honest and heartbreakingly real, thanks to deeply affecting performances.
Wartime docu can be grim but possibly inspiring to teens.
Offbeat drama about modern babymaking turns dark and bloody.
Gory teen-scream sequel includes teen drinking and sex.
A beautiful illustration of powerlessness in the face of art.
Thoughtfully persuades, but never shocks.
Uber crowd-pleasing...both candy for confirmed theater nerds, and functioning propaganda for the uninitiated.
Let the Right One In is certainly well-made and miles more thoughtful than you might expect a teenage vampire film to be.
Two Lovers is a testament to the childish madness of infatuation, and maybe even true love's impossibility.
There's a vaguely appealing elegance to the way the film moves -- that is, when the actors stop spouting laughably portentous dialogue long enough for one to appreciate the film's pacing.
The magic of Limits is that Jarmusch has used rigorous formalism to construct what feels like a loose, dreamy continuum of ideas.
I can count on half a hand the things I found appealing about the middle fifty minutes of this movie, but I'll be damned if I don't want to know what happens next...
Thrillingly far off the rails.
The Hangover, Todd Phillips' return to fratastic form after the disappointing School for Scoundrels, marks itself as an aesthetic step up for the Old School director right from the get go.
At once austere and seductive.
A psychological thriller that looks like art but satisfies as a work of genre.
Glorious.
If Johnson doesn't reinvent the con man wheel, he pulls off a magic act in the romance department, reinvigorating the fiction that first love can be the last/best/only love ever needed.
He's Just Not That Into You is smart for what it is, but it refuses to be condescendingly smarter than the people it exists to please. And that makes it even smarter.
movie_title: He's Just Not That Into You (2009)

...as [a] densely layered, intensely visual work of creative autobiography, Tetro claims a key place in the Coppola filmography. At least, for the first time in the last few decades worth of filmography, it feels like it's got somewhere to take you.
Real-life mockumentary.
Memorial Day sets up the party zone as a moral equivalent to the war zone, hammers that connection home and then stops-content with offering an equation in lieu of an argument
Benjamin Button is a film about the feat of its own whiz-bang, Frankensteinian digital imagery, drunk on its own accomplishment to an extent that feels quasi-ethical.
movie_title: The Curious Case of Benjamin Button (2008)

movie_review_blurb: An Education works as a fever dream of first love, but the wake-up is unsatisfying.

The rare love letter to influence that's infused with enough personal style and sentiment to transform the stolen into something thrilling and moving

We drink every time Angelina hysterically proclaims, "He's not my son!" We get very drunk, and this may be why we can't figure out why Clint Eastwood made a cheap-looking Lifetime movie that eventually turns into an "And justice for all!" episode of SVU.

Nick and Norah, and their assorted pals drift fluidly between irony-as-defense and taking both themselves, and the idea of love, very seriously. The result is a film that's much more of a traditional teen romance, but also a more honest one.

He documents an undeniably affecting personal story, and patches it together like a short attention span scrapbook with his fingerprints intact, but there's something about it which feels false enough to undercut some of its potential power.
movie_title: Dear Zachary: A Letter to a Son About His Father (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Spring Breakdown rides a very fine line between total trash and intelligent provocation, mall multiplex dreck and Troma-esque satire via the grotesque.

movie_title: Un Conte de Noël (A Christmas Tale) (2008)

movie_review_blurb: This is a film which asks us to contemplate the deeply complicated relationship between rational thought and instinctual feeling via a perverse intermingling of global horror and very, very local pain.
Rourke delivers a performance that seems to start and end in the cardiovascular system, making everything Rourke actually does seem effortless. As if he's just breathing it.
Gran Torino is most fun when it's working on the level of performance art, and much of the time, it resembles an art school take on an insult comic's one-man show.

Certainly the best work Mendes has ever produced for the screen, Revolutionary Road works as a showcase for performances: DiCaprio and Winslet are at the top of their game.

Moon manages to be both derivative and deliberately rebellious in its treatment of sci-fi tropes. Moon is a story that digs deep into the traumas of people being people.
A whip-smart, uproariously funny comedy which uses a "bros will be bros" dare as the in point to talk about the inevitable loss of self in long term relationships.
Milk is a film about the politics of sex, in which the political process itself not only takes precedence over but seems to stand in for the complexities of real life sexuality.
Like swimming laps in bowl of room-temperature oatmeal.
A must see for anyone interested in internet fame and the phenomenon of casual over-sharing, even if the storytelling tactics are surprisingly stale.
One gets swept up in the first soapy, then tragic melodrama of the life matter that overwhelmed Rogers' desire/compulsion/ability to make art.
A beautifully made but not completely intellectually satisfying mirror on contemporary French upward mobility.
A lament for the lost luxuries of time and space.
Never has the bizarre beauty of degraded low-grade video been exploited to this extent.
The kind of feel-good film about bad news that has been winning Oscars for decades.
It's beautiful dread.
Blending CGI and live action, this "squeakquel" to the witless 2007 kids' film proves just how dangerous such technology is when placed in the wrong hands.

If the film doesn't get anywhere narratively, that's just form following content: The Moshers themselves don't go anywhere, either.

Stuffed with talking heads, Harlan is overlong and redundant, but its core questions are worthy.
movie_title: Harlan - Im Schatten von Jud Süss (Harlan: In the Shadow of Jew Seuss) (2010)

Watching Thorn is like being helplessly locked out of an inside joke.

Never as shocking as it thinks it is, as funny as it should be, or as engaged in cultural critique as it could be.
Bears the mark of a painter, full of deceptively beautiful imagery masking multiple layers of meaning.
Bittersweet.
This is scary in a way that unrelenting brutality could never be.
A powerfully loony portrait of American rot.

movie_review_blurb: ...this is pure 1930s movie escapism, which would be fine if Spinotti's camera was up to the task of capturing the contrast between the glitzy dance halls where Dillinger plays and the scrappy climes in which he hides.

Apatow has taken blisteringly personal material and filtered it through tropes and cliches borrowed from trite, mainstream factory-line cinema of another era. Judd Apatow the writer deserves a better director.

Cinerina invites her first guest reviewer, Melanie Treco. See full review for details.

Unfortunately for this movie, television has evolved well past this degree of silliness and spoon feeding, leaving our beloved X-Files in the vault. I wanted to believe it would be fun movie, but this was definitely time spent.

movie_title: Night at the Museum 2: Battle of the Smithsonian (2009)

movie_review_blurb: My six companions and I uniformly fell in love with this movie, and I can't wait to see it again, even at $15 for 3-D.
Jenkins, as always has a quiet, almost apologetic hesitation to his performance that serves him well as Walter....a very sweet and gentle film.
He antagonized people, he galvanized people, and he mesmerized me even from beyond the grave thanks to Penn's and Van Sant's beautiful and inspiring work here.
Is the movie trying too hard? In moments of self-doubt, I wonder...I found the performances stellar and I was emotionally rocked and rolled; I ask for little more.
Writing this review gave me more appreciation for the film as a work than I had while I was watching it. Perhaps it was intended to be more like a lovely poem or a painting.

We left the theatre feeling that we had spent a satisfying evening at the movies, but in retrospect I wish the screenwriters had tweaked the story's sophistication as much as they did the technical effects.

movie_review_blurb: There is a plot, but it only exists to give Ferrell and Reilly some focus for their juvenilia. While this sounds like a negative comment, it's actually not.

Basically a 95 minute homage to Waiting for Guffman and Ed Wood (the filmmaker, not the Johnny Depp biopic)...pokey but generally charming.

I have to confess that at times I was so flabbergasted by the incredible camerawork and long shots, I forgot to listen to the story. I loved it.
Any movie that inspires an audience to clap during and after with such incredible performances is definitely worth your money.
Dench and Blanchett are wonders to behold, wielding their respective powers over each other and drawing near and far, sparking flames between themselves.
They aren't superheroes. They are afraid. It's OK to be afraid - to not be afraid would be stupid or insane. Courage is feeling the fear and acting anyway, and that is what these men did.
Eccentric...heartbreakingly hilarious...terrific tension of inevitability...one of those movies that form my raison d'etre as a movie reviewer.
Well, if you liked Anchorman: The Legend of Ron Burgundy, you'll probably love Talladega Nights: The Ballad of Ricky Bobby. I did not like Anchorman.
movie_title: Talladega Nights: The Ballad of Ricky Bobby (2006)

movie_review_blurb: The marketing campaign is superb for this movie: it shows the beauty and the mystery of the story without the actually incredibly complex structure of it...full of magic and beauty.

It's an identity crisis wrapped in a mystery and smothered in freakout sauce, and it's relentlessly interesting. The grooviest scenes are the ones where the characters are clearly impaired and riffing on their own inner alpha waves.
More of the same, and more of it...at a bladder-challenging 145 minutes, it's packed to the gills, but never feels rushed or lazy. Lazy? No way. These people are working HARD.
movie_title: Pirates of the Caribbean: Dead Man's Chest (2006)

movie_review_blurb: If you want to explore the ideas of love and emotional permeability while seeing a narratively complex world of sexual self-exploration to which few are privy, then this is the movie for you. Otherwise, run for your life.

I'm not a fanboy, but Superman Returns is a great triumph, an ode both to the DC icon and the late Man of Steel who played him before, and it is a terrific adventure all around.

While it is a sobering film, it is not depressing...there might be more fun ways to spend your summer afternoon, but Gore infuses his talk with much more than just, as he calls it, a nature hike through the Book of Revelations.

If you are a woman, or if you love one, you should see it. You will see yourself somewhere, as with all her movies, and it will change the way you see yourself as well...Holofcener nderstands us better than we admit we understand ourselves
The true merit of the movie is the momentary pleasures of the dialogue and the performances, but the story itself leaves you wanting. So, is it art? Looks like it.
Expected to be disappointed after having been so scared by the original, I was pleased to find the antichrist plot device to be new and exciting again.

I walked into the movie with kind of low expectations (too many big names, not enough of an apparent premise, untested animation company), and walked out with a gigantic smile on my face and a desire to see it again.

The lack of camp is either what is best about the film or what is desperately wrong...It's worth seeing for Streep alone, or making fun of the clothes, but don't spend too much money on it.

no girl or boy over the age of 12 would be attracted by anything so puerile, while its UK certificate and occasionally risqué subject matter rule out under-12s.

In the case of Oboler's film, the story is, for once, not the most important thing about it. Rather, the manner in which it is presented becomes of prime interest.

Altogether Hamlet is one of the most impressive films ever made and, so far as Shakespeare's work is concerned, it need never be done again on stage nor for the screen, as the Olivier production... may stand for all time as THE Hamlet.

Appealing to the whole family and giving Julie Andrews a chance to sing and perform charmingly, it presents Christopher Plummer as Captain Von Trapp, a role that is sure to enhance the popularity of this fine actor.
Lean and photographer Fred A. Young have combined their artistic talents in an evocation of the Arabian desert that makes it both terrifying and deeply moving in its lonely grandeur.
Walt Disney has waved his magic wand over Collodi's world-famous fairy story, "Pinocchio," and presto! he has changed it into the most enchanting film ever brought to the screen.
A delightful entertaining film that will appeal to the young and the not-so young alike.
It is a picture that will charm the young and tickle adults, since the old fairy tale has been transferred to the screen by a Disney who kept his tongue in his cheek throughout the film's animation.
Judy Garland is perfectly cast as Dorothy. She is as clever a little actress as she is a singer and her special style of vocalizing is ideally adapted to the music of the picture.
It is light, it is charming, it is delightfully funny and completely captivating. It is all that, and something more.
Some day, and the time won't be long in arriving, Welles will be the greatest director in Hollywood.
The film is as charming as it is novel in conception and execution and it is so bound to appeal as strongly to grown-ups as to youngsters.
movie_title: Snow White and the Seven Dwarfs (1937)

movie_review_blurb: [Taylor] is nothing less than brilliant as the shrewish, slovenly. blasphemous, frustrated, slightly wacky, alcoholic wife of a meek, unambitious assistant professor of history at a university, over which her father reigns as president.
Natalie Wood, who was made a hit in the Kazan-Inge production of Splendor In the Grass and is the most promising young star of today, gives a fine dramatic performance.
For those who've seen the stage show, My Fair Lady give complete satisfaction and those who will see and hear the musical for the first time will be enchanted by it.
There isn't a dull moment in the picture.
There has never been a picture like David O. Selznick's production of Gone With the Wind.
Overall, the film is sweet but often loses impact in its most serious moments by blasting a happy pop soundtrack.
